[[Remo Sernagiotto]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2020 deaths, Former MEPs, MEPs for Italy, Deaths from myocardial infarction

Remo Sernagiotto (1 September 1955 – 29 November 2020) was an Italian politician. He was born in Montebelluna, Italy. He was a member of the Christian Democrat. He was first elected to the Regional Council of Veneto in 2000 for Forza Italia (FI). 

He was re-elected to the Regional Council of Veneto in 2005.

In the 2014 European Parliament election Sernagiotto was elected member of the European Parliament (MEP) and left office in 2019.

Sernagiotto died on 29 November 2020 from a heart attack at the age of 65.

[[Montebelluna]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Veneto

[[Viorel Turcu]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, 2020 deaths, Romanian footballers, Deaths from myocardial infarction

Viorel Turcu (9 August 1960 – 29 November 2020) was a Romanian footballer. He played as a midfielder. He was born in Popești, Romania. Turcu made seven appearances for the national team in 1982.

Turcu died on 29 November 2020 in Piatra Neamț, Romania at the age of 60.

[[Piatra Neamț]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Romania

Piatra Neamț (ˈpjatra ˈne̯amt͡s), Kreuzburg an der Bistritz, Karácsonkő) is the capital city of Neamț County, in the historical region of Western Moldavia, in northeastern Romania.

[[Betty Bobbitt]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, American movie actors, American television actors, Australian movie actors, Australian television actors, Actors from New York City, Actors from Melbourne, Naturalised citizens of Australia, Deaths from stroke, Cardiovascular disease deaths in Australia

Betty Ann Bobbitt (February 7, 1939 – November 30, 2020) was an American-born Australian actress, director, singer, and playwright. She was born in New York City. Bobbitt's career began in 1957. She was known for her cameos in the Crocodile Dundee movie series playing American tourists. She also played Judy Bryant in the 1980s comedy Prisoner.

Bobbitt died on November 30, 2020 in Melbourne from a stroke at the age of 81.

[[Kiran Maheshwari]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in India, Indian politicians

Kiran Maheshwari (29 October 1961 – 30 November 2020) was an Indian politician. She was born in Udaipur, Rajasthan. Maheshwari was a member of the Bharatiya Janata Party. She was a member of the Lok Sabha from 2004 to 2009. 

Maheshwari died of COVID-19 on 30 November 2020 at a hospital in Gurgaon, Haryana at the age of 59.

[[Mildred Harris]]

CATEGORIES: 1901 births, 1944 births, American child actors, American silent movie actors, Actors from Wyoming, People from Cheyenne, Wyoming

Mildred Harris (November 29, 1901 – July 20, 1944) was an American actress. She was also the first wife of Charlie Chaplin.

She appeared in Frank Capra's 1928 silent drama The Power of the Press with Douglas Fairbanks, Jr. and Jobyna Ralston and the same year, starred in Universal Pictures first sound movie Melody of Love opposite Walter Pidgeon.

[[Amazon river dolphin]]

CATEGORIES: Mammals of South America, River dolphins

The Amazon river dolphin, boto, bufeo or pink dolphin (Inia geoffrensis) is one of five species of river dolphin. The Amazon river dolphin lives in the Amazon River and Orinoco River. It is greyish pink in color.  It is endangered because of dams and water pollution, especially mercury pollution.

[[Lita Grey]]

CATEGORIES: 1908 births, 1995 deaths, American silent movie actors, American movie actors, Actors from Los Angeles, California

Lita Grey (born Lillita Louise MacMurray, April 15, 1908 – December 29, 1995), who was known for most of her life as Lita Grey Chaplin, was an American actress. She was the second wife of Charlie Chaplin.

[[Paulette Goddard]]

CATEGORIES: 1910 births, 1990 deaths, Deaths from heart failure, Deaths from emphysema, American silent movie actors, American stage actors, Movie producers from New York City, Models from New York City, American dancers, Actors from New York City

Paulette Goddard (born Marion Levy; June 3, 1910 – April 23, 1990) was an American actress and model. She was known as one of the  Ziegfeld Girl.

She became a major star of  Paramount Pictures in the 1940s. Her most known movies were her first major role, as Charlie Chaplin's leading lady in Modern Times, and Chaplin's movie The Great Dictator. 

She was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress for her performance in So Proudly We Hail! (1943).

[[Modern Times (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 movies, 1930s comedy movies, American comedy movies, Movies directed by Charlie Chaplin

Modern Times is a 1936 American silent comedy movie written and directed by Charlie Chaplin. It is known for being the last time that Chaplin played the Tramp character and for being the first time Chaplin's voice is heard on movie.

In 1989, Modern Times was one of the first 25 movies selected by the Library of Congress for preservation in the United States National Film Registry for being "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant".

[[The Kid (1921 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 movies, 1920s comedy movies, 1920s drama movies, American comedy-drama movies, Movies directed by Charlie Chaplin

The Kid  is a 1921 American silent comedy-drama movie written, produced, directed and starring Charlie Chaplin and Jackie Coogan. 

In 2011, The Kid was selected for preservation in the United States National Film Registry by the Library of Congress as being "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant." 

[[The Tramp]]

CATEGORIES: Fictional British people

The Tramp (Charlot in several languages), also known as The Little Tramp, was British actor Charlie Chaplin's most well known character on-screen and has become an icon in world cinema. The character was popular during the era of silent movies. 

The character is known to be humorous, often acting drunk, and clumsy. 

[[Kid Auto Races at Venice]]

CATEGORIES: 1914 movies, 1910s comedy movies, American sports comedy movies, American silent movies, Short movies

Kid Auto Races at Venice (also known as The Pest) is a 1914 American movie starring Charlie Chaplin. The movie is known for being the first appearance of Chaplin's well known Little Tramp" character.

[[Tom Casperson]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from lung cancer, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Michigan, US Republican Party politicians

Tom Casperson (July 20, 1959 – November 29, 2020) was an American politician. He was born in Escanaba, Michigan. He was a Republican member of the Michigan State Senate from 2011 to 2018. He was a member of the Michigan State House of Representatives from 2003 to 2008.

Caperson died on November 29, 2020 from lung cancer in Escanaba at the age of 61.

[[Michael J. Budds]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, American educators, Musicologists, Writers from Illinois, Writers from Missouri

Michael Joseph Budds (June 11, 1947 – November 19, 2020) was an American musicologist. He was a professor at the University of Missouri in Columbia, Missouri. Many of his works focused on American popular music. He was born in Pana, Illinois.

Budds died on November 19, 2020 in Columbia at the age of 73.

[[Agnieszka Chylińska]]

CATEGORIES: Polish people, 1976 births, Living people

Agnieszka Barbara Chylińska (born May 23, 1976, in Gdańsk) is a Polish singer-songwriter, actress, dancer, author and television personality.

From 1994 to 2003, she was the vocalist for the Polish rock band O.N.A.. Since 2003 she has performed as Chylińska and in 2004 she released an album titled Winna. Since 2008 she has been a judge on the Polish version of the Got Talent franchise called Mam talent!. In 2009, she released a studio album Modern Rocking, then Forever Child (2016) and Pink Punk (2018)

[[João Alves Filho]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Brazilian politicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil

João Alves Filho  (3 July 1941 – 24 November 2020) was a Brazilian politician and civil engineer. He was governor of the state of Sergipe from 1983 to 1987, from 1991 to 1995, and from 2003 to 2007.  From 1987 to 1990 he was Brazilian Minister of the Interior. From 1975 to 1979 and again from 2013 to 2017, he was mayor of Aracju. 

He died on 24 November 2020, aged 79, in Brasília from COVID-19.

[[Mack Sennett]]

CATEGORIES: 1880 births, 1960 deaths, American silent movie actors, Canadian movie actors, Canadian movie directors, Canadian movie producers, Canadian stage actors, American stage actors, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Movie producers from Los Angeles, California, Movie directors from Los Angeles, California, Actors from Los Angeles, California, Actors from Quebec, Screenwriters from Los Angeles, California, Canadian screenwriters, Writers from Quebec, American composers, Canadian composers, American cinematographers

Mack Sennett (born Michael Sinnott; January 17, 1880 – November 5, 1960) was a Canadian-American actor, director, and producer. He was known as the "King of Comedy". He helped create the first slapstick silent comedy movies.

Sennett died on November 5, 1960, in Woodland Hills, California, aged 80.

According to IMDB he acted in 360 films.

[[Jen Psaki]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 births, Living people, White House Communications Directors, American political commentators, CNN people, Politicians from Connecticut, People from Stamford, Connecticut, People from Greenwich, Connecticut, US Democratic Party politicians, White House Press Secretaries

Jennifer Rene Psaki (s; born December 1, 1978) is an American political advisor. She is the 34th White House Press Secretary and has held the position since January 20th 2021.

She was White House Communications Director from 2015 to 2017 during the Barack Obama presidency. She has also been a CNN contributor.

In November 2020, Joe Biden announced Psaki his pick for White House Press Secretary. She told Biden that she would be press secretary for only a year into her term, so until 2022.

[[Neera Tanden]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births, Living people, American lawyers, Politicians from Massachusetts, Businesspeople from Massachusetts, US Democratic Party politicians

Neera Tanden (born September 10, 1970) is an American political consultant and lawyer. She is president of the Center for American Progress since 2003. During the Barack Obama presidency, Tanden helped create the Affordable Care Act. In May 2021, she became a Senior Advisor to President Joe Biden.

On November 29, 2020, then President-elect Joe Biden announced that he would nominate Tanden as the next director of the Office of Management and Budget. However, after Democrats and Republicans criticized her nomination, she withdrew her nomination as OMB director on March 3, 2021. Two months later, she became senior advisor to Biden.

[[Cecilia Rouse]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, Living people, American economists, American educators, Scientists from California, Politicians from California, US Democratic Party politicians

Cecilia Elena Rouse (born December 18, 1963) is an American economist. She is the 30th and current Chair of the Council of Economic Advisers since 2021 under the Joe Biden administration. In 2012, she became dean of the Princeton School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University.

She was a member of President Barack Obama's Council of Economic Advisers from 2009 to 2011.

In November 2020, President-elect Joe Biden announced his plans to nominate Rouse as the Chair of the Council of Economic Advisers. The Senate confirmed her nomination by a vote of 95–4 on March 2.

[[Kate Bedingfield]]

CATEGORIES: 1982 births, Living people, White House Communications Directors, Politicians from Georgia (U.S. state), US Democratic Party politicians

Katherine Joan Bedingfield (born c. 1982) is an American communications director and political campaign manager. She is the White House Communications Director for the Biden administration since January 20, 2021.

She was deputy campaign manager for the Joe Biden 2020 presidential campaign and former communications director for Biden when he was Vice President.

[[White House Communications Director]]

CATEGORIES: White House Communications Directors

The White House communications director or White House director of communications, also known officially as Assistant to the President for Communications, is part of the senior staff of the President of the United States. 

The communications director is responsible for creating and promoting the agenda of the president and leading its media campaign. 

[[Gerald Rafshoon]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, American television producers, Living people, White House Communications Directors, Businesspeople from New York City, Politicians from New York City, US Democratic Party politicians

Gerald Monroe Rafshoon (born January 11, 1934) is an American television producer and political operative. He is one of the four founding members of Unity08, and was the White House Communications Director under the presidency of Jimmy Carter from 1978 to 1979.

[[David Gergen]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, Living people, American political commentators, American educators, CNN people, White House Communications Directors, Politicians from North Carolina, Writers from North Carolina, Politicians from Massachusetts, Writers from Massachusetts, Businesspeople from Massachusetts, Businesspeople from North Carolina, Independent politicians in the United States, People from Durham, North Carolina

David Richmond Gergen (born May 9, 1942) is an American political commentator. He was a presidential adviser during the administrations of Richard Nixon, Gerald Ford, Ronald Reagan, and Bill Clinton. He is a senior political analyst for CNN. Gergen is a professor of public service and he was the first director of the Center for Public Leadership at the Harvard Kennedy School.

[[Ann Lewis]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, Living people, American political commentators, American political writers, American television writers, Politicians from New Jersey, White House Communications Directors, Politicians from Massachusetts, Writers from Massachusetts, Writers from New Jersey, US Democratic Party politicians, People from Jersey City, New Jersey, Jewish American politicians, Jewish American writers

Ann C. Frank Lewis (born December 19, 1937) is an American Democratic Party strategist and communicator. Lewis was the White House Communications Director in the Clinton administration from 1997 to 1999.

Lewis was co-chair for Jewish Women for the Hillary Clinton 2016 presidential campaign.

[[Bill Shine]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, American television producers, Fox News people, Living people, White House Communications Directors, Businesspeople from New York City, Politicians from New York City, US Republican Party politicians

William Shine (born July 4, 1963) is an American television executive and politician. He was White House Deputy Chief of Staff for Communications in the administration of U.S. President Donald Trump. He spent most of his career as a producer and executive at Fox News.

He was co-president of Fox News, a position he held for 9 months before he was forced out on May 1, 2017.

On March 8, 2019, the White House announced that Shine was resigning to advise President Trump's 2020 presidential campaign.

[[Farmingville, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Hamlets in New York, Census-designated places in New York (state)

Farmingville is a hamlet and census-designated place (CDP) in Suffolk County, New York, United States. The population was 15,481 at the 2010 census.

[[East Farmingdale, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Hamlets in New York, Census-designated places in New York (state)

East Farmingdale is a hamlet and a census-designated place (CDP) in Suffolk County, New York, United States. The population of the CDP was 6,484 at the 2010 census.

[[Elissa Slotkin]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, Living people, United States representatives from Michigan, Politicians from New York City, People from Lansing, Michigan, US Democratic Party politicians

Elissa Blair Slotkin (born July 10, 1976) is an American politician. She is the U.S. Representative for MI since 2019. Slotkin is a member of the Democratic Party.

She was a Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) analyst during the Barack Obama presidency.

[[Emily W. Murphy]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 births, Living people, American lawyers, Politicians from St. Louis, Missouri, Businesspeople from St. Louis, Missouri, US Republican Party politicians

Emily Webster Murphy (born 1973) is an American attorney and government official. She was the administrator of the General Services Administration (GSA) from 2017 to 2021.

She was appointed as administrator in 2017 by President Donald Trump. She was criticized for her actions after the 2020 presidential election for her delay in starting the transition to a Joe Biden administration after Biden won the election on November 7.

Murphy at first did not want to sign a letter allowing Biden's transition team to access federal agencies and transition funds. She signed the letter on November 23, allowing the presidential transition process to begin.

[[Pearson product-moment correlation coefficient]]

CATEGORIES: Mathematics

Pearson's correlation is a mathematical formula used to calculate correlation coefficients between two datasets. Most computer programs have a command to calculate this such as CORREL(dataset A: dataset B). You would calculate this your self by...

Developed by Karl Pearson in the 1880's,

[[Purna Swaraj]]

CATEGORIES: History of India, British India, Government of India

Purna Swaraj, or "total independence," was a document written by the Indian National Congress session at Lahore in December 19, 1929.  It said that India should be separate from the British Empire.  Purna Swaraj was announced on January 26, 1930.  This is one reason why January 26 is India's Republic Day.

The Purna Swaraj was 750 words long.  Scholars such as Mithi Mukherjee say it was an important part of Indian independence because it said becoming independent was about justice.

[[Michael Dubke]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births, Living people, Politicians from New York, Businesspeople from New York, White House Communications Directors, US Republican Party politicians

Michael D. Dubke (born April 18, 1970) is an American entrepreneur and political aide. He was the White House Communications Director for U.S. President Donald Trump until his resignation on June 2, 2017.

[[Hamburg (village), New York]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in New York

Hamburg is a village in Erie County, New York, United States. The population was 9,409 at the 2010 census.

[[Hamburg, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New York

Hamburg is a town in Erie County, New York, United States. As of the 2010 census, the town had a population of 56,936.

[[David Yong]]

CATEGORIES: Singaporean businesspeople

David Yong is an entrepreneur, venture capitalist and lawyer. He has invested in various lifestyles and financial businesses across Singapore, Malaysia, Myanmar, Cambodia, Vietnam, and Korea.

[[Gerald P. Carmen]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, Living people, Businesspeople from Massachusetts, Businesspeople from New Hampshire, Politicians from Massachusetts, Politicians from New Hampshire, US Republican Party politicians, Ambassadors of the United States

Gerald P. Carmen (born July 8, 1930) is an American businessman and politician. He was born in Quincy, Massachusetts. He was a member of the Republican Party. From 1981 to 1984, he was the Administrator of the General Services Administration during the Ronald Reagan presidency.

[[General Services Administration]]

CATEGORIES: United States government agencies

The General Services Administration (GSA) is an  independent agency of the United States government. It was created in 1949 to help manage and support the basic functioning of federal agencies. 

GSA gives products and communications for U.S. government offices, provides transportation and office space to federal employees, and develops government-wide cost-minimizing policies and other management tasks.

[[Whitewater controversy]]

CATEGORIES: 1992 in the United States, Political scandals in the United States, Bill Clinton, Hillary Rodham Clinton, Arkansas

The Whitewater controversy, Whitewater scandal, or simply Whitewater, was an American political controversy during the 1990s. It began with an investigation into the real estate investments of Bill and Hillary Clinton in the Whitewater Development Corporation. 

A March 1992 New York Times article published during the 1992 U.S. presidential campaign reported that the Clintons, then governor and first lady of Arkansas, had invested and lost money in the Whitewater Development Corporation.

Lewis looked for connections between the savings and loan company and the Clintons, and on September 2, 1992, she submitted a criminal referral to the FBI naming Bill and Hillary Clinton as witnesses in the Madison Guaranty case. 

David Hale, the source of criminal allegations against the Clintons, claimed in November 1993 that Bill Clinton had pressured him into providing an illegal $300,000 loan to Susan McDougal, the Clintons' partner in the Whitewater land deal. 

Jim Guy Tucker, Bill Clinton's replacement as governor, was convicted of fraud and sentenced to four years of probation for his role in the controversy. 

Neither Bill Clinton nor Hillary Clinton were ever prosecuted, after three separate inquiries found lack of evidence linking them with the criminal conduct.  

[[Guyanese Americans]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in the United States

Guyanese Americans are an ethnic group of Americans who can trace their ancestry back to Guyana. As of 2011, there are 208,899 Guyanese Americans currently living in the United States. The majority of Guyanese live in New York City – some 140,000 – making them the fifth-largest foreign-born population in the city.

[[Jamaican Americans]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in the United States

Jamaican American or Jamerican are an ethnic group of Caribbean Americans who have full or partial Jamaican ancestry.

[[West Indian Americans]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in the United States

West Indian Americans or Caribbean Americans are Americans who can trace their ancestry to the Caribbean, unless they are of native descent. As of 2016, about 13 million  — about 4% of the total U.S. population — have Caribbean ancestry.

[[Hypogamy]]

CATEGORIES: Sociology

Hypogamy is marrying someone considered to be of lower economic or social class or caste.

[[Moldovan Americans]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in the United States

Moldovan Americans are Americans who are from Moldova or are descended from Moldovans. According to the U.S. 2000 census, there were 7,859 Moldovan Americans in the United States. However, the American Community Survey indicated that the number of Moldovan immigrants greatly increased over the years, and in 2014 exceeded 40,000 people in the United States. Most Moldovan Americans are Eastern Orthodox. 

[[Mediterranean tree frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Africa, Animals of Europe, Frogs

The Mediterranean tree frog or stripeless tree frog (Hyla meridionalis) is a frog from Africa and Europe.  It lives in parts of Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, Portugal, Spain, France and Italy where there is plenty of water in the air.

The female frog lays eggs on groups of plants near the edge of a body of water.  The tadpoles hatch after eight to ten days.  The very largest tadpoles grow to 5.5 cm long.  They become frogs after three or four months.  The frogs eat insects and insect-like animals, for example spiders.

[[Azerbaijani Americans]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in the United States

Azerbaijani Americans (Amerikalı azərbaycanlılar) or Azeri Americans (Amerikalı Azərilər) are Americans of the Azerbaijani ancestry from Azerbaijan and Iranian Azerbaijan region or people possessing Azerbaijani, Iranian, and/or American citizenship. Most Azerbaijani Americans have immigrated to the United States from Azerbaijan, Iran, Germany, Georgia, Russia, Turkey and Ukraine.

[[Lebanese Americans]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in the United States

Lebanese Americans (أمريكيون لبنانيون) are Americans of Lebanese descent. This includes both those who are native to the United States as well as Lebanese immigrants to America.

[[Argentine Americans]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in the United States

Argentine Americans are people in or from the United States who have at least one ancestor from Argentina.

[[Types of crushing machines]]

CATEGORIES: Machines

There are four traditional types of crushers in materials engineering.  They are known as jaw crushers, gyratory crushers and roll crushers. The first two crushers mentioned are the most common when it comes to mineral processing.  Roll crushers are a relatively new type of crusher and they are just starting to become more and more popular in mineral processing.  

The main idea behind how jaw crushers work is that there is a hinge plate that moves back and forth with a fixed plate is held up against the prior hinge plate.  The beginning of the process has the jaws of the crusher open to receive a rock.  The hinge plate, like a big jaw-bone, bites down on the rock and crushes it.

Gyratory crushers have a conical outer wall and a large spindle suspended from a bearing. There is a circular propeller at the bottom of the crusher that oscillates, spins around, really fast and compresses the rocks that enter.

For roll crushers, there are two side by side rolls, one fixed and the other can move a little bit from side to side.  The gap between the rollers is what determines the output size of the rocks. Forcing rocks through these gaps produces a large amount of shear stress on them and causes them to break apart.

[[Bisection method]]

CATEGORIES: Calculus

The bisection method is a way to estimate solutions for single equations. When we solve one equation, this method can help us to get a number that is very close to the real solution. 

Think about a continuous function F(x). If the curve of F(x) passes through the x-axis, it means that there must be one specific x number which makes F(x) = 0, in other words, a solution. But how to judge whether the curve passes the x-axis or not? We pick one section with lower boundary a1 and upper boundary b1. Then we calculate F(a) and F(b). If F(b) has different signal with F(a) (or F(a)*F(b) < 0), the F(x) curve will pass through the x-axis in this section, which means F(x) must have a solution in this section. In this way, we can estimate a range of the solution. 

To make our estimation more precise, we need to shorten the range which contains the solution. We divide this section into two equal parts: ( a , a/2+b/2) and (a/2+b/2, b). Then we apply the same method to judge whether there is a solution in each section. If there is no solutions in one section( F(a)*F(a/2+b/2) > 0 or F(a/2+b/2)*F(b)> 0), we ignore this section. If there is a solution in one section (F(a)*F(a/2+b/2) < 0 or F(a/2+b/2)*F(b) < 0), we continue to shorten the range until the range is smaller than the error of estimation we expected. Finally, we take the middle point of the final range as a solution of F(x).

[[Deaths in 2021]]

CATEGORIES: 2021 deaths, September 2021 events

The following is a list of deaths that should be noted in September 2021. For deaths that should be noted before the month that the world is in, please see "Months". Names under each date are noted in the order of the alphabet by last name or pseudonym. Deaths of non-humans are noted here also if it is worth noting.

Each listing of a death must have a source. If no reference is included, the death notice will be removed. The following are the requirements of adding a name to the list in its order: name, age, where they came from, what the person is known for, cause of death (if known) and a source.

[[Valorant]]

Valorant (stylized as VALORANT) is a free-to-play multiplayer tactical first-person shooter developed and published by Riot Games, for Microsoft Windows. First talked about under the codename Project A in October 2019, the game began a closed beta period with limited access on April 7, 2020, followed by official release on June 2, 2020.

[[Nernst equation]]

CATEGORIES: Equations, Electricity, Physical chemistry, Electromagnetism

Nernst Equation is a scientific equation used to find the reduction potential or voltage of an electrochemical cell. It is widely used in cell physiology and neurobiology. It is named after Walther Nernst. He was a German chemist who created this equation. 

This equation can be used to check which combination of chemicals will be suitable to construct a powerful electric cell.

[[Thermodynamics in nutrition]]

The law of conservation of energy states that energy cannot be created or destroyed. It can only be transformed from one form to another. This law also applies to nutrition. 

[[Angle grinder]]

CATEGORIES: Cutting tools

An angle grinder is a handheld power tool. It is also known as a disc grinder or side grinder. They are commonly used in machine shops and metal workshops. Most angle grinders today are powered by electricity. They can be corded or battery-powered. Angle grinders can be used for cutting, grinding, and polishing objects.

There are different kinds of discs that are used for various materials and tasks. Angle grinders can use grinding stones, sanding discs, wire brush wheels, cut-off discs, abrasive grinding discs, and polishing pads. Angle grinders come in different disc sizes and motor specifications. Other differences include a power source, rpm, and arbor size. Generally disc size and power increase together. Disc size is measured in imperial or metric units. Pneumatic grinders are generally used for lighter duty jobs where more precision is required. Electric grinders are more commonly used for larger, heavy-duty jobs.

Angle grinders generate sparks when cutting ferrous metals. The blades on the angle grinder may also break during operation. Proper personal protective equipment must always be worn when using an angle grinder. Angle grinders should never be used without their guard or handle attached. Inspect the discs for cracks, defects, and wear before using an angle grinder.

[[Demis Hassabis]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, British computer scientists, Fellows of the Royal Society, Living people

Demosthenes "Demis" Hassabis GBR (born 27 July 1976) is a significant figure in artificial intelligence. He is a British researcher, neuroscientist, video game designer, entrepreneur, and five times winner of the Pentamind board games championship. 

Hassabis is the CEO and co-founder of DeepMind, a machine learning AI startup, founded in London in 2010 with Shane Legg and Mustafa Suleyman. Hassabis met Legg when both were postdocs at University College London's Gatsby Computational Neuroscience Unit, and he and Suleyman had been friends through family. Hassabis also recruited his university friend and Elixir partner David Silver.

DeepMind's mission is to "solve intelligence" and then use intelligence "to solve everything else". More concretely, DeepMind aims to use powerful general-purpose learning algorithms to build an artificial general intelligence (AGI).

The company was bought by Google for £400 million. 

They created AlphaGo, a program which defeated world champion Lee Sedol at the complex game of Go. Go had been considered a holy grail of AI, for its high number of possible board positions and resistance to existing programming techniques. However, AlphaGo beat European champion Fan Hui 5-0 in October 2015 before winning 4-1 against former world champion Lee Sedol in March 2016. 

More recently, DeepMind turned its artificial intelligence to protein-folding, one of the toughest problems in science. In December 2018, DeepMind's tool AlphaFold won the 13th Critical Assessment of Techniques for Protein Structure Prediction (CASP) by successfully predicting the most accurate structure for 25 out of 43 proteins.

Although Hassabis is expert at many games, he does not program specific rules into Deep Mind. For Go and chess, the machine played many games with itself, learning from its results. In other words it taught itself how to play, given the basic rules of the game. 

[[George Carter (basketball)]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Detroit Pistons players, Sportspeople from Buffalo, New York, Sportspeople from New York City

George Carter (January 10, 1944 – November 18, 2020) was an American professional basketball player. He was a 6'4" swingman. He was born in Buffalo, New York. His career lasted from 1967 to 1977. He played for the Detroit Pistons and for the New York Nets.

Carter died on November 18, 2020 in Las Vegas, Nevada at the age of 76.

[[Eduardo Lourenço]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, Portuguese writers, Philosophers, Critics, Portuguese educators, Essayists

Eduardo Lourenço GCSE, GCIH (23 May 1923 – 1 December 2020) was a Portuguese essayist, professor, critic, philosopher, and writer. He was a professor at the University of Coimbra. He won the Camões Prize in 1996. Lourenço was born in Almeida, Portugal.

Lourenço died on 1 December 2020 in Lisbon at the age of 97.

[[November 2020 lunar eclipse]]

CATEGORIES: November 2020 events, Eclipses, 2020 in Asia, 2020 in Europe

A penumbral lunar eclipse took place on 30 November 2020. It was visible mainly in North America with visibility reaching to some other places such as parts of South America and Asia.

[[DeepMind]]

CATEGORIES: 2010 establishments in the United Kingdom, Companies of the United Kingdom, Artificial intelligence

DeepMind Technologies is a UK based artificial intelligence company and research laboratory founded in September 2010. It was bought by Google in 2014. 

The company is based in London, with research centres in Canada, France, and the United States. 

[[Miguel Algarín]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Puerto Rican people, American historians, American poets, American educators, American playwrights, American editors, American critics, Writers from New York City, Deaths from sepsis

Miguel Algarín Jr. (11 September 1941 – 1 December 2020) was a Puerto Rican poet, historian and writer. He was known as the co-founder of the Nuyorican Poets Café. He was a Rutgers University professor of English. Algarín was born in Santurce, Puerto Rico.  He lived most of his life in New York City.  He was a Nuyorican poet.

Algarín's books include Mongo Affair, On Call (1980), Body Bee Calling from the 21st Century (1982), Time's Now/Ya es tiempo (1985), Love Is Hard Work: Memorias de Loisaida/Poems (1997, Lower East Side Memories/Poems).

Algarín died on 1 December 2020 in New York City of sepsis, aged 79. 

[[Jim McFarland]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, American football tight ends, Buffalo Bills players, Miami Dolphins players, Arizona Cardinals players, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Omaha, Nebraska, People from North Platte, Nebraska, US Democratic Party politicians, Deaths from pancreatic cancer

James Darrell McFarland (October 4, 1947 – November 27, 2020) was an American football player. He played tight end for six seasons in the National Football League (NFL) with the Buffalo Bills, St. Louis Cardinals, and Miami Dolphins. He was born in North Platte, Nebraska.

After leaving football, he became a member of the Nebraska Legislature between 1986 to 1991 as a Democrat. He unsuccessfully ran for Governor of Nebraska in 1998.

McFarland died of pancreatic cancer on November 27, 2020, in Omaha, Nebraska at age 73.

[[Dieter Popp]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, German businesspeople, Spies, People from Bonn, German politicians

Dieter Popp (24 November 1938 – 27 November 2020) was a West German insurance agent. He worked as a spy between 1969 and 1990. He was born in Bonn. He was a spy for the Military Intelligence Service of the East German National People's Army.

Popp died on 27 November 2020, three days after his 82nd birthday.

[[Clifton Bertrand]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Trinidad and Tobago sportspeople, Olympians, Sprinters

Clifton Bertrand (2 March 1936 – 28 November 2020) was a Trinidadian sprinter. He was born in Arima, Trinidad and Tobago. He won three bronze medals at the Pan American Games in 1959 and 1963. Bertrand also competed during the 1960 and 1964 Summer Olympics.

Bertrand died on 28 November 2020 in New York City at the age of 84.

[[Shams Badran]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Egyptian politicians, Egyptian military people

Shams Al Din Badran (شمس الدين بدران; 19 April 1929 – 28 November 2020) was an Egyptian politician. He was Minister of Defence of Egypt during Gamal Abdel Nasser's era from 1966 to 1967. He also was Commander of the Egyptian Armed Forces at the same time. He was removed from the ministry during the Six-Day War and later imprisoned. 

Badran died at a Plymouth, Devon hospital on 28 November 2020 while living in exile since his prison release in 1974, aged 91.

[[KaTeX]]

CATEGORIES: Free software, JavaScript

KaTeX is a JavaScript library that shows mathematical notation on any web browser. It aims to be fast and easy to use.

It was initially developed by Khan Academy. This is why it starts from K. KaTeX is known to be one of the top five popular projects on GitHub in September 2014.

[[Miša Aleksić]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2020 deaths, Serbian singers, Serbian musicians, Songwriters, Guitarists, Rock singers, Rock musicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Serbia

Miroslav "Miša" Aleksić (Serbian Cyrillic: Мирослав-Миша Алексић, 16 August 1953 — 29 November 2020) was a Serbian musician. He was best known as the bass guitarist for the Serbian and former Yugoslav rock band Riblja Čorba.

On 29 November 2020, Aleksić died from problems caused by COVID-19 in Belgrade at the age of 67.

[[José Rafael Barquero Arce]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Roman Catholic bishops, Costa Rican people

José Rafael Barquero Arce (27 October 1931 – 29 November 2020) was a Costa Rican Roman Catholic bishop. He became a priest in 1956. He was titular bishop of 'Arindela' and was auxiliary bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Alajuela, Costa Rica, from 1979 to 1980. He then was bishop of the diocese from 1980 until 2007.

Barquero Arce died on 29 November 2020 at the age of 89.

[[Marco Dino Brogi]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Italian Roman Catholics, Roman Catholic bishops, People from Cairo

Marco Dino Brogi, O.F.M. (12 March 1932 – 29 November 2020) was an Italian prelate of the Roman Catholic Church

Brogi was born in Cairo, Egypt. He was became a priest on 5 May 1963. Pope John Paul II made Brogi titular archbishop of Città Ducale, Apostolic Nuncio to Sudan, and Apostolic Delegate to Somalia on 13 December 1997. Pope John Paul named him Apostolic Nuncio to Egypt and Apostolic Delegate to the Arab League on 5 February 2002.

Brogi ended his service as Nuncio on 27 January 2006. Benedict named him a Consultor to the Congregation for the Oriental Churches on 15 September 2007.

Brogi died on 29 November 2020 in Rome at the age of 88.

[[Delian League]]

CATEGORIES: Ancient Greece, 5th-century establishments, 5th-century disestablishments

The Delian League was founded in 478 BC. It was an association of Greek city-states under the leadership of Athens. The League had a many cities: at various times between 150 and 330. 

The League was led by Athens to continue fighting the Persian Empire. The Greeks had won the Battle of Plataea at the end of the Second Persian invasion of Greece. 

The League's modern name comes from its official meeting place, the island of Delos, where congresses were held in the temple. The treasury stood there, until Pericles moved it to Athens in 454 BC.

Soon after the League was set up, Athens began to use the League's funds for its own purposes. This led to conflict between Athens and the less powerful members of the League. By 431 BC,  the League presented a threat to Sparta. This, and Athens's heavy-handed control of the League, started the Peloponnesian War. The League was dissolved after the war's end in 404 BC by the order of Lysander, the Spartan commander.

[[Irina Antonova]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Russia, Russian historians

Irina Aleksandrovna Antonova (Ирина Александровна Антонова) (20 March 1922 – 30 November 2020) was a Russian art historian. He was a Director of the Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts in Moscow for 52 years, from 1961 to 2013. She was the oldest and the longest serving director of a major art museum in the world. 

Antonova was honored with the State Prize of the Russian Federation and the Ordre des Arts et des Lettres. She was the President of the Pushkin Museum.

Antonova died of COVID-19 at a Moscow hospital on 30 November 2020 at the age of 98.

[[Dee Benson]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, American judges, Politicians from Salt Lake City, Utah, US Republican Party politicians, Deaths from brain cancer

Dee Vance Benson (August 25, 1948 – November 30, 2020) was an American politician and lawyer. He was born in Sandy, Utah. He was nominated to the United States District Court for the District of Utah in 1991 by President George H. W. Bush. From 1999 to 2006, he was chief justice of the court. 

Benson died of brain cancer on November 30, 2020 at his home in Salt Lake City, Utah at the age of 72.

[[Sandy, Utah]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Utah

Sandy is a city in the Salt Lake City metropolitan area, located in Salt Lake County, Utah, United States. The population of Sandy was 87,461 at the 2010 census. 

[[Tan Eng Bock]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Singaporean people, Olympians, Water polo players

Tan Eng Bock (29 April 1936 – 30 November 2020) was a Singaporean water polo player He competed in the men's tournament at the 1956 Summer Olympics.

Tan died in Singapore on 30 November 2020 at the age of 84.

[[Ben Bova]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, Deaths from stroke, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, American novelists, American science fiction writers, American editors, American critics, American essayists, American journalists, Writers from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Infectious disease deaths in Florida

Benjamin William Bova (November 8, 1932spaced en dashNovember 29, 2020) was an American writer. He was the author of more than 120 works of science fiction. He was a six-time winner of the Hugo Award. 

He was an editor of Analog Magazine, an editorial director of Omni; he was also president of both the National Space Society and the Science Fiction Writers of America. He was known for his Grand Tour novel series.

Bova died on November 29, 2020 at a hospital in Naples, Florida from pneumonia and a stroke caused by COVID-19, aged 88.

[[Abhay Bharadwaj]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in India, Ugandan politicians, Indian politicians, Indian activists, Indian lawyers, People from Chennai

Abhay Ganpathrai Bharadwaj (2 April 1954 – 1 December 2020) was an Ugandan-born Indian politician, activist and lawyer. He was born in Kampala, Uganda.

Bharadwaj was a member of the Rajya Sabha from 22 July 2020 until his death. He was a member of the Bharatiya Janata Party. He also was a member of the national Law Commission from 2016 to 2018.

Bharadwaj died of COVID-19 on 1 December 2020 at a hospital in Chennai, India at the age of 66.

[[Tableau vivant]]

CATEGORIES: Performing arts

A tableau vivant is when people pose and make the scene look like the one in a picture. People in a tableau vivant don't move or speak. The name comes from French, and translates as "living picture". The plural is tableaux vivants. 

In Europe, tableaux vivants became popular towards the end of the 19th century. Sometimes, there was even music. Jean Sibelius composed his work Finlandia (1900) for a sequence of tableaux vivants.

At the beginning of the 20th century, they became notorious, because usually naked women would present them in revue theatres. The dancer Olga Desmond became well-known because of her posing naked in revues at the beginning of the 20th century.

[[Gillette Stadium]]

CATEGORIES: 2000s establishments in Massachusetts, 2002 establishments in the United States, National Football League venues, Football stadiums in the United States, Buildings and structures in Massachusetts, New England Patriots

The Gillette Stadium is a stadium in Foxborough, Massachusetts. It is the home stadium of NFL team New England Patriots and MLS team New England Revolution.

[[LockWiper]]

CATEGORIES: Software

LockWiper is an iOS application developed by iMyFone. It enables users to remove various locks from iPhone, iPad, iPod touch devices. LockWiper can remove the Apple ID without a password, remove the iPhone passcode, and it can also bypass the MDM activation screen & remove MDM Profile from iPhones.

According to its website, the iMyFone LockWiper app can remove iPhone passcode from locked, disabled, broken screen and quickly bypass Screen Time or Restrictions passcode without data loss.

[[Thomas and the Magic Railroad]]

CATEGORIES: 2000 animated movies, 2000s adventure movies, 2000s fantasy movies, American adventure movies, American animated movies, American fantasy movies, British adventure movies, British animated movies, British fantasy movies, Crossover movies, English-language movies

Thomas and the Magic Railroad is a 2000 British-American live-action/animated fantasy adventure movie based on Thomas the Tank Engine and Shining Time Station. The Fat Controller is on holiday while Thomas the Tank Engine and his friends were working hard .

Turtles Forever is a 2009 television movie based on the TMNT franchise. It is a crossover between the 1984 comics, 1987 cartoon and 2003 cartoon.

"The Nightmare Begins" is the first episode of Invader Zim as was aired on March 31, 2001.

Scary Movie 2 is an American comedy movie. It is a parody of a horror movie. It is directed by Keenan Ivory Wayans. It stars Anna Faris Regina Hall, Marlon Wayans and Shawn Wayans. It was released to mixed reviews on July 7, 2001.

[[Marcus Terentius Varro]]

CATEGORIES: 2nd century BC births, 1st century BC deaths, Ancient Roman writers

Marcus Terentius Varro Reatinus (116–27 BC) was a Roman writer. He wrote many books, but only one work survives completely Three books on Agriculture.  In this work, he describes farming in Roman times. 

Scholars say this book has a little microbiology and epidemiology. Varro warned his contemporaries to stay away from swamps and marshes: 

[[Cassie Cage]]

[[Vipassana]]

CATEGORIES: Buddhist terminology

Vipassanā (Pāli) or vipaśyanā (Sanskrit) is a Buddhist word that is usually translated as "insight". It is a form of meditation which aims to have "insight into the true nature of reality."

[[Ananke (mythology)]]

CATEGORIES: Greek mythology

Ananke means fate in Greek mythology. 

[[1992 United Kingdom general election]]

CATEGORIES: 1992 elections, United Kingdom general elections

A general election was held on 9 April 1992 to elect all 651 members to the House of Commons of the United Kingdom. The Conservative Party won the election, winning 336 seats, and John Major stayed as Prime Minister. Many people thought that the Labour Party would win the election because opinion polls had shown them to be ahead.

[[1987 United Kingdom general election]]

CATEGORIES: 1987 in Europe, 1980s in the United Kingdom, United Kingdom general elections

A general election was held on 11 June 1987 to elect all 650 members to the House of Commons of the United Kingdom. The Conservative Party won the election, winning 376 seats, and Margaret Thatcher stayed as Prime Minister for the third election in a row. The Labour Party won 20 more seats than the last election, mostly from the Conservatives.

[[1983 United Kingdom general election]]

CATEGORIES: 1983, 1980s in the United Kingdom, United Kingdom general elections

A general election was held on 9 June 1983 to elect all 650 members to the House of Commons of the United Kingdom. The Conservative Party won by the largest majority since Labour in the 1945 general election. It meant that Margaret Thatcher stayed as Prime Minister.

[[1400]]

CATEGORIES: years

Year 1400 (MCD) was a leap year starting on Thursday of the Julian calendar. The year 1400 wasn't a leap year in the Proleptic Gregorian calendar.

[[Omnisexuality]]

CATEGORIES: Sexuality

Omnisexuality is a sexual orientation where one is attracted to all genders or any gender, though gender often still plays a role or a preference in one's attraction. Similar to pansexuality. Omnisexual could be seen as a form of multisexuality, or non-monosexuality.

[[Moller's tree frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Europe, Frogs

The Iberian tree frog or Moller's tree frog (Hyla molleri) is a frog from Europe.  Scientists saw it in Spain, Portugal and France.

[[Multiracial American]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in the United States

Multiracial Americans are Americans who have mixed ancestry.

[[My Grandfather's Clock]]

CATEGORIES: Music, Children's songs

"My Grandfather's Clock" is a song. Henry Clay Work wrote it in 1876. Henry Clay Work also wrote "Marching Through Georgia". British brass bands and colliery bands play "My Grandfather's Clock". Bluegrass musicians also play it.

The Oxford English Dictionary says the word "grandfather clock" comes from this song. Before that, grandfather clocks were called "longcase clocks". In 1905,  Harry Macdonough and the Haydn Quartet (known then as the "Edison Quartet") made the first recording of this song that people know about.

[[Maltese Americans]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in the United States

Maltese Americans are Americans of Maltese descent.

[[Lithuanian Americans]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in the United States

Lithuanian Americans refers to American citizens and residents who are Lithuanian and were born in Lithuania, or are of Lithuanian descent. New Philadelphia, Pennsylvania has the largest percentage of Lithuanian Americans (20.8%) in the United States. Lithuanian Americans form by far the largest group within the Lithuanian diaspora.

[[Antica Dolceria Bonajuto]]

CATEGORIES: Sicily

Antica Dolceria Bonajuto is a chocolate factory founded in Modica in 1880, known as the oldest in Sicily and one of the oldest in Italy.

[[Super Bowl XXXVIII halftime show controversy]]

CATEGORIES: Super Bowl, Controversies in the United States, 2004 in television, Janet Jackson, Justin Timberlake

The 38th Super Bowl was shown on television as it was happening on February 1, 2004 on CBS. The halftime show of the Super Bowl got controversy when Janet Jackson's breast was revealed by Justin Timberlake to everyone watching the show. This caused a big debate on broadcasting things that people might see as offensive.

MTV was the producer of the halftime show. 143.6 million people watched the halftime show when it first happened. The incident with Jackson and Timberlake made CBS and MTV remove Jackson's songs from its radio and television channels. The Federal Communications Commission gave CBS a fine of US$27,500 for the incident. The fine was made bigger for US$325,000 and then even bigger, for US$550,000. The Third Circuit Court of Appeals removed the fine in 2011. The FCC tried to put another fine on CBS in 2012, but it was rejected.

The incident made Janet Jackson the most searched words ever on the Internet. It also became the most watched event on TiVo and made 35,000 people become new subscribers to TiVo. The term "wardrobe malfunction" (meaning an error related to clothing) was made because of the incident. It was later added to Webster's Dictionary.

[[Abdur Rahman Khan]]

CATEGORIES: History of Afghanistan

Abdur Rahman Khan was Emir of Afghanistan from 1880 to 1901. He is known for uniting the country after years of internal fighting and negotiation of the Durand Line Agreement with British India. Abdur Rahman Khan was the first child and only son of Mohammad Afzal Khan, and grandson of Dost Mohammad Khan.

[[Blue Whale Challenge]]

CATEGORIES: Suicide

The Blue Whale Challenge, also called Blue Whale game, or simply Blue whale is an internet phenomenon that started in 2016, in Russia. Over a period of 50 days, participants are assigned tasks. Each participant gets one task a day. At first, the tasks are harmless (such as: get up at 4.30am, and watch a horror movie). Later, the tasks require the participants to hurt themselves. The final task requires the player to commit suicide.

When people want to quit, they are threatened. Sometimes, this includes threats to the family of the participant.

The first to report on this was the Russian newspaper Novaya Gazeta, in 2016. It  linked many suicides of children. All these children had been members of the group "F57", in the Russian social network called VK. The article claimed there were 130 suicides because of the challenge. The article was later criticized, because it made connections where none existed. None of the suicides were found to be related to the activities of the group. There were several suicides which have been linked to the challenge. So far, no link has been proven.

[[The Way It Is (Keyshia Cole album)]]

CATEGORIES: 2005 albums

The Way It Is is the debut studio album by American R&B singer Keyshia Cole; it was released on June 21, 2005, by A&M Records. The album debuted at number 6 on the US Billboard 200 and it was supported by five singles, including "Never", "I Changed My Mind", "(I Just Want It) To Be Over", "I Should Have Cheated" and "Love". The album sold 89,000 units in its first week.

The album was certified gold within 17 weeks, and then platinum, only eight weeks later. The album stayed on the charts for over a year, eventually selling over 1.6 million copies and it is Cole's second highest-selling album to date.

[[Arecibo Telescope]]

CATEGORIES: Telescopes, Puerto Rico

The Arecibo Telescope is now destroyed by a collapse.

The radio telescope was a 305 spherical reflector dish built into a natural sinkhole at the Arecibo Observatory which was completed in November 1963. 

For more than 50 years, the Arecibo Telescope was the world's largest single-aperture telescope. In July 2016 the Five-hundred-meter Aperture Spherical Telescope (FAST) in China was put into service.

On 19 November 2020, the National Science Foundation announced that they would close and dismantle the telescope. On 1 December 2020, the telescope collapsed.

[[Pfizer–BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine]]

CATEGORIES: COVID-19 pandemic

Pfizer–BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine is a COVID-19 vaccine, developed by BioNTech, Pfizer and Fosun Pharmaceutical.

The vaccine is given by injection. It is an RNA vaccine made of nucleoside-modified mRNA which is meant to create spike protein of SARS-CoV-2. 

[[Mony Elkaïm]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Moroccan scientists, Belgian scientists, People from Marrakesh

Mony Elkaïm (7 November 1941 – 20 November 2020) was a Moroccan-Belgian psychiatrist and psychotherapist. He was a part of the anti-psychiatry movement in the 1970s. He was born in Marrakesh, French Morocco.

Elkaïm died on 20 November 2020 in Brussels at the age of 79.

[[Bonifácio Piccinini]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Brazilian people, Roman Catholic archbishops

Bonifácio Piccinini (13 May 1929 – 28 November 2020) was a Brazilian Roman Catholic archbishop. He became a priest in 1960. He was titular archbishop of Turres in Byzacena and as coadjutor archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Cuiabá Brazil, from 1975 to 1981 and as archbishop of the archdiocese from 1981 to 2004.

Piccinini died on 28 November 2020 at the age of 91.

[[Peg Murray]]

CATEGORIES: Tony Award winning actors, 1924 births, 2020 deaths, American television actors, American stage actors, Actors from Denver, Colorado, Actors from New York City

Margaret L. "Peg" Murray (February 14, 1924 – November 29, 2020) was an American actress. She was born in Denver, Colorado. She won a Tony Award for Best Performance by a Featured Actress in a Musical for her performance as the villain "Fräulein Kost" in the original Broadway production of Cabaret (1966). 

Murray died on November 29, 2020 in Southold, New York at the age of 96.

The Town of Southold is one of ten towns in Suffolk County, New York, United States. The population was 21,968 at the 2010 census.

Southold is a census-designated place (CDP) that is in the Town of Southold in Suffolk County, New York, United States. The CDP population was 5,748 at the 2010 census.

[[Ali-Asghar Shahbazi]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cardiopulmonary arrest, Iranian actors, People from Tehran

Ali-Asghar Shahbazi (علی‌اصغر شهبازی; November 1922 – 29 November 2020) was an Iranian actor. He was born in Tehran. He was known for his role as Nader's father in the 2011 drama A Separation.

Shahbazi died on 29 November 2020 in Tehran from cardiopulmonary arrest at the age of 98.

[[Liliane Juchli]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Switzerland, Swiss writers, Nurses

Liliane Juchli (19 October 1933 – 30 November 2020) was a Swiss nurse and writer. She was a member of the Merciful Sisters of the Holy Cross. She was the main author of an important German-language nursing textbook which was called "the Juchli". She was born in Obersiggenthal, Switzerland.

Juchli died in Bern, Switzerland from COVID-19 on 30 November 2020 at the age of 87.

[[Roger Chappot]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Olympians, Swiss ice hockey players, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Switzerland

Roger Chappot (17 October 1940 – 7 April 2020) was a Swiss professional ice hockey player. He played for HC Villars and Genève-Servette HC in the National League A.  He also represented the Swiss national team at the 1964 Winter Olympics.

Chappot died from COVID-19 during the pandemic on 8 April 2020 at the age of 79.

[[Aleksandr Shatskikh]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 births, 2020 deaths, Kazakhstani sportspeople

Aleksandr Shatskikh (21 January 1974 – 30 November 2020) was a Kazakh footballer. He played as a striker. He was born in Taldıqorğan, Kazakhstan. His career lasted from 1990 to 2009.

Shatskikh played club football for Zhetysu / Taldykorgan, Qaynar, Chkalovets, Astana Aqmola / Zhenis Astana, Irtysh Pavlodar, CSKA-Qayrat Almaty, Esil Bogatyr, Megasport and Lokomotiv Astana.

He appeared once for the Kazakhstan national team in 2003.

Shatskikh died on 30 November 2020, aged 46.

[[Anne Sylvestre]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from stroke, French singers, French songwriters, French musicians, Guitarists, People from Lyon

Anne Sylvestre (an silvɛstʁ, born Anne-Marie Beugras 20 June 1934 – 30 November 2020) was a French singer-songwriter and guitarist. She was born in Lyon, France. She was known for her children's songs such as "Fabulettes" (1962). She also appeared many times as a musical guest on the television program Discorama.

Sylvestre died in Paris on 30 November 2020 from problems caused by a stroke, aged 86.

[[Dennis W. Sciama]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 1999 deaths, British physicists, People from Manchester, People from Oxford

Guthrie Medal and Prize (1991)

Dennis William Siahou Sciama, GBR (ʃ; 18 November 1926 – 18/19 December 1999) was a British physicist. He was an important scientist for the development of British physics after the Second World War. 

He was the PhD supervisor to many famous cosmologists, including Stephen Hawking, Martin Rees and David Deutsch. He is seen as one of the fathers of modern cosmology.

[[Jane Hawking]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, Living people, Educators, Writers from Hertfordshire, Autobiographers

Jane Beryl Wilde Hawking Jones (born 29 March 1944) is an English author and teacher. She was married for 30 years to Stephen Hawking. She was born in St Albans, Hertfordshire, England. In 1999 she wrote an autobiography about her first marriage, Music to Move the Stars: A Life with Stephen.

Hawking was played by Felicity Jones in the 2014 movie The Theory of Everything.

[[Isaak Markovich Khalatnikov]]

CATEGORIES: 1919 births, 2021 deaths, Soviet writers, Ukrainian scientists, Russian physicists, Ukrainian writers, Russian writers, Centenarians

Isaak Markovich Khalatnikov (Исаак Маркович Халатников; Ісаак Маркович Халатников; 17 October 1919 – 9 January 2021) was a Soviet-born physicist. He was known for his role in developing the BKL conjecture in general relativity. Khalatnikov was born in Dnipro, Ukraine.

Khalatnikov directed the Landau Institute for Theoretical Physics in Moscow from 1965 to 1992. He was elected to the Soviet Academy of Sciences in 1984. In 1994, he became a fellow at the Royal Society.

Khalatnikov died in Chernogolovka, Russia on 9 January 2021, aged 101.

[[Supreme Court of the United Kingdom]]

CATEGORIES: 2009 establishments in the United Kingdom, Politics of the United Kingdom, National supreme courts

The Supreme Court (initialism: UKSC or the acronym: SCOTUK) is the final court of appeal in the United Kingdom for civil cases, and for criminal cases from England, Wales and Northern Ireland. 

It hears cases of the greatest public or constitutional importance.

[[Luciano Guerzoni (born 1938)]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, People from Naples, Italian politicians

Luciano Guerzoni (1 April 1938 – 1 December 2020) was an Italian Communist politician. He was a member of the Chamber of Deputies three times representing Parma for his first two terms from 1983 to 1992, and Mirandola in his final term from 1994 to 1996. Guerzoni was born in Naples, Italy.

Guerzoni died on 1 December 2020 in Modena, Italy at the age of 82.

[[Brian Kerr, Baron Kerr of Tonaghmore]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, British lawyers, Northern Ireland politicians, British judges

Brian Francis Kerr, Baron Kerr of Tonaghmore, GBR (k; 22 February 1948 – 1 December 2020) was a British politician and lawyer. 

He was Lord Chief Justice of Northern Ireland and then as a Justice of the Supreme Court of the United Kingdom from 2009 until his retirement in 2020. Until his retirement, Kerr was the longest serving Supreme Court Justice, and the last original member of the Court.

Kerr died on 1 December 2020 at the age of 72.

[[Mohammad Maleki]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cancer, Deaths from diabetes, Iranian people, Academics, Political activists

Mohammad Maleki (محمد ملکی; 11 July 1933 – 1 December 2020) was an Iranian academic and pro-democracy nationalist-religious activist. He was president of the University of Tehran for a short time in 1979.

Maleki died of cancer and diabetes in Tehran on 1 December 2020 at the age of 87.

[[Erlend Rian]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Norwegian journalists, Norwegian politicians, Mayors, Editors

Erlend Rian (15 June 1941 – 1 December 2020) was a Norwegian politician. He was a member of the Conservative Party. He was editor-in-chief of the newspaper Tromsø from 1974 to 1979. He was mayor of Tromsø City from 1980 to 1995.

Rian died on 1 December 2020 in Tromsø at the age of 79.

[[Henri Teissier]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, People from Lyon, People from Algiers, French Roman Catholics, Roman Catholic bishops, Roman Catholic archbishops, Deaths from stroke

Teissier died on 1 December 2020 at a hospital in Lyon from problems caused by multiple strokes at the age of 91.

[[Moreirense F.C.]]

CATEGORIES: 20th century establishments in Portugal, 1938 establishments in Europe, Portuguese football clubs

Moreirense Futebol Clube is a Portuguese professional football club based in Moreira de Cónegos, Guimarães Municipality, in Minho. It was founded on 1 November 1938 and it plays in the Primeira Liga.

[[Mohamed Abarhoun]]

CATEGORIES: 1989 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from stomach cancer, Moroccan footballers

Mohamed Abarhoun (3 May 1989spnd 2 December 2020) was a Moroccan professional footballer. He played as a defender.

Abarhoun joined Portguese Primeira Liga club Moreirense in 2017.  After two seasons he joined Turkish club Çaykur Rizespor.

Abarhoun played nine games for the Morocco U20 team and eight for the Morocco U23 team, including three at the 2012 Summer Olympics. He made his senior international debut in 2013, earning 7 international caps.

In February 2020, Abarhoun was diagnosed with stomach cancer. He died from the disease on 2 December 2020 in Istanbul, aged 31.

[[Hasna Begum]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Bangladesh, Bangladeshi writers, Philosophers, Editors, Feminist writers, People from Dhaka

Hasna Begum (February 24, 1935 – December 1, 2020) was a Bangladeshi philosopher and feminist. She was a professor of philosophy at the University of Dhaka until her retirement in December 2000. Begum was born in Dhaka, Bangladesh.

Begum was chair of the Department of Philosophy at the University of Dhaka from 1991 to 1994 and was appointed to the University Grants Commission (UGC) of Bangladesh's Rokeya Chair in 2010. 

She was a board member of the International Association of Bioethics (IAB) from 1997 to 2005. She was a member of the editorial board of Bioethics.

Begum died at a Dhaka hospital on December 1, 2020 from COVID-19 at the age of 85. 

[[Boris Plotnikov]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Russia, Soviet movie actors, Soviet television actors, Russian movie actors, Russian television actors, Russian stage actors

Boris Grigoryevich Plotnikov (Борис Григорьевич Плотников; 2 April 1949 – 2 December 2020) was a Soviet and Russian actor. His career began in 1970 and he retired in 2019. Plotnikov appeared in more than seventy movies and television series. He was born in Nevyansk, Soviet Union.

His best known roles were as Sotnikov in the 1977 drama movie The Ascent, as Nikolai in the 1988 crime movie The Cold Summer of 1953 and as Ivan in the 1988 science fiction television movie Heart of a Dog.

Plotnikov died on 2 December 2020 in Moscow from COVID-19 at the age of 71.

[[Defection]]

CATEGORIES: Politics by issue, Words

Defection is when a person leaves their home country in a way the home country claims to be illegal. To the first country, they can be seen as traitors.

It is a political label used by authoritarian countries. 

More broadly, it involves abandoning a person, cause, or doctrine to which one is bound by some tie. The tie may be one of allegiance or of duty.

An example of this today are North Koreans who escape the country to live in a new country, such as South Korea or the United States. The North Korean government makes leaving the country without permission illegal, and punishments for this are extremely harsh. Escapees who are caught usually get sent to a prison camp or are publicly put to death. There have been around 33,000 defectors from North Korea since the North Korean famine.

[[Paraguayan American]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in the United States

Paraguayan Americans are Americans of Paraguayan descent.

[[Dolichostyrax longipes]]

CATEGORIES: Polyphaga

Dolichostyrax longipes is a species of beetle in the family Cerambycidae. It was described by Per Olof Christopher Aurivillius in 1913 and is known from Borneo.

[[Bullseye (mascot)]]

CATEGORIES: Target Corporation, Mascots, Dogs

right|thumb|Bullseye at the start of the Iditarod in 2009.Bullseye is the mascot of Target Corporation. It is a Bull Terrier that is used for Target's advertising and marketing starting in 1999. The dog has the Target logo on its left eye. The makeup used for the logo is natural and non-toxic. 

There have been many Bull Terriers that have had the role of Bullseye. Only one dog works as Bullseye at a time until another one can get the role. Bullseye lives on a ranch next to Los Angeles. Its owner is dog trainer David McMillan. In 2004, Target asked the artist Amy Brazil to make a painting of Bullseye. Brazil made an 8 ft by 8 ft portrait of Bullseye. The portrait is now in Target's headquarters in Minnesota.

[[Spark plug]]

Also known as a "sparking plug", it's a device used in delivering the electric current to the air-fuel mixture in the combustion chamber in an internal combustion engine. It’s connected to the ignition coil and as the electricity flows through the coil, a voltage difference develops between the electrodes on the spark plug. This causes electricity to jump the gap, making a spark which ignites fuel.

[[Sabrina Ferilli]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, Living people, Actors from Rome, Italian movie actors, Italian television actors, Italian stage actors, Italian voice actors

Sabrina Ferilli (born 28 June 1964) is an Italian actress. She is known for her role as Ramona in the 2013 movie The Great Beauty.

[[Hyla orientalis]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Asia, Animals of Europe, Frogs

Hyla orientalis (also known as the oriental tree frog, eastern tree frog, Caucasian tree frog or Shelkovnikov's tree frog) is a frog from both Europe and Asia.  Scientists saw it in Turkey, Romania, Poland, Ukraine, Georgia, Russia, Iran, Azerbaijan and Armenia.  It may also live in Greece

Scientists used to think this frog was part of Hyla arborea but they do not think so now.

[[Dewberry]]

A dewberry is a type of berry. It is similar to a blackberry. Dewberries are very dark blue.

[[Flash (camera)]]

CATEGORIES: Photography

A camera flash, sometimes called a strobe or just a flash, is a device used in photography to allow pictures to be taken of dark areas by producing a flash of very bright light.

Flashes are often built into cameras, but external flashes are available and are mostly used by professional photographers, they can be mounted directly to the camera, or used 'off-camera' on a special stand or tripod.

Flashes were first used in the late 1800's in the form of a stick with magnesium on the top that when burned would produce very bright light (the stick was held in the air, and the camera shutter released at the same time), later camera flashes used a special type of light bulb known as a flashbulb, and modern flashes use LED's or a special type of tube which emits a flash of mostly blue light when electricity is applied to it from the flash capacitor (known as a xenon flashtube).

The use of a flash to take photographs is mostly known as 'flash photography' 

The use of flashes is not allowed in some places where it may be annoying to other people or where the bright light could damage rare or very old objects (like paintings) such as in a museum.

[[Ambiamory]]

Ambiamory is the capability of experiencing monogamous and polyamorous relationships.

[[Romance (1930 movie)]]

[[George Ross Anderson Jr.]]

George Ross Anderson Jr. (January 29, 1929 – December 1, 2020) was an American lawyer and politician. He was a Judge of the United States District Court for the District of South Carolina from 1980 until his retirement in 2016. He was nominated by President Jimmy Carter to the court. He also was a member of the South Carolina House of Representatives from 1955 to 1956. 

Anderson was born in Anderson, South Carolina. He was a Democrat. Anderson died on December 1, 2020 at a South Carolina nursing home at the age of 91.

[[Walter E. Williams]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, American academics, American economists, American political commentators, Writers from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Libertarians

Walter Edward Williams (March 31, 1936 – December 1, 2020) was an American economist, commentator, and academic. He was the John M. Olin Distinguished Professor of Economics at George Mason University. He was known for his classical liberal and libertarian views. His writings frequently appeared on Townhall.com, WND, and Jewish World Review. He was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

Williams died on December 1, 2020 in Devon, Pennsylvania at the age of 84.

[[Dead End]]

[[Ankylosing spondylitis]]

CATEGORIES: Autoimmune diseases, Inflammation

Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a type of arthritis. There is a long-term inflammation of the joints of the spine. 

Usually the joints where the spine joins the pelvis are also affected. Eye and bowel problems may also occur. Pain in the back is a typical symptom of AS, and it often comes and goes. Stiffness of the affected joints usually gets worse over time.

[[Koba Davitashvili]]

Koba Davitashvili (კობა დავითაშვილი; July 31, 1971 – December 2, 2020) was a Georgian politician. He was a leader of the Georgian People's Party and co-founder of the United National Movement. He was a member of the Georgian Parliament between 1999 to 2006.

Davitashvili died on December 2, 2020 in Tbilisi from ankylosing spondylitis, aged 49.

[[Aldo Moser]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Italian cyclists, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Italy

Aldo Moser (7 February 1934 – 2 December 2020) was an Italian cyclist. Moser rode in 16 editions of the Giro d'Italia and 4 of the Vuelta a España, totaling in 20 Grand Tours. He was the older brother of Francesco Moser, Enzo Moser  and Diego Moser. He was born in Giovo, Italy.

Moser died on 2 December 2020 in Trento, Italy from COVID-19 at the age of 86.
