Indian_Election_Symbol_Scale.png Shiromani Akali DalHand_INC.svg Indian National CongressAAP_Symbol.png Aam Aadmi PartyIndian_Election_Symbol_Ears_of_Corn_and_Sickle.png Communist Party of IndiaIndian_Election_Symbol_Hammer_Sickle_and_Star.png Communist Party of India (Marxist)Water_bottle_RLP_election_symbol.svg Rashtriya Loktantrik PartyIndian_Election_Symbol_Bow_And_Arrow.png Shiv Sena

Over 1,500 telecom tower sites damaged (as of 28 Dec)

The 2020–21 Indian farmers' protest is a protest that is taking place right now in India. It was caused when Parliament passed three new laws. A lot of people think that these laws will hurt farmers and put them under the control of big farming corporations.

A lot of the farmers who are protesting are from Punjab and Haryana states.

[[2020 Indian general strike]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 in India, 2020 protests in Asia, November 2020 events, December 2020 events

On 26 November 2020, a mass general strike was held across India. Some people have estimated that 250 million (25 crore) people took part in the strike. If that number is correct, then it would be the biggest strike in history. The strike was jointly called by ten central trade unions – Indian National Trade Union Congress (INTUC), All India Trade Union Congress (AITUC), Hind Mazdoor Sabha (HMS), Centre of Indian Trade Unions (CITU), All India United Trade Union Centre (AIUTUC), Trade Union Co-ordination Centre (TUCC), Self-Employed Women’s Association (SEWA) and All India Central Council of Trade Unions (AICCTU), Labour Progressive Federation (LPF) and United Trade Union Congress (UTUC).

All over the country, both public and private sector employees participated in the strike. The united front of the over 250 farmers organizations, All India Kisan Sangharsh Co-ordination Committee (AIKSCC), extended support to the trade union strike and the unions extended their support to the farmers’ “Chalo Delhi” (Go to Delhi) mobilization on 26 and 27 November. Farmers are protesting against recent anti-farmer laws which would withdraw the government’s minimum support price for farm products, with serious implications for farmers’ income and livelihoods. 

The unions protested against the three new Labour Codes – the Industrial Relations Code Bill, 2020; the Code on Social Security Bill, 2020; and the Occupational Safety, Health and Working Conditions Code Bill, 2020 – that were passed by both houses of the Parliament earlier in 2020.

[[Vikki Carr]]

CATEGORIES: Singers from Texas, American pop singers, American country musicians, People from El Paso, Texas, Living people, 1940s births, Grammy Award winners

Vikki Carr (born July 19, 1940 or 1941 in El Paso, Texas) is an American singer. Her singing career has lasted several decades. She works in a variety of music genres, including pop, jazz and country music. Her greatest success, however, comes from singing in the Spanish language.

Carr has won three Grammy Awards. She was honored with a Lifetime Achievement Award at the Latin Grammy Awards.

Carr was born to parents of Mexican ancestry.

Many sources say Carr was born in 1940. Other sources say that she was born in 1941.December 2020

[[List of The Cleveland Show episodes]]

CATEGORIES: The Cleveland Show, Lists of animated television series episodes, Lists of comedy television series episodes

The Cleveland Show is an American animated sitcom. It was created by Seth MacFarlane, Richard Appel, and Mike Henry. The sitcom was first shown on the Fox network from September 27, 2009 to May 19, 2013. It is a spin-off of another show created by MacFarlane, Family Guy.

The series started with an order of 22 episodes. On May 3, 2009, Fox said that a second season with 13 more episodes will happen. This was said before the series was first shown on television. The second season was later given 9 more episodes. On June 10, 2010, Fox said that a third season would happen. On May 9, 2011, Fox said the fourth season will happen.

On April 17, 2013, Fox said that they were not sure about giving The Cleveland Show another season. However, on May 13, 2013, Fox's chairman Kevin Reilly said that The Cleveland Show has been cancelled. The main character Cleveland Brown and his family go back to Family Guy after the series was cancelled.

The Cleveland Show had 88 episodes in its four seasons.

[[Huba Rozsnyai]]

Huba Rozsnyai (14 December 1942 – 4 December 2020) was a Hungarian sprinter. He competed in the men's 100 metres at the 1964 Summer Olympics.

Rozsnyai died on 4 December 2020, just ten days before his 77.

[[Tony Curcillo]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, Arizona Cardinals players, Hamilton Tigers players, American football quarterbacks, Sportspeople from New Jersey

Anthony Curcillo Jr. (May 27, 1931 – December 8, 2020) was an American football player. He was born in Long Branch, New Jersey. His playing career lasted from 1953 to 1958. Curcillo played for the Chicago Cardinals and the Hamilton Tiger-Cats.

Curcillo died of COVID-19 on December 8, 2020 in Riverside, California at the age of 89.

[[Phil Linz]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, New York Yankees players, Philadelphia Phillies players, New York Mets players, Sportspeople from Baltimore, Maryland

Philip Francis Linz (June 4, 1939 – December 9, 2020) was an American professional baseball player. Linz played in Major League Baseball for the New York Yankees (1962–65), Philadelphia Phillies (1966–67), and New York Mets (1967–68). He was born in Baltimore, Maryland.

Linz died on December 9, 2020 at his home in Virginia at the age of 81.

[[Imran Momina]]

CATEGORIES: Pages created with the Article Wizard from 2020

Syed Muhammad Imran Momina AKA Emu is a multi-dimensional pianist & is one of the founding members of the band Fuzon who had been playing since the age of 19.

His flair for arranging his own music and experimenting with melodies made him set up his own recording and mixing studio — and this is where the jam sessions take place.

Technically proficient, self-tutored Fuzoneer, Emu has an array of possibilities at his disposal. Imran aka ‘Emu' is a charismatic keyboard exponent. The music stalwart that he is, Emu has an uncanny knack for orchestrating memorable music which is dominant in Fuzon's gilt-edged.

[[Vote Smart]]

CATEGORIES: Non-profit organizations of the United States

Vote Smart is a non-profit organization that collects information about candidates that run for a public office in the United Staes. For each candidate, the organisation gathers background information and political positions in different areas. It then distribnutes this informton in different channels, such as print media, its website, or using a toll-free phone number. With this, it helps people decide who they shouid vote for. Richard Kimball founded the platform in the 1990s. 

[[Deterministic system]]

CATEGORIES: Systems

In mathematics, and natural science, a deterministic system is a system where the current state the system  does not depend on random factors. It only depends on previous states, and time. A deterministic model will always produce the same state at a given time, given the same starting conditions.

Kismayo is a city in Somalia. It is the commercial capital of Jubaland. The word Kismayo is a Somali word which literally means small not.

[[Billy DeMars]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2020 deaths, Oakland Athletics players, Baltimore Orioles players, Baseball coaches, Sportspeople from New York City

William Lester DeMars (August 26, 1925 – December 10, 2020) was an American shortstop and coach in Major League Baseball. He threw and batted right-handed. He was born in Brooklyn, New York. He played for the Philadelphia Athletics in 1948 and for the St. Louis Browns from 1950 to 1951.

DeMars died on December 10, 2020 in Clearwater, Florida at the age of 95.

[[Tom Lister Jr.]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, 2020 deaths, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American professional wrestlers, Actors from Compton, California, Sportspeople from California, Blind people

Thomas Duane "Tom" Lister Jr. (June 24, 1958 — December 10, 2020) was an American actor and occasional professional wrestler. He was known for his roles as the neighborhood bully Deebo in Friday and its 2000 sequel and as President Lindberg in The Fifth Element. 

Lister Jr. also appeared as a prisoner in The Dark Knight (2008) who refused to activate Joker's bomb and voiced Finnick in Zootopia (2016).

He had two short professional wrestling performances, wrestling Hulk Hogan in the World Wrestling Federation (WWF) after appearing as Zeus in the 1989 movie No Holds Barred and for having a feud as Z-Gangsta in 1996 for World Championship Wrestling (WCW). 

Lister Jr. was born in Compton, California. He was blind in his right eye. 

In early 2020, Lister Jr. had COVID-19 and was successfully treated. However, shortly before his death, he showed COVID symptoms for a second time. Lister Jr. was found dead at his home in Marina Del Rey, California on December 10, 2020 at the age of 62. Investigation of his death is currently ongoing.

[[Next Friday]]

Next Friday is a 2000 American comedy movie and the sequel to the 1995 movie Friday. It is the first movie to be produced by Ice Cube's movie production company Cubevision. It was directed by Steve Carr.

It stars Ice Cube, Mike Epps, Don "D.C." Curry, John Witherspoon, and Tommy "Tiny" Lister Jr. The movie was released on January 12, 2000.

The Fifth Element (Le Cinquième Élément) is a 1997 English-language French science-fiction action movie directed and co-written by Luc Besson. It stars Bruce Willis, Gary Oldman, and Milla Jovovich.

The Fifth Element received mainly positive reviews.

[[José Mario Ruiz Navas]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Ecuadorian people, Roman Catholic priests, Roman Catholic archbishops

José Mario Ruiz Navas (20 July 1930  – 10 December 2020) was an Ecuadorian Roman Catholic prelate. Ruiz Navas was born in Pujilí, Ecuador. He became a priest in 1954. He was bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Latacunga, Ecuador, from 1968 to 1989 and then as bishop and then archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Portoviejo, Ecuador, from 1989 to 2007.

Ruiz Navas died on 10 December 2020 in Latacunga, Ecuador at the age of 90.

[[Pork cycle]]

CATEGORIES: Economics, Statistics

In economics, the term pork cycle, hog cycle, or cattle cycle describes the phenomenon of cyclical fluctuations of supply and prices in livestock markets. It was first observed in 1925 in pig markets in the US by Mordecai Ezekiel and in Europe in 1927 by the German scholar Arthur Hanau.

[[Nikolai Ivanov]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Russian movie actors, Russian television actors, Russian stage actors

Nikolai Nikolaevich Ivanov (22 January 1943 – 11 December 2020) was a Russian actor. He was born in Leningrad, Soviet Union. His career began in 1961. His best known roles were as Kolka in The Red Tent (1969), Pytor in The Love of Mankind (1972) and as Colonel Victor in Battle of Moscow (1985).

Ivanov died on 11 December 2020 in Saint Petersburg, Russia at the age of 77.

[[Malik (artist)]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from fire, French artists, Belgian comics artists, People from Paris

Malik (born William Tai; 2 January 1948 – 11 December 2020) was a French-born Belgian comics artist. He was born in Paris. He drew many works under the pseudonym Phénix. He was best known for his works with Bédéadult and Cupidon.

Malik died on 11 December 2020 from injuries caused by a house fire in Wallonia, Belgium at the age of 72.

[[Masao Komatsu]]

Komatsu was known for his roles in Kaiju funsen–Daigoro tai Goriasu (1972), Pink Lady no Katsudō Daishashin (1978), Station (1981), Izakaya Chōji (1983), University of Laughs (2004) and Journey to the Shore (2015).

Komatsu died on December 7, 2020 from liver cancer in Tokyo at the age of 78.

He was known for his roles as Charlie Tyrell in The Duchess of Duke Street, David Rose in Eye of the Needle, Edward in Three Men and a Little Lady, John Thatcher in A Knight's Tale and as Ben in Dynasty.

[[John Boswall]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, 2011 deaths, British movie actors, British stage actors, British voice actors, Deaths from pancreatic cancer, Actors from Oxfordshire, People from Oxford

John Boswall (2 May 1920 – 6 June 2011) was a British actor. He was best known for playing Barrow in Three Men and a Little Lady and as Wyvern in Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006). Boswall was born in Oxford, Oxfordshire. His career began in 1970 and he retired in 2009.

Boswall died of pancreatic cancer on 6 June 2011 in South Woodchester, Gloucestershire at the age of 91.

[[Irena Veisaitė]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic, Holocaust survivors, Lithuanian Jews, Lithuanian educators, Human rights activists, People from Kaunas

Irena Veisaitė (9 January 1928 – 11 December 2020) was a Lithuanian theatre scholar, intellectual and human rights activist. He was born in Kaunas, Lithuania. She was a Holocaust survivor. She was a lecturer at the teacher's college in Vilnius from 1953 to 1997

She was awarded the Goethe Medal in 2012 for her contribution to the cultural exchange between Germany and Lithuania. She was President of the Open Society in Lithuania Foundation.

Veisaitė died on 11 December 2020 in Vilnius from COVID-19 at the age of 92.

Imane Anys (ʾImān ʾAnīs (Arabic pronunciation: ʔimaːn ʔaniːs); born 14 May 1996), better known by her online alias Pokimane, is a Moroccan-Canadian internet personality. She is a Twitch streamer and YouTuber.

Anys is best known for her live streams on Twitch, where she is best known for playing League of Legends and Fortnite. She is a member of OfflineTV.

[[Hayabusa2]]

CATEGORIES: Spacecraft

Hayabusa2 is an asteroid sample-return mission owned by the Japanese state space agency JAXA. It replaced the Hayabusa mission, which returned asteroid samples for the first time in June 2010. 

Hayabusa2 was launched on 3 December 2014 and rendezvoused in space with near-Earth asteroid 162173 Ryugu on 27 June 2018. It surveyed the asteroid for a year and a half and took samples. It left the asteroid in November 2019 and returned the samples to Earth on 5 December 2020.

[[162173 Ryugu]]

CATEGORIES: Asteroids

162173 Ryugu is a near-Earth object and a potentially dangerous asteroid of the Apollo group. It is about 1 kilometer (0.6 mi) in diameter and is a dark object.

In June 2018, the Japanese spacecraft, Hayabusa2, arrived at the asteroid. After making measurements and taking samples, Hayabusa2 left Ryugu for Earth in November 2019 and returned to Earth on 5 December 2020.

[[Carlos Calvo]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2020 deaths, Argentine movie actors, Argentine stage actors, Argentine television actors, Argentine comedians, Actors from Buenos Aires, Deaths from stroke

Carlos Andrés "Carlín" Calvo (21 February 1953 – 11 December 2020) was an Argentine actor and comedian. His career began in 1972. Calvo was best known for his roles in Enrique Dawi directed movies such Locos por la música (1980), Los Hijos de López (1980) and in Adiós, Roberto (1985). Calvo was born in Buenos Aires.

Calvo died of problems caused by multiple strokes in Buenos Aires on 11 December 2020, aged 67.

[[Lily Eskelsen García]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, Living people, American educators, American labor leaders, Politicians from Texas, US Democratic Party politicians

Lily Eskelsen García (née Pace; born May 1, 1955) is an American teacher and labor union leader. She was president of the National Education Association from 2014 to 2020. 

In November 2020, following the United States presidential election, many news organizations saw her as a potential candidate for President-elect Joe Biden’s United States Secretary of Education. 

[[Fort Hood]]

CATEGORIES: United States Army, Buildings and structures in Texas

Fort Hood is a United States Army post in Killeen, Texas. It is named after Confederate General John Bell Hood. It is located halfway between Austin and Waco, about 60 from each, within the U.S. state of Texas. 

The post is the headquarters of III Corps and First Army Division West and is home to the 1st Cavalry Division and 3rd Cavalry Regiment, among others.  

It is one of ten U.S. Army bases named after former Confederate generals.

[[Fountain Place]]

CATEGORIES: Skyscrapers in the United States, Buildings and structures in Texas, Dallas, Texas

Fountain Place is a 60-story late-modernist skyscraper in downtown Dallas, Texas. It stands at a height of 720. It is the fifth-tallest building in Dallas and the 15th-tallest in Texas.

[[Bank of America Plaza (Dallas)]]

CATEGORIES: Skyscrapers in the United States, Buildings and structures in Texas, Dallas, Texas

Bank of America Plaza is a 72-story, 280.7 late-modernist skyscraper in Dallas, Texas, United States. It is the tallest skyscraper in the city, the 3rd tallest in Texas and the 40th tallest in the United States.  

Construction began in 1983 and the tower was completed in 1985.

[[Neoselachii]]

CATEGORIES: Sharks, Rays

The Neoselachii are an important group of cartilaginous fish in the subclass Elasmobranchii, class Chondrichthyes. 

The group is important because it includes all living  sharks, skates,  and rays. They rapidly diversified during the Upper Triassic.

The group is descended from a primitive type of shark in the Devonian period.

She voiced Melia Antiqua in the video game Xenoblade Chronicles.

[[Williams Tower]]

CATEGORIES: Skyscrapers in the United States, Buildings and structures in Houston, Texas

The Williams Tower (originally named the Transco Tower) is a 64-story, 1.4 office tower. It is located in Houston, Texas. 

Construction began in August 1981, and was completed in December, 1982. It is the 4th-tallest tower in Texas, and the 44th-tallest in the United States.

[[Intraspecific competition]]

CATEGORIES: Biological competition

In ecology, intraspecific competition is when two individuals of the same species compete for limited resources. Usually, the one winning the competition has a better fitness, and may better be able to reproduce. Examples for resources are food, water, space, light, or mates. This is different from interspecific competition vwhere members of different species compete. Intraspecific competition is important, because through evolution, species can become better adapted to where they live.

Valennurg aan de Geul is a municipality in the Dutch province of Limburg. In 2019, 16,470 people lived there.

[[Venray]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Limburg (Netherlands), Municipalities of Limburg (Netherlands)

Venray is a town and municipality in the Dutch province of Limburg. As of 2020, about 41,000 people were living in the municipality and about 28,500 people were living in the town.

In 2010, parts of the former municipality of Meerlo-Wanssum were added to Venray (Blitterswijck, Geijsteren, and Wanssum).

[[Interspecific competition]]

CATEGORIES: Biological competition

In ecology, interspecific competition is when individuals of different species compete for the same resources, in an ecosystem. Examples for such resources are food, or space. Even species that never meet can compete with each other, because they need the same resources: Two kinds of predators might prey on the same animals.  Interspecific competition is important, because it regulates the population of the different species. It is one of the ways natural selection happens. Interspecific competition causes evolution. 

When two individuals of the same species compete, this is called intraspecific competition.

[[Divya Bhatnagar]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 births, 2020 deaths, Indian actors

Divya Bhatnagar (17 September 1986- 7 December 2020) was an Indian actress and production manager. Known for television shows like Sethji, Shrimaan Shrimati Phir Se, Sawaare Sabke Sapne… Preeto, Yeh Rishta Kya Kehlata Hai etc. She started her career with the show Chand Ke Paar Chalo in the year 2006. She also appeared in Bollywood films like 99 and Sapne Sakar karo. She was diagnosed with COVID-19, and died from it, at the age of 34. Shortly before her death Divya said that she had a problem with domestic violence, and that her husband regularly beat her. Her sister,  Devoleena Bhattacharjee, accused Divya's husband for being responsible for her  death.

[[Psychological horror]]

CATEGORIES: Movie genres, Horror, Video game genres

A psychological horror is a type of horror and psychological fiction used in movies, games, and books. It is used to make the viewer unsettled and uncomfortable. This type of horror is close to psychological thriller, because they both have mysteries most of the time and have unreliable or disturbed characters to make the drama and action bigger, so they can make the story less happy and sadder.

[[Forgetting curve]]

CATEGORIES: Psychology, Learning

The forgetting curve is an idea from psychology, that shows how rapidly people forget things, if they do nothing to retain them. German psychologist Hermann Ebbinghaus discovered it. A related concept is the strength of memory: People with a stronger memory are able to remember things longer. Ebbinghaus tested how long he could remember random syllables, and recorded the results in his paper Über das Gedächtnis (1885). In 1913, this was translated into English as Memory: A Contribution to Experimental Psychology". Ebbinghaus studied the memorisation of nonsense syllables, such as "WID" and "ZOF" (CVCs or Consonant–Vowel–Consonant) by repeatedly testing himself after various time periods and recording the results. He plotted these results on a graph creating what is now known as the "forgetting curve". Ebbinghaus investigated the rate of forgetting, but not the effect of spaced repetition on the increase in retrievability of memories.

As a rough guide, after 20 minutes, people can only recall about 60% of what they memorized. After a week, only about 15% is left. When Ebbinghaus did the experiment, he used meaningless sequences of syllables. In the 20th century, several other researchers repeated the experiment. One of them was Georg Elias Müller. For this reason, the results are still considered to be valid.

To be able to remember things better, more repetitions are needed. Things that are needed and used more often, will not be forgotten so easily. 

[[Francisco de Vitoria]]

CATEGORIES: Articles with unsourced statements

Francisco de Vitoria (Boroughs, 1483 or 1486-Salamanca, 12 August 1546) was a friar dominico Spanish, writer and chair of the University of Salamanca, the one who stood out by his ideas and contributions to the international right and the moral economy based in the thought humanist of the Aristotelian realism-tomista.

[[Calanley mosque]]

CATEGORIES: Jubaland, Mosques

Calanley mosque or Masjid express is a historically Ibadist mosque in Kismayo, Jubaland. Its minarets have a Ibadite semiellipse shape. The reason the minarets have a Ibadist design is that Kismayo and Jubaland used to be under the influence of the Ibadi-ruled Sultanate of Zanzibar. This is the reason that colonial era buildings in Jubaland have an Ibadist design.

[[Sultanate of Zanzibar]]

CATEGORIES: 19th-century establishments in Africa, Ibadi kingdoms

The Sultanate of Zanzibar was an Ibadite kingdom in East Africa. It was under the influence of the Omani Muscat Sultanate at first. It came to an end when the British East Africa colony was established. This means it ended at the turn of the twentieth century.

[[Rustamid kingdom]]

CATEGORIES: Ibadi kingdoms

The Rustamid kingdom is a former Ibadist kingdom in Algeria. The Rustamid Kingdom had an Ibadite dynasty which ruled Algeria from 779 until 909. The Rustamids are the longest-lasting Ibadi kingdom in north Africa.

[[Paramount+]]

CATEGORIES: Entertainment websites

Paramount+ (formerly CBS All Access) is an American  streaming service owned and operated by ViacomCBS Streaming, a subsidiary of ViacomCBS. It offers original content, content recently transmitted in the transmission properties of CBS and content from the ViacomCBS library. In the United States, many markets offer a live stream from the main channel of the local CBS affiliate. As of November 5, 2020, it had 17.9 million subscribers.

Paramount + would also expand to international markets, starting with Latin America on the day of the service rebranding, followed by the Nordic countries on March 25, 2021 and Australia in mid-2021.

[[Hermann Ebbinghaus]]

CATEGORIES: 1850 births, 1909 deaths, German psychologists, Deaths from pneumonia

Hermann Ebbinghaus (24 January 1850 – 26 February 1909) was a German psychologist. Today, he is mostly known for his work regarding learning and forgetting. He was the first to do experiments to explore how memory works. He first described the forgetting curve, the learning curve and the spacing effect. The Ebbinghaus illusion, which is named after him is related to the perception, not memory. His son was the philosopher Julius Ebbinghaus. 

In 1896, he did a test on children in school: The pupils had to complete sentences, and their teacher had to rate each pupil, if the pupil was in the lowest, the middle or the highest third of all the people in the class. Ebbinghaus saw a relationship between the teacher's rating, and the result of the pupil, but he could not give a correlation (because he was lacking the tools to do so). This was possibly the first test of verbal intelligence in a group. 

Many of his experimental methods to rate memory performance are still in use.

Ebbinghaus died of pneumonia, when he was 59 years old.  

[[Will Hurd]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 births, Living people, United States representatives from  Texas, US Republican Party politicians

William Ballard Hurd (born August 19, 1977) is an American politician. He was the U.S. representative for Texas's 23rd congressional district from 2015 to 2021.

[[Ruhollah Zam]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 births, 2020 deaths, People executed by hanging, Iranian journalists, People from Tehran, Political activists

Ruhollah Zam (روح‌الله زم, also Romanized as "Rouhollah Zam"; 27 July 1978 – 12 December 2020) was an Iranian activist and journalist. He was best known for working with Telegram channel named 'Amadnews'.

Zam was a well known activist during the 2017–18 Iranian protests.

In June 2020, an Iran court found him guilty of "corruption on earth" for running a popular anti-government forum. He was sentenced to death by an Iranian court and was executed on 12 December 2020, aged 42.

[[Valentin Gaft]]

Valentin Iosifovich Gaft (Валенти́н Ио́сифович Гафт; 2 September 1935 – 12 December 2020) was a Russian actor. He was awarded the People's Artist of Russia in 1984. Gaft was born in Moscow. Gaft was known for his roles in Hello, I'm Your Aunt!, Say a Word for the Poor Hussar and Forgotten Melody for a Flute.

Gaft died on 12 December 2020 in Moscow at the age of 85.

[[Osvaldo Cochrane Filho]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Brazilian water polo players

Oswaldo Cochrane Filho (29 July 1933 – 9 December 2020) was a Brazilian water polo player. He competed in the men's tournament at the 1964 Summer Olympics. He was born in Espirito Santo, Brazil. He played for the national team for the first time in 1955 until he retired after the 1971 Pan American Games.

Cochrane Filho died on 9 December 2020 in Rio de Janeiro at the age of 87.

[[Kurt Stettler]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Swiss footballers, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Switzerland, Association football goalkeepers

Kurt Stettler (21 August 1932 – 8 December 2020) was a Swiss football goalkeeper. He played for Switzerland in the 1962 FIFA World Cup. Stettler began playing for the national team in 1961 and retired in 1963. Stettler was born in Stettlen, Switzerland. He mainly played with FC Basel from 1957 to 1964 making 160 appearances. 

Stettler died on 8 December 2020 in Zürich from COVID-19 at the age of 88.

[[Kenneth Alwyn]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2020 deaths, English composers, Conductors, Writers from London

Kenneth Alwyn (born Kenneth Alwyn Wetherell) (28 July 1925 – 11 December 2020) was an English conductor, composer and writer. He was called by the BBC as "one of the great British musical directors". 

Alwyn was known for his many recordings, including with the London Symphony Orchestra on Decca's first stereophonic recording of Tchaikovsky's 1812 Overture. He was also known for his works with BBC Radio 2's orchestral live music programme Friday Night is Music Night.

He was a Fellow of the Royal Academy of Music.

Alwyn died on 11 December 2020 in London at the age of 95.

[[James Flynn (academic)]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths

James Robert Flynn FRSNZ (28 April 1934 – 11 December 2020) was a New Zealand intelligence researcher. He taught political studies at the University of Otago in Dunedin. He was known for his studies on the increase of IQ scores throughout the world, which is now known as the Flynn effect. 

Flynn died on 11 December 2020 in Dunedin, New Zealand at the age of 86.

[[U. A. Khader]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Indian novelists, Burmese people

U. A. Khader (1935–12 December 2020) was an Burmese-born Indian writer. He published in Malayalam such as novels. His works have been translated to many  languages including English, Hindi and Kannada. Khader was born in Bilin, Rangoon, Burma. Khader's first story was published in Chandrika weekly in 1953. He was the president of Purogamana Kala Sahitya Sangham.

Khader died on 12 December 2020 at a hospital in Calicut, Kerala at the age of 85.

[[Fikre Selassie Wogderess]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from diabetes, Prime Ministers of Ethiopia, War criminals

Fikre Selassie Wogderess (ፍቅረ ሥላሴ ወግደረስ; 13 July 1945 – 12 December 2020) was an Ethiopian politician. He was the first Prime Minister of the People's Democratic Republic of Ethiopia (PDRE) from 10 September 1987 to 8 November 1989. He was fired by President Mengistu Haile Mariam.

In 1989, he was sentenced to death for war crimes and murder. In 2010, the Ethiopian court removed his death sentence and released him following year.

Wogderess died on 12 December 2020 in Addis Ababa from diabetes-related problems at the age of 75.

[[Qisas]]

CATEGORIES: Law

Qisas or Qiṣāṣ (Qiṣāṣ) is a term interpreted to mean "retaliation in kind", "eye for an eye", or retributive justice. 

In historical practice, qisas appears in two forms. One of them is, the punishment of the perpetrator "with the same act" in crimes "committed against the physical integrity of the person, such as a life for a life, an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth". Another application is related to the social status of the perpetrator and the victim. In the tribal understanding, when a person kills a woman, a slave or an honorable person from another tribe, a person "of similar status from the tribe to which the murderer belongs" will be killed in return. As a general custom, killing the master's to slave, father's to child, husband's to wife was not punished with retaliation, and retaliation was not applied to the man who killed the woman as a rule. The condition of "social equality" in qisas means that; "if a socially inferior person kills someone from the upper class, qisas will be applied", whereas "if someone from the upper class kills someone from the lower class, it cannot be applied". 

In this case, compensation can be paid to the family of the murdered person.

The main verse for implementation in Islam is Al Baqara; 178 verse;

: 'Believers! Retaliation is ordained for you regarding the people who were killed. Free versus free, captive versus captive, woman versus woman. Whoever is forgiven by the brother of the slain for a price, let him abide by the custom and pay the price well."

In traditional Islamic law (sharia), the doctrine of qisas allows a punishment analogous to the crime. Qisas is available to the victim or victim's heirs against a person convicted of murder or intentional bodily injury. In the case of murder, qisas gives the right to take the life of the killer, if the latter is convicted and the court approves. Those who are entitled to qisas have the option of receiving monetary compensation (diyya) or granting pardon to the person instead.

[[Hylarana]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Asia, Frogs

Hylarana is a genus of true frogs.  They are also called golden-backed frogs. They live in tropical Asia. Scientists used to put 84 to 96 valid species in Hylarana, but they looked at the frogs again.  Today, scientists say four species are in Hylarana.

[[Sharlene Whyte]]

Her other notable credits include Adanna Lawal in the BBC One school-based drama series Waterloo Road (2011), although she first appeared in Waterloo Road as Alison Yates (2009), and Bev in the CBBC children's comedy-drama series Sadie J (2013). She has also acted in other British television series such as multiple roles in Doctors and Casualty and roles in Silent Witness and Coronation Street. She trained at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art from 1996 till 1999. 

Whyte is of Grenadian descent.

[[City Girls]]

City Girls are an American hip hop duo from Miami, Florida consisting of Yung Miami (born Caresha Romeka Brownlee on February 11, 1994) and JT (born Jatavia Shakara Johnson on December 3, 1992). They garnered attention after making an uncredited guest appearance on Drake's chart-topping hit, "In My Feelings". Their debut studio album, Girl Code (2018), spawned the platinum certified singles "Twerk" and  "Act Up". Their second studio album, City on Lock was released in 2020.

[[Lil Baby]]

CATEGORIES: 1994 births

Dominique Armani Jones (born December 3, 1994), known professionally as Lil Baby, is an American rapper, singer, and songwriter from Atlanta, Georgia. He rose to mainstream fame in 2017 following the release of his mixtape Perfect Timing, becoming one of the most popular artists in the trap music genre as of now.

Lil Baby's debut studio album Harder Than Ever (2018) was certified RIAA Platinum and included the song "Yes Indeed" with Drake, which peaked at six on the Billboard Hot 100. He went on to release two more mixtapes in 2018, Drip Harder and Street Gossip, the former containing his most popular song "Drip Too Hard", which peaked at number four on the Billboard Hot 100, and the latter peaking at number two on the US Billboard 200. Lil Baby's second album, My Turn (2020), peaked at number one on the Billboard 200. The song "We Paid", from the album, charted at number ten on the Hot 100. In June 2020, he released the single "The Bigger Picture", which peaked at number three on the Hot 100 and became the highest charting song of his career. 

Throughout his career, Lil Baby has been nominated for three Grammy Awards, two American Music Awards, two MTV Video Music Awards, and seven BET Awards.

She was a professor at the University of Missouri–Kansas City. 

She also was an advisor to Bernie Sanders' 2016 presidential campaign.

[[Belle Delphine]]

CATEGORIES: 1999 births, Living people, People from Cape Town, British YouTubers, South African models, Adult models, Pornographic actors

Mary-Belle Kirschner (born 23 October 1999), better known online as Belle Delphine, is a South African-born British Internet celebrity, model, and YouTuber.

Delphine was born on 23 October 1999 in South Africa, and was raised in Cape Town. She experienced a devout Christian family upbringing. After her parents divorced, she moved to Lymington, England with her mother. Now in Hampshire, she attended Priestlands School, but dropped out at the age of fourteen, due to being bullied online. Around this time, she was treated for depression. After dropping out, she found work as a waitress, nanny, and barista. Delphine additionally began posting pictures of her cosplay onto her Facebook account, which was later deleted. Delphine's now-deleted cosplay posts were "low-res and dimly lit."

Delphine has a boyfriend, who often works on the photography of her modeling content and likes to remain anonymous. Claire Kittrell has stated that she is dating Delphine.

Initially he's a fabbricator of weapons until he discovers that terrorists used them to harm innocents. Then he decided to stop the production of weapons and instead he starts building and wearing a technological suit to fight criminals.

[[National parks and nature reserves of Israel]]

CATEGORIES: Geography of Israel, National parks in Asia

The national parks of Israel are historic sites or nature reserves, which are mostly operated by the National Nature and Parks Authority. In 2015, Israel had 81 national parks and more than 400 nature reserves.

Some of the country's most notable parks are located at sites such as Tel Megiddo, Jerusalem and Ashkelon. These include the "Alexander stream" and "Mount Carmel National Park". Several parks and nature reserves have camping options, such as tent grounds and bungalows, open to small groups or campers. The main idea behind these parks and reserves is to guard the values of nature, landscape, heritage, and species.

Following the drying of Lake Hula, the Hula Reserve was established in 1964 and became the first declared nature reserve in Israel. It is a major stopover for birds migrating between Africa, Europe and Asia. In 1963 the Israeli parliament approved the "National parks and nature reserves act", and as a result, two authorities were established: the National Parks Authority and the Nature Reserves Authority. In 1998 the two authorities were merged into one body - Israel Nature and Parks Authority.

In Israel, the difference between national parks and nature reserves is often hard to make. National parks are in most cases centered around archaeological sites, but sometimes include protected nature as well. The nature reserves often contain not just protected flowers, trees and animals, but also archaeological sites of importance.

[[Brandon Bernard]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 births, 2020 deaths, African-American people, American burglars, American kidnappers, American people executed for murder, American robbers, Criminals from Texas, People executed by lethal injection, People from San Antonio, Texas

Brandon Anthony Micah Bernard (July 3, 1980 – December 10, 2020) was an American man who was convicted for the 1999 robbery, kidnapping, and murder of two people. He was sentenced to death for the murders and remained on death row until his execution in December 2020.

Bernard was a gang member. In 1999, Bernard was one of five gang members who together robbed, kidnapped, and murdered two youth pastors. After forcing the pastors into the trunk of their car, Christopher Andre Vialva shot both in the head before Bernard set the car on fire with the victims inside. Vialva was executed on September 24, 2020, and Bernard was executed on December 10, 2020.

Sutton died on December 10, 2020 from COVID-19 in New Orleans at the age of 76.

[[Jimmy Collins (basketball)]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Chicago Bulls players, College basketball coaches, Sportspeople from New York, People from Syracuse, New York, Deaths from surgical complications

James Earl Collins (November 24, 1946 – December 13, 2020) was an American basketball player and coach. He was born and raised in Syracuse, New York. He played for the Chicago Bulls from 1970 to 1972.

Collins was the head coach of the men's basketball team at the University of Illinois at Chicago from 1996 to 2010. He helped push the team to the NCAA Tournament in 1998, 2002 and 2004, and an NIT showing in 2003.

Collins died on December 13, 2020 from heart surgery-related problems in Chicago at the age of 74.

[[Investing.com]]

CATEGORIES: Websites, Money

Investing.com is a notable financial website. It provides financial news as well as information about market "quotes", foreign exchange, stocks, commodities, currencies, interest rates and more. As of December 2020, it is the second most popular financial website in the world and is among the top 200 most popular websites overall.

The website was founded in 2007 as "Forexpros". In 2012 its name changed to Investing.com, after the company bought their (domain) name for $2.45 million.

In the years 2013-2014, Investing.com launched Android and iOS apps, and in 2019 had editions in 24 languages. 

[[Nur Hossain Kasemi]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from respiratory failure, Bangladeshi educators, Bangladeshi politicians, Bangladeshi Muslims, People from Dhaka

Allama Nur Hossain Kasemi (নূর হুসাইন কাসেমী) (10 January 1945 — 13 December 2020) was a Bangladeshi Deobandi Islamic scholar, politician, educator, religious speaker and spiritual figure. He was the Secretary General of Hefazat-e-Islam Bangladesh from November 2020 until his death. He also was in charge of Jamiat Ulema-e-Islam Bangladesh from 2015 until his death. Kasemi was born in Dhaka.

Kasemi died at a Dhaka hospital on 13 December 2020 from respiratory failure, aged 75.

[[Escurinho]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Brazilian footballers, Deaths from Alzheimer's disease, Deaths from multiple organ failure

Benedito Custódio Ferreira, nicknamed Escurinho (3 July 1930 – 12 December 2020) was a Brazilian footballer who played as an attacking midfielder and left winger. He was born in Nova Lima, Brazil. Escurinho played for Villa Nova, Fluminense, Atlético Junior, Portuguesa (RJ) and Bonsucesso.

He played eight times for the Brazilian national team between 1955 and 1956.

He died on 12 November 2020 from Alzheimer's disease and multiple organ failure in Nova Lima at the age of 90.

[[Nicolas Chumachenco]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Polish musicians, German musicians, Violinists, People from Kraków, Spanish musicians

Nicolas Chumachenco (also known as Nicolas Chumachenko; March 27, 1944 – December 12, 2020), was a Polish-born Spanish-German violin soloist and professor. He was director of the Queen Sofía Chamber Orchestra. Chumachenco was born in Kraków, in Nazi-occupied Poland, to Ukrainian parents who left Poland at the end of the Second World War.

Chumachenco died on December 12, 2020 in Schallstadt, Germany at the age of 76.

[[Claude Castonguay]]

He was a member of the National Assembly of Quebec from 1970 to 1973. Catonguay was a member of the Senate of Canada from 1990 to 1992.

Castonguay died on December 12, 2020 at the age of 91.

[[Bird Averitt]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, San Antonio Spurs players, Los Angeles Clippers players, New Jersey Nets players, Sportspeople from Kentucky

William Rodney "Bird" Averitt (July 22, 1952sndDecember 12, 2020) was an American professional basketball player in the American Basketball Association (ABA) and the National Basketball Association (NBA). He was born in Hopkinsville, Kentucky. His career lasted from 1973 to 1978. Averitt played for the San Antonio Spurs, Kentucky Colonels, Buffalo Braves and New Jersey Nets.

Averitt died on December 12, 2020 at the age of 68.

[[Hotsuit]]

CATEGORIES: Clothing

Hotsuit is a fitness apparel and accessories brand. It is designed to make the wearer sweat profusely. It is intended for use in sports however, it has become commonly worn in other contexts. 

[[Scalable Hosting]]

CATEGORIES: Internet, 2019 establishments in Europe

Scalable Hosting or "Scalacube" develops hosting services that include a control panel, allowing users to create their game servers for Minecraft, Rust, ARK, Hytale, etc. According to their website, they combines VPS and game server hosting. 

The company was founded in January 2019 by Kostiantyn Rohatkin and is headquartered in Tallinn, Estonia. In October 2020, the business was accredited by the Estonian Startup Committee.

[[Confidence and supply]]

CATEGORIES: Government, Politics

Confidence and supply is an agreement in a Westminster system government where parties or independents agree to support the minority government in votes of no confidence and appropriation or budget (supply) votes. This lets the government keep control of the lower house.

[[McNary, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Louisiana

McNary is a village in Rapides Parish, Louisiana, United States.

[[Hung parliament]]

CATEGORIES: Government, Politics

A hung parliament (also called a balanced parliament, or as a legislature under no overall control) is when no political party (or coalition that existed before) has a majority in the Westminster system of legislatures. If this isn't solved with something like a confidence and supply agreement or a new coalition, the largest party will have to form a minority government. This is bad because they can easily lose a vote of no confidence, so a government is hard to run.

[[Hagewood, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: Unincorporated communities in Natchitoches Parish, Louisiana

Hagewood is an unincorporated community in Natchitoches Parish, Louisiana, United States.

[[Master and slave philosophy]]

CATEGORIES: Philosophical concepts, Slavery

"Master and slave" is a theme in philosophy that can be used in different ways. It is explained by the German philosophers Georg W. F. Hegel and Friedrich Nietzsche but with different meanings. In philosophy, the words "master" and "slave" are not always meant literally. The theme refers to a hierarchy of certain things or people being put beneath others.

[[Mackenzie Ziegler]]

CATEGORIES: 2004 births, American singers, American dancers, American child actors, American television actors, Singers from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, Actors from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, Living people

Mackenzie Frances Ziegler (born June 4, 2004) is an American dancer, actress, model, and singer. She first got noticed as a child while appearing for six years on the Lifetime reality dance series Dance Moms with her older sister, Maddie Ziegler, who is a dancer and actress. 

[[Without Love]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 movies, 1940s romance movies, 1940s comedy movies, American romantic comedy movies, Movies based on plays, MGM movies

Without Love is a 1945 American romantic comedy movie directed by Harold S. Bacquet and was based on the 1942 play of the same name by Philip Barry. It stars Spencer Tracy, Katharine Hepburn, Lucille Ball, Keenan Wynn, Carl Esmond, Patricia Morison and was distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

[[1980 United States heat wave]]

CATEGORIES: Severe weather, Droughts, Natural disasters in the United States, 1980 in the United States

The 1980 United States heat wave was a period of strong heat and drought. It caused serious havoc and damage in the Southern Great Plains and much of the Midwestern United States during the summer of 1980. It was one of the most devastating and damaging natural disasters in terms of deaths.

The heat wave first got started in June 1980. A strong high pressure area began building in the central and Southern United States. That allowed the temperatures to soar to 90 almost every day from June to September. This high pressure system acted as a cap on the atmosphere. That prevented thunderstorm development and caused severe drought conditions. But the heat wave broke when the dying Hurricane Allen stopped the weather pattern.

The heat wave and drought led a number of cities in the Midwest and South to have record heat. In Kansas City, Missouri, the high temperature was only below 90 twice. In the same city, the high temperature hit 100 17 days in a row. In Memphis, Tennessee, the high temperature reached 108 on Sunday, July 13. It was part of a 15-day stretch of 100 temperatures that lasted from July 6 to July 20.

The agricultural damage by the 1980 heat wave and drought was over $20 billion (1980 USD). That allowed the temperatures to soar to 90 almost every day from June to September. This high pressure system acted as a cap on the atmosphere.

In Dallas-Fort Worth, Texas, high temperatures exceeded 100 a total of 69 times. Forty-two of those were consecutive days. In Dallas-Fort Worth, the high temperature hit 113 on two days: June 26 and 27.

[[Lovers and Liars]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 comedy movies, Italian comedy movies, French comedy movies, Movies directed by Mario Monicelli

Lovers and Liars (Viaggio con Anita) is a 1979 Italian French comedy movie directed by Mario Monicelli and starring Goldie Hawn, Giancarlo Giannini, Claudine Auger, Aurore Clément, Laura Betti, Andréa Ferréol.

[[MediaZona]]

CATEGORIES: 2014 establishments, Websites, Belarus, Russia, Kyrgyzstan, Kazakhstan, Censorship in Belarus, Free Media Award winners

MediaZona is a Russian website. Two girls from the Russian punk rock collective Pussy Riot (Maria Alyokhina and Nadezhda Tolokonnikova) made it in 2014. Russian political journalist Sergey Smirnov is the main editor of the website.

MediaZona gives information on the judicial, law enforcement, and penal system in Russia. Since 2020 the site gives such news on Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, and Belarus too.

MediaZona has a Russian media license, but Tolokonnikova said in 2016 that it could be taken away at any time.

The site of MediaZona can't be opened in Belarus.

On 30 January 2021, the main editor of Mediazona Sergey Smirnov was locked up by the police.

[[Born to Win]]

Born to Win is a 1971 American black comedy movie directed by Ivan Passer and starring George Segal, Karen Black, Paula Prentiss, Hector Elizondo, Robert De Niro. It was distributed by United Artists.

[[Charlotte Tillar Schexnayder]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Arkansas, American journalists, Writers from Arkansas, US Democratic Party politicians

Charlotte Tillar Schexnayder (December 25, 1923 – December 11, 2020) was an American journalist and politician. She was a member of the Arkansas House of Representatives from the 74th district from 1985 to 1999. She was born in Tillar, Arkansas. Schexnayder was a member of the Democratic Party.

Schexnayder died on December 11, 2020 in Little Rock, Arkansas at the age of 96.

[[Huang Zongying]]

Huang died on 14 December 2020 in Beijing at the age of 95.

[[Piotr Machalica]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Poland, Polish movie actors, Polish television actors, Polish stage actors, Polish voice actors

Piotr Machalica (13 February 1955 – 14 December 2020) was a Polish actor. His career began in 1979. Machalica was born in Pszczyna, Poland. Machalica played Tadeusz in Hero of the Year (1987), Roman in Dekalog: Nine (1988) and Roman in A Short Film About Love (1988).

Machalica died on 14 December 2020 in Warsaw from COVID-19 at the age of 65.

[[Alfonso Gagliano]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Italian politicians, Canadian politicians, Naturalized citizens of Canada

Alfonso Gagliano PC  (alˈfɔnso gaʎˈʎaːno; (January 25, 1942 – December 12, 2020) was an Italian-born Canadian accountant and a Liberal Party politician. He was born in Siculiana, Italy. Gagliano was a member of the Parliament of Canada from 1984 to 2002. He also was a Minister of Labour from 1996 to 1997 and of Public Works and Government Services from 1997 to 2002.

Gagliano died on December 12, 2020 at the age of 78.

Kay died on December 12, 2020 from liver cancer in Athens, Georgia at the age of 82.

[[Jerzy Mikułowski Pomorski]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Polish scientists, Sociologists

Jerzy Mikułowski Pomorski (3 January 1937 – 12 December 2020) was a Polish sociologist and professor. He was a doctor honoris causa of Grand Valley State University (1993) and Teesside University (1995). He was a rector of Cracow University of Economics in years 1990–1996.

Pomorski died on 12 December 2020 at the age of 83.

[[Radhika Ranjan Pramanick]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Indian politicians

Radhika Ranjan Pramanick (18 December 1932 – 13 December 2020) was an Indian politician. He was born in West Bengal, British India. Pramanick was a member of the All India Trinamool Congress. From 1989 to 2004, he was a member of the Lok Sabha. 

Pramanick died on 13 December 2020 in Kolkata, India at the age of 87.

[[Shahid Mahmood]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Pakistani cricketers

Shahid Mahmood (Urdu: شاہد محمود) (17 March 1939 – 13 December 2020) was a Pakistani cricketer. He was born in Lucknow. He played in one Test in 1962. He played first-class cricket in Pakistan from 1957 to 1969. He played for the national team.

Mahmood died on 13 December 2020 in New Jersey at the age of 81.

[[Otto Barić]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Croatia, Croatian footballers, Croatian football managers, Austrian footballers, Austrian football managers

Otto Barić (bǎːritɕ; 19 June 1933 – 13 December 2020) was an Austrian-born Croatian football player and later manager. He was born in Eisenkappel-Vellach, Austria. From 1958 to 1963, he played for Lokomotiva Zagreb. He managed the national team from 2002 to 2004.

Barić died of COVID-19 on 13 December 2020 in Zagreb, Croatia at the age of 87.

Fiorenzo Alfieri (11 September 1943 – 13 December 2020) was an Italian educator and politician. He was born in Polignano a Mare, Italy. He was a member of the Turin City Council from 1995 to 2000.

Alfieri died of COVID-19 in Turin on 13 December 2020 at the age of 77.

[[Polignano a Mare]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Italy, Settlements in Apulia

Polignano a Mare (poliɲˈɲaːno a mˈmaːre; Barese: Peghegnéne) is a town and comune in the Metropolitan City of Bari, Apulia, southern Italy, located on the Adriatic Sea. 

[[Hasu Yajnik]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Indian writers, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in India, Critics, Editors

Hasmukhray Vrajlal Yajnik (12 February 1938 ― 10 December 2020), better known as Hasu Yajnik, also spelled Hasu Yagnik was a Gujarati writer and editor. He wrote novels, short stories, criticism, folklore, and children's stories. He was a professor of Gujarati in many government colleges in Gujarat. 

He wrote twenty novels, three short story collections, two jail stories, four medieval stories, and criticism of four medieval works. He edited twelve folk works and six works of children's literature.

He was the registrar of the Gujarat Sahitya Akademi, Gandhinagar from 1982 to 1996. He was a founder and managing trustee of the Meghani Lokvidya Sanshodhan Bhavan, Ahmedabad from 1996 to 2005.

He died on 10 December 2020 due to COVID-19 in Ahmedabad at the age of 82.

[[Diego Novelli]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, Living people, People from Turin, Mayors, Former MEPs, MEPs for Italy

Diego Novelli (born 22 May 1931) is an Italian politician. He was born in Turin. 

Novelli was a member of the Italian Communist Party. He was a Member of the European Parliament from 1984 to 2001. He was a member of the Chamber of Deputies from 1987 to 2001. Novelli was Mayor of Turin from 1975 to 1985.

[[Valentino Castellani]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, Living people, Mayors, Italian politicians, People from Turin

Valentino Castellani (born 19 March 1940) is an Italian politician. He was the independent Mayor of Turin from 24 June 1993 to 1 June 2001. Castellani was born in Varmo, Italy. From 1999 to 2006, he was President of the International Olympic Committee.

[[Varmo]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Friuli-Venezia Giulia

Varmo (Vildivar) is a comune (municipality) in the Province of Udine in the Italian region Friuli-Venezia Giulia. It is about 70 northwest of Trieste and about 30 southwest of Udine.

[[Burshtyn]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Ukraine

Burshtyn (Буршти́н) is a city located in Ivano-Frankivsk Oblast, Ukraine. Its population is 14,976 (2020).

It was developed significantly during the Soviet Union period due to Burshtyn Coal Power Station. The city has an old Roman Catholic Church in the center of the city.

[[Anatoliy Kinakh]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, Living people, Prime Ministers of Ukraine, Economists

Anatoliy Kyrylovych Kinakh (Анатолій Кирилович Кінах; born 4 August 1954) is a Ukrainian politician. He is the leader of Party of Industrialists and Entrepreneurs of Ukraine.

Kinakh is most known for holding the Prime Minister of Ukraine office under the President Leonid Kuchma from 2001 to 2002. He was also the first Vice Prime Minister and a Minister of Economy of Ukraine.

[[Guangdong frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Asia, Frogs

The Guangdong frog, brown grasspound frog, three-striped grass frog, long-toed frog, marbled slender frog, long-toed slender frog or stripe-backed frog (Hylarana macrodactyla) is a frog from China, Myanmar , Laos, Cambodia, Vietnam and Malaysia.

This frog lives in tropical and subtropical forests that are not too wet and in some grasslands

The name "macrodactyla" means "with big fingers," or "long-toed."

[[1962 Atlantic hurricane season]]

CATEGORIES: Atlantic hurricane seasons, 1962

The 1962 Atlantic hurricane season was not very active. It was the least active hurricane season since 1939, as there were only five named storms. It started on June 15, 1962, but the first storm was not until August 26. 

[[Battle of Lepanto]]

CATEGORIES: Battles involving Greece

The battle of Lepanto (in Italian Battaglia gave Lepanto; in Turkish: İnebahtı deniz muharebesi 'naval battle of İnebahtı') was a naval fight that took place on 7 October 1571 near of the Greek city of Náfpaktos (Lepanto in Italian).

They confronted  in her the armed of Imperio otomano against the one of a Catholic coalition, called Saint League, formed by the Spanish Empire, the States Pontificios, the Republic of Venecia, the Order of Malta, the Republic of Génova and the Duchy of Saboya.

In this battle participated Miguel de Cervantes, that resulted injured and lost the mobility of his left hand, what cost him the nickname of «manco of Lepanto». This writer, that was very proud to having combated there, described it like «the more memorable and high occasion that saw the past centuries, neither expect to see the coming». Also it entered the history in the Quijote, through the #narration of the captive, as typical work of literature of border.

[[Race (anthropology)]]

The definition of race by Merriam-Webster is any one of the groups that humans are often divided into based on physical traits regarded as common among people of shared ancestry. The field of anthropology has largely been based off of examining racial differences. Despite centuries of scientific racism, the biological concept of race has been debunked.

The Web is a 1947 American crime thriller movie directed by Michael Gordon and starring Ella Raines, Edmond O'Brien, William Bendix, Vincent Price, Maria Palmer, Howland Chamberlain. It was distributed by Universal Pictures.

[[Borders of Israel]]

CATEGORIES: Geography of Israel

The state of Israel has borders with four countries: Lebanon in the north, Egypt (and Gaza) in the southwest, Jordan (and the West Bank) in the east, and Syria in the northeast. Israel also has "sea borders" in the Red Sea, the Dead Sea and the Mediterranean Sea. The current borders Israel are the result of war, diplomatic agreements between Israel and its neighbors, and colonial powers from before its creation.

Some borders are internationally recognized while others are not accepted by all countries. The borders with Lebanon, Syria and Jordan are based on those drawn by the United Kingdom and France in 1923. The border with Egypt is the international border determined in 1906 between United Kingdom and the Ottoman Empire. Israel's borders with Egypt and Jordan have been formally recognized as part official peace treaties between the countries. On the other hand, the borders with Syria and Palestinian National Authority are still in dispute between the sides involved. The Golan Heights area is at the heart of the dispute between Israel and Syria on their common border. There is agreement between Israel and Lebanon on their border, with the exception of a small area of known as the "Shebaa Farms" which Israel took over during a war. Since the 1990s, Israel and the Palestinian Authority have been negotiating a border between them as well.

[[Happy Joe's]]

CATEGORIES: American food companies, 1972 establishments in the United States

Happy Joe's Pizza & Ice Cream Parlor is an American pizza parlor chain based in Bettendorf, Iowa. The restaurant chain was founded in 1972 by Lawrence Joseph "Happy Joe" Whitty. He was a former Shakey's Pizza manager.

Happy Joe's has 61 restaurants in North Dakota, Missouri, Minnesota, Wisconsin, Iowa and Illinois.

[[Indoor cricket]]

CATEGORIES: Cricket

Indoor cricket is a form of cricket that is played in an indoors area much smaller than a regular cricket field. There are multiple versions of indoor cricket, and games can be played with different time lengths. 

[[Cynthia Ozick]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, American novelists, American short story writers, Writers from New York City, Living people

Cynthia S. Ozick (born April 17, 1928) is an American novelist, short story writer and essayist. She mostly writes fiction. However, she also writes literary criticism, politics and history.

Ozick received an Edward Lewis Wallant Award and the National Jewish Book Award for her short story collection, The Pagan Rabbi and Other Stories in 1971. She received the National Jewish Book Award for Fiction in 1977 for her book Bloodshed and Three Novellas.

Ozick was selected as the winner of a Rea Award for the Short Story in 1986.

The novelist David Foster Wallace called Ozick one of the greatest living American writers. 

[[26th century]]

CATEGORIES: 3rd millennium, Centuries

The 26th century will begin on January 1, 2501 and will end on December 31, 2600.

[[Bandō prisoner of war camp]]

CATEGORIES: History of Japan, World War I

Bandō prisoner of war camp was a prisoner of war camp that existed from 1917 to 1920, during and shortly after the First World War. It was located in the city with the same name. It housed about 1000 of the 3900 prisoners of war captured at Tsingtao, China, in 1914. Today, the camp is considered special, because of the liberal rules it had. Many of the prisoners were not professional soldiers, but had other jobs before the war. The commander of the camp, Matsue Toyohisa, saw this, and allowed the prisoners many liberties. One of these liberties was that they were allowed to follow courses to improve their skills. That way, Hermann Richard Hansen directed a choir and an orchestra of prisoners, to perform Beethoven's 9th symphony. This was the first performance of the symphony in Japan and in Asia. When the camp closed in 1920, 63 people chose to stay in Japan.

[[MOD (Marehan, Ogaden, Darawiish)]]

CATEGORIES: 1970s establishments in Africa, 1989 disestablishments, Somalia

MOD in Somali politics stands for Marehan, Ogaden, Darawiish. It is an acronym to describe the political alliance between the Marehan, Ogaden and reer Darawiish tribes. The political alliance between MOD (Marehan, Ogaden, Darawiish) started in the 1980s in the Hantiwadaag era. The political coalition of MOD ended in 1989 with the Somali Civil War. The political alliance between Marehan, Ogaden and Darawiish was led by president Siad Barre.

[[Tartib al-Musnad]]

CATEGORIES: Ibadism

Tartib al-Musnad is the hadith collection used by people who follow the Ibadism sect.

[[Anatomical terms of location]]

CATEGORIES: Human body features, Animal anatomy

Anatomical terms of location have been developed. They help describe the anatomy of animals (including humans). They describe standard positions on an animal. They use Latin and Greek words.

[[SOS Fairy Manu]]

CATEGORIES: 2015 television series debuts, Children's television series, Brazilian television series

SOS Fairy Manu (Spanish: SOS Hada Manu kouion as Ffiguiner: SOS Guione Muin)  is a Brazilian cartoon produced by TeamTO, Boutique Filmes and Lightstar Studios in co-production with Cartoon Network, Nickelodeon and Cake Entertainment  in association with Disney Channel, Rede Globo 2007 and TV Cultura with the participation of francetélévisions. It is shown by the paid channel Gloob from July 13, 2014 from Monday to Friday at 4:30 am, 8:45 am and 11:45 am, with 26 episodes of 11 minutes each in its first season. The second season premiered on November 7, 2016, also with 26 episodes. On TV Brasil, the series is shown from Monday to Friday, at 2:30 pm, and on Saturdays and Sundays. 

The series was nominated for an Emmy Kids Award in 2016.

[[Decision stream graph]]

Decision stream is a directed acyclic graph of decision rules for classification and regression tasks (Fig. 1). This decision tree based method avoids the problem of data exhaustion in terminal nodes by merging of leaves from the same/different levels of predictive model. 

Decision stream provides:

– High accuracy due to the precise splitting of data with unpaired two-sample test statistics.

– Decrease of overfitting due to partition of data only into statistically representative groups.

– Reduction of complexity on every level of predictive model.

– Self-regulated depth of predictive model.

[[Nina Ivanova]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Russian movie actors, Russian television actors, Russian stage actors, Actors from Moscow

Nina Ivanova (6 January 1934 – 1 December 2020) was a Russian-Soviet actress. She was born in Moscow. Ivanova's career began in 1944. Her best known roles were in Once There Was a Girl (1944), Spring on Zarechnaya Street (1956), An Easy Life (1964) and There Is Such a Lad (1964).

Ivanova died on 1 December 2020 in Moscow at the age of 86.

[[Mickaël Bethe-Selassié]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, 2020 deaths, Ethiopian people, Sculptors

Mickaël Bethe-Selassié (1951 – 5 December 2020) was an Ethiopian sculptor. He was known for his work in papier mâché. Many of his works were seen at the National Museum of African Art in Washington, D.C..

Bethe-Selassié died on 5 December 2020 in Washington, D.C. at the age of 69.

[[Marilyn Lewis]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, US Republican Party politicians

Marilyn Stoughton Lewis (July 19, 1931 – December 7, 2020) was an American politician. She was a Republican member of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives from 1979 to 1982. Lewis was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

She was married to Andrew L. Lewis Jr..

Lewis died on December 7, 2020, in Lansdale, Pennsylvania at age 89.

[[Wallace Barnes]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Connecticut, Businesspeople from Connecticut, US Republican Party politicians

Wallace Barnes (March 22, 1926 – December 10, 2020) was an American businessman and politician. He was born in Bristol, Connecticut. Barnes was a member of the Republican Party. He was a member of the Connecticut Senate from 1959 to 1971.

Barnes died in Washington, D.C. on December 10, 2020 at the age of 94.

[[Rafael Ramón Conde Alfonzo]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from pancreatic cancer, Roman Catholic priests, Roman Catholic bishops, People from Caracas

Rafael Ramón Conde Alfonzo (13 July 1943 – December 10, 2020) was a Venezuelan Roman Catholic bishop. Conde Alfonzo was born in Caracas. He became a priest in 1968. He was titular bishop of Bapara and as auxiliary bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Caracas from 1995 to 1997.

He was bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of La Guaira from 1997 to 1999. He then became bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Margarita from 1999 to 2008 and as bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Maracay from 2008 to 2009.

Conde Alfonzo died at the age of 77 on 10 December 2020 from pancreatic cancer in Maracay.

[[Maracay]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Venezuela

Maracay (maɾaˈkaj) is a city in north-central Venezuela. It is the capital of the state of Aragua. About 955,362 people lived here in 2011.

[[Andrzej Skowroński]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2020 deaths, Polish Olympians, People from Kraków

Andrzej Skowroński (16 November 1953 – 10 December 2020) was a Polish rower. He competed in the men's quadruple sculls event at the 1980 Summer Olympics. He was born in Kraków, Poland.

Skowroński died on 10 December 2020 in Kraków at the age of 67.

[[Per Carlsen (diplomat)]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Danish politicians, Ambassadors to Russia, People from Copenhagen

Per Carlsen (1948 – December 2020) was a Danish politician. He was the Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of the Kingdom of Denmark to Latvia from 2010 through 2015. Before 2010 he was the Danish ambassador to the Russian Federation.

Carlsen died in December 2020 in Copenhagen at the age of 72.

[[Luis de Góngora]]

Luis of Góngora and Argote (Córdoba, 11 July 1561-ib., 23 May 1627) it was a poet and Spanish dramatist of the Century of Gold, maximum exponent of the literary current known later, and with simplification perpetuated during centuries, like culteranismo or gongorismo, whose work will be imitated along the centuries in Europe and America. As if it treated of a classical Latin, his works were object of #exegesis already in his same period

[[Hydrophobe]]

CATEGORIES: Chemistry

Hydrophobe is a term from chemistry for a substance that does not mix with water. Examples of such substances are different types of vegetable oils, and fats. Many hydrophobic substances are lipophiles, they  mix with fats and oils easily.

[[Ann Reinking]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2020 deaths, American movie actors, American stage actors, American television actors, American dancers, American choreographers, Tony Award winners, Actors from Seattle, Washington

Ann Reinking (November 10, 1949 – December 12, 2020) was an American actress, dancer, and choreographer. Reinking was born in Seattle, Washington.

Reinking acted in Coco (1969), Over Here! (1974), Goodtime Charley (1975), Chicago (1977), Dancin' (1978) and Sweet Charity (1986). She won a Tony Award for Best Choreography in 1996. 

For the 2000 West End production of Fosse, she won the Olivier Award for Best Theatre Choreographer. 

She was in the movies All That Jazz (1979), Annie (1982), and Micki & Maude (1984).

Reinking died on December 12, 2020 in Seattle at the age of 71.

[[Robert Bloxom]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Baltimore, Maryland, Politicians from Virginia, US Republican Party politicians

Robert Spurgeon Bloxom Sr. (April 26, 1937 – December 13, 2020) was an American Republican politician. He was a member of the Virginia House of Delegates from 1978 to 2004. Bloxom was the State Secretary of Agriculture and Forestry from 2005 to 2010. Bloxom was born in Baltimore, Maryland.

Bloxom died on December 13, 2020 in Mappsville, Virginia at the age of 83.

[[Mappsville, Virginia]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in Virginia

Mappsville is a census-designated place (CDP) in Accomack County, Virginia, United States. About 440 people lived here since the 2010 Census.

[[Jorge Bruni]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Uruguayan politicians

Jorge Bruni (1941 – 13 December 2020) was an Uruguayan politician. He was the Minister of the Interior from 2009 to 2010 during the Tabaré Vázquez presidency. He was a member of the Broad Front Party.

Bruni died on 13 December 2020 in Montevideo at the age of 79.

[[Barry Sonshine]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Canadian Olympians, Sportspeople from Toronto, Equestrians

Barry Sonshine (1 February 1948 – 13 December 2020) was a Canadian equestrian. He competed in two events at the 1968 Summer Olympics. Sonshine was born in Toronto. 

Sonshine died in Toronto on 13 December 2020 at the age of 72.

[[Antihistamine]]

CATEGORIES: Drugs

Antihistamines are drugs which treat allergic rhinitis and other allergies.  

Usually people take antihistamines as an over-the-counter drug , with few side effects. It is for relief from nasal congestion, sneezing, or hives. These symptoms may be  caused by pollen, dust mites, or allergy to animals. 

Antihistamines are usually for short-term treatment. Chronic allergies increase the risk of health problems which antihistamines might not treat, including asthma, sinusitis, and respiratory tract infections near the lungs. Consultation of a medical professional is recommended for those who intend to take antihistamines for longer-term use.

Although people use the word “antihistamine” to describe drugs for treating allergies, doctors and scientists use the term to describe a class of drug that opposes the activity of histamine receptors in the body. In this sense of the word, antihistamines are subclassified according to which histamine receptor they act upon.

[[Herman Asaribab]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, 2020 deaths, Indonesian people, Generals

Herman Asaribab (10 June 1964 – 14 December 2020) was an Indonesian Papuan military officer. He was the Commander of the 17th Military Regional Command/Cenderawasih from August 2019 to November 2020. Asaribab was born in Jayapura, West Irian. 

Asaribab died on 14 December 2020 in Jakarta at the age of 56.

[[Mamye BaCote]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Virginia, US Democratic Party politicians

Mamye Edmondson BaCote (February 18, 1939 – December 14, 2020) was an American politician. She was a member of the Democratic Party. She was a member of the Virginia House of Delegates, representing the 95th District from 2004 to 2016. BaCote was born in Halifax, Virginia.

BaCote died on December 14, 2020 in Newport News, Virginia at the age of 81.

[[Eric Freeman (cricketer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Australian cricketers, Sportspeople from South Australia

Eric "Fritzy" Freeman AUS(13 July 1944 – 14 December 2020) was an Australian cricketer. He played in 11 Tests from 1968 to 1970. He was also a leading Australian rules footballer with Port Adelaide Football Club, playing 116 games between 1964 and 1972. Freeman was born in Semaphore, South Australia.

Freeman died on 14 December 2020 from a heart attack at the age of 76.

[[Roddam Narasimha]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cerebral hemorrhage, Indian scientists

Roddam Narasimha (20 July 1933 – 14 December 2020) was an Indian aerospace scientist and fluid dynamicist. He was a Professor of Aerospace Engineering at the Indian Institute of Science (IISc) from 1962 to 1999. He was Director of the National Aerospace Laboratories (NAL) from 1984 to 1993 and the Chairman of the Engineering Mechanics Unit at Jawaharlal Nehru Centre for Advanced Scientific Research from 2000 to 2014.

Narasimha died of a cerebral hemorrhage on 14 December 2020 in Bangalore, Karnataka at the age of 87.

[[Marcelo Veiga]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil, Brazilian footballers, Brazilian football managers, People from São Paulo

Marcelo Castelo Veiga (7 October 1964 – 14 December 2020), commonly known as Marcelo Veiga, was a Brazilian professional football manager and player. He played for Santos, Internacional, Goiás, Bahia and Portuguesa.

He managed Bragantino. He was born in São Paulo, Brazil.

Veiga died on 14 December 2020, aged 56 in Bragança Paulista, from COVID-19.

[[Ungku Abdul Aziz]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2020 deaths, Malaysian people, Educators, Economists, Scientists from London

Ungku Abdul Aziz bin Ungku Abdul Hamid (28 January 1922 – 15 December 2020) was an English-born Malaysian economist. He was the First General Director of the Council on Language and Literature of Malaysia from 1956 to 1957. Aziz was the former Vice-Chancellor of the University of Malaya from 1968 to 1988. He was born in London.

Aziz died on 15 December 2020 in Kuala Lumpur at the age of 98.

[[Deserts of Australia]]

CATEGORIES: Australia, Climate

The deserts of Australia cover 1371000, or 18% of the Australian mainland. 

However, about 35% of Australia gets so little rain it is actually a desert. The deserts in Australia are mainly in the western plateau and interior lowlands of the country.

By international standards, Australian deserts receive relatively high rates of rainfall. They are not necessarily devoid of vegetation: they have large areas where vegetation is very limited in height or extent.

Rainfall is mainly in the North and East of the country (especially the Daintree Rainforest), with some in the southern area. Almost all rain falls on the edges of the huge island, not in the centre.

[[Milomir Odović]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2020 deaths, Bosnia and Herzegovina footballers, Bosnia and Herzegovina football managers, Deaths from cancer

Milomir Odović "Oda" (26 March 1955 – 14 December 2020) was a Bosnian professional football manager and player. He was known for playing and managing Bosnian Premier League club Željezničar.

Odović died on 14 December 2020 in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, two years after being diagnosed with cancer at the age of 65.

[[Zoltan Sabo]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 births, 2020 deaths, Serbian footballers, Hungarian footballers, Serbian football managers, Hungarian football managers, Deaths from pulmonary embolism

Zoltan Sabo (Золтан Сабо, Szabó Zoltán; 26 May 1972 — 15 December 2020) was a Serbian professional footballer. He played as a defender. He also held Hungarian citizenship. 

Sabo played for Hajduk Kula, Vojvodina, and Partizan. Sabo began his managerial career at the helm of his hometown club Radnički Sombor in October 2009.

Sabo died on 15 December 2020 in Sremska Kamenica, Serbia from pulmonary embolism-related problems at the age of 48.

[[Roupa Nova]]

CATEGORIES: Brazilian musicians

Roupa Nova  (lit. "New Clothes") is a Brazilian soft rock band. They had many hits in the 1980s and early 1990s. They are often compared American band Toto.

The band was formed in 1970, under the name Os Famks. 

[[Department of Health and Social Care]]
