The Department of Health and Social Care is a department of the British Government. It is responsible for the health of people in the United Kingdom, mostly via the National Health Services. Its head is known as the Health Secretary.

[[Valkyrae]]

CATEGORIES: 1992 births, Living people, American YouTubers, Entertainers from Washington, Twitch (service) streamers

Rachell Hofstetter (born January 8, 1992) is an American YouTuber and live streamer. SHe uses the online name Valkyrae, She was born in Washington. 

She began a gaming channel on Instagram and later moved to Twitch. She is the first female gamer and content creator for 100 Thieves. She supports female gamers. 

On January 13, 2020, Valkyrae left Twitch for YouTube.

[[Corpse Husband]]

CATEGORIES: 1997 births, Living people, American YouTubers, Twitch (service) streamers, Singers from San Diego, California, American rap musicians from California, American TikTokers

Corpse Husband, also known as Corpse, (born August 8, 1997) is an American internet personality and musician. He creates his work on YouTube where he does not show his face but only records his voice. He makes horror story narrations and Let's Play content. He has become well known for streaming his Among Us on YouTube.

In October 2020, he worked with U.S. representatives Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Ilhan Omar along with several other streamers including Disguised Toast, HasanAbi, Pokimane, and Valkyrae for a session of Among Us as part of a get-out-the-vote motivation movement for the 2020 United States presidential election. 

[[Fargo (season 1)]]

CATEGORIES: 2014 television seasons

The first season of the anthology black comedy–crime drama television series Fargo. Its first episode was released on April 15, 2014, on FX. This season stars Billy Bob Thornton, Allison Tolman, Colin Hanks and Martin Freeman.

CATEGORIES: 2015 in television, 2010s television seasons

The second season of Fargo, an American anthology black comedy–crime drama television series created by Noah Hawley. It premiered on October 12, 2015 on FX. The ten-episode season's finale aired on December 14, 2015. 

[[Lipophile]]

CATEGORIES: Chemicals

A lipophile is a chemical substance that mixes easily with vegetable oil and fat. An example of such a substance is petroleum. Many lipophiles are also hydrophobes.

[[Fargo (season 3)]]

CATEGORIES: 2017 television seasons

The third season of Fargo, an American anthology dark comedy–crime drama television series created by Noah Hawley. It premiered on April 19, 2017, on FX. The season had ten episodes. The season ended on June 21, 2017.

[[Fargo (season 4)]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 television seasons

The fourth season of Fargo, an American anthology black comedy–crime drama television series created by Noah Hawley. It premiered on September 27, 2020, on FX and ended on November 29, 2020. It has about 11 episodes. 

The fourth season is set in 1950 in Kansas City. It shows the crime war between to mafia organizations. Chris Rock plays Loy Cannon, the head of a crime mafia made up of black criminals trying to escape from the Jim Crow South.

The season was originally scheduled to premiere on April 19, 2020, but it was pushed back because of the COVID-19 pandemic.

It has a 81% approval from Rotten Tomatoes, and is the lowest rated season from the entire Fargo series.

[[Eden Valley, Minnesota]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Minnesota

Eden Valley is a city in Meeker and Stearns counties in the U.S. state of Minnesota. About 1,042 lived here since the 2010 census.

Luverne (l) is a city in Rock County, Minnesota, United States. About 4,745 lived here since the 2010 census. It is the county seat.

Noah Hawley (born 1967) is an American television writer and producer, screenwriter, and bestselling author. He created and wrote the FX television series Fargo (2014–present) and Legion (2017–2019). 

[[Kathrine Narducci]]

CATEGORIES: 1965 births, Living people, Actors from New York City, American television actors, American movie actors

Kathrine Narducci (born November 22, 1965) is an American actress. She is known for her role as Charmaine Bucco, Artie Bucco's wife, in the HBO crime drama series The Sopranos (1999–2007). Her movie credits include A Bronx Tale (1993), Chicago Overcoat (2009), Jersey Boys (2014), The Wizard of Lies (2017), Bad Education (2019), The Irishman (2019) and Capone (2020).

Narducci was born to an Italian-American family in East Harlem, New York City.  Her father, Nicky Narducci, was a bar owner and organized crime figure in East Harlem. He was killed in a Mafia-related murder when Kathrine was ten years old.

[[Virgin Orbit]]

CATEGORIES: Private spaceflight

Virgin Orbit is a company in the Virgin Group that will provide a for small satellites to be put into space. The company was made in 2017 to create the LauncherOne rocket, which would be launched from an airplane. 

They currently have have made one try to go to space on May 25, 2020, which did not work. They will try again no earlier than December 19, 2020

[[Great Bitter Lake]]

CATEGORIES: Coordinates on Wikidata, Lakes of Africa, Geography of Egypt

The Great Bitter Lake (البحيرة المرة الكبرى; transliterated: al-Buhayrah al-Murra al-Kubra) is a saltwater lake in Egypt. Today, it is part of the  Suez Canal, which connects it to the Mediterranean and the Red Sea. It is connected to the Small Bitter Lake (Arabic: البحيرة المرة الصغرى; transliterated: al-Buhayrah al-Murra as-Sughra), through which the canal also runs. Before the canal was built (1869), the site was a dry salt valley or basin. Even the ancient  Pyramid Texts mention it. Ships traveling through the Suez Canal use the Great Bitter Lake as a "passing lane", where they can change their position in line or turn around.

[[Pyramid Texts]]

CATEGORIES: Ancient Egypt, Religious texts

Pyramid Texts is the name for several religious texts, found on the wall of several pyramids of the 5th and 6th and 8th dynasties. They are the biggest corpus of Ancient Egyptian texts.

[[Ilinden–Preobrazhenie Uprising]]

CATEGORIES: 1903, 1900s in Europe, History of Bulgaria, Ottoman Empire

The Ilinden–Preobrazhenie Uprising was an uprising by mostly Bulgarian and some of the Aromanian population in certain regions in the Ottoman Empire. The uprising was against Ottoman rule.

The uprising lasted from 2 August 1903 up to November 1903. 

The name of the uprising comes from the Christian Orthodox holy day of Ilinden as well as another holy day known as Preobrazhenie on which the revolts began. 

Ultimately the uprising was crushed by the better equipped and much larger Ottoman army. The casualties were on both sides were small however a large number of people were made homeless, the majority of which number around 30,000 fled to Bulgaria.

[[Seychellois Creole]]

CATEGORIES: Languages of Africa, Seychelles

Seychellois Creole is the main language spoken in the country of the Seychelles. It is a type of creole language.

[[The Mod Squad]]

The Mod Squad is an American crime drama series, originally broadcast for five seasons on ABC from September 24, 1968, to March 1, 1973. 

[[Ministry of Defence]]

CATEGORIES: Ministries

The Ministry of Defence or Defense (see spelling differences), may also be known as a Department of Defence or Defense. This is the name for the part of government responsible for matters of defence.

These departments are found in states where the government is divided into ministries or departments. The department usually includes all branches of the military, and is usually controlled by a Defence Minister, Minister of Defence, or Secretary of Defense. The department is often referred to by the initials MoD (UK) or DoD (USA).

[[The Gay Divorcee]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 movies, 1930s musical movies, American musical movies, Movies based on musicals, Movies directed by Mark Sandrich

The Gay Divorcee is a 1934 American musical movie directed by Mark Sandrich and was based on the 1932 musical of the same name by Dwight Taylor. It stars Fred Astaire, Ginger Rogers, Alice Brady, Edward Everett Horton, Eric Blore, Erik Rhodes, Betty Grable and was distributed by RKO Radio Pictures. It was nominated for 5 Oscars and won an Academy Award in 1935.

The Eastern Conference is one of Major League Soccer's two conferences. The other is the Western Conference.

[[The Champ (1979 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 drama movies, American drama movies, Movie remakes, Movies directed by Franco Zeffirelli

The Champ is a 1979 American drama movie directed by Franco Zeffirelli and is the remake of the 1931 movie of the same name. It stars Jon Voight, Ricky Schroder, Faye Dunaway, Jack Warden, Joan Blondell, Strother Martin and was distributed by United Artists. It was nominated for an Academy Award in 1980.

[[Common green frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Asia, Frogs

The common green frog, leaf frog red-eared frog, golden-lined frog, green paddy frog, common greenback, green lotus frog, or greenbacked frog (Hylarana erythraea) is a frog from Laos, Cambodia, Indonesia, Borneo, Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand, Myanmar, Vietnam, and India.  It also lives in the Philippines and Sulawesi because human beings brought it there.  This frog can live as high in the hills as 1200 meters above sea level.

The adult female frog is 7.8 cm long and the adult male frog is 4.8 cm long.  They can be light green or dark green with a lighter belly.  Some of the frogs are blue.

[[Huw Irranca-Davies]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, Living people, Former Labour MPs (UK), Members of the British House of Commons for Welsh constituencies, Politicians from Swansea, UK MPs 2001–2005, UK MPs 2005–2010, UK MPs 2010–2015, UK MPs 2015–2017, Welsh politicians

Ifor Huw Irranca-Davies (ne Davies; born 22 January 1963) is a Welsh Labour and Co-operative politician. He has been the Member of the Senedd for Ogmore since 2016. He was also the Member of Parliament (MP) for Ogmore from 2002 to 2016.

Irranca-Davies was born in Gowerton, Swansea. He was named after his step great-uncle, Ifor Davies, also a Welsh Labour politician. On marriage, he and wife Joanna Irranca both changed their surnames to Irranca-Davies.

[[The Son Also Draws]]

CATEGORIES: Family Guy (season 1) episodes, 1999 television episodes

"The Son Also Draws" is the 6th episode of the first season of Family Guy. It originally aired on Fox in the United States on May 9, 1999. The episode is about Chris getting kicked out of the Boy Scouts (the episode calls it "Youth Scouts"). Peter drives the family to Scout headquarters to get Chris back in. During a rest stop at a Native American casino, Lois gambles away the family car. Peter pretends to be a member of the tribe in an attempt to get the car back, and is sent on a vision quest to prove his heritage, giving him and Chris an opportunity to bond.

[[The Treasure of the Sierra Madre]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 movies, 1940s adventure movies, 1940s drama movies, American adventure movies, American drama movies, Mexican movies, Movies based on books, Warner Bros. movies, Movies directed by John Huston

The Treasure of the Sierra Madre is a 1948 American Mexican adventure drama movie directed by John Huston and was based on the 1927 novel of the same name by B. Traven. It stars Humphrey Bogart, Walter Huston, Tim Holt, Bruce Bennett, Barton MacLane, Alfonso Bedoya and was distributed by Warner Bros. Pictures. It was nominated for 4 Oscars and won 3 Academy Awards in 1949.

[[The Bribe]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 movies, 1940s crime movies, 1940s drama movies, American crime drama movies, Movies based on short stories, Movies directed by Robert Z. Leonard, Movies directed by Vincente Minnelli

The Bribe is a 1949 American crime drama movie directed by Robert Z. Leonard and Vincente Minnelli and was based on the 1947 short story of the same name by Frederick Nebel. It stars Robert Taylor, Ava Gardner, Charles Laughton, John Hodiak and was distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

[[Metro Trains Melbourne]]

CATEGORIES: 2009 establishments in Australia, Companies of Australia, Rail transport in Australia, Transport in Melbourne

Metro Trains Melbourne is the branding name of the operator of the train system in Melbourne, Victoria, Australia. They have been operating the network since 2009.

[[The Lost Patrol (1934 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 movies, 1930s war movies, American war movies, Movies based on books, World War I movies, Movies directed by John Ford

The Lost Patrol is a 1934 American World War I movie directed by John Ford and is the second adaption of the 1927 novel Patrol by Philip MacDonald. It stars Victor McLaglen, Boris Karloff, Wallace Ford, Reginald Denny, Alan Hale Sr., Billy Bevan, Brandon Hurst and was distributed by RKO Radio Pictures. It was nominated for an Academy Award in 1935.

[[Jean Cottard]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, Fencers, Sportspeople from Paris

Jean Cottard (14 July 1926 – 1 December 2020) was a French fencer. He earned his Master of Arms at Fort Carré in 1949. He became the first National Technical Director of France in 1964. He was a member of the French Federation of Fencing from 1988 until his death. Cottard was born in Paris.

Cottard died on 1 December 2020 in Antibes, France at the age of 94.

[[Bernard Vogler]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, French historians

Bernard Vogler (30 April 1935 – 2 December 2020) was a French academic and historian. He was a professor at the University of Strasbourg. He  was a specialist in the History of Alsace from the 15th to the 20th Centuries. Vogler was born in Obermodern-Zutzendorf, France.

Vogler was a member of the Comité des travaux historiques et scientifiques from 1989 to 2000 and was Vice-President of the International Commission for Comparative Ecclesiastical History from 1975 to 2001. He was President of the University of the Third Age from 2004 to 2008.

Vogler died on 2 December 2020 in Strasbourg, France at the age of 85.

[[Kaj Ikast]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Danish politicians

Kaj Ikast (22 December 1935 – 3 December 2020) was a Danish Conservative politician. He was a member of the Folketing from 1985 to 2005 and was the Minister of Transport from 1990 to 1993.

Ikast died on 3 December 2020 at the age of 84.

[[Adil Ismayilov]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic, Azerbaijani people, Lawyers

Adil Alviz oglu Ismayilov (Adil Əlviz oğlu İsmayılov; 5 July 1957 – 3 December 2020) was an Azerbaijani lawyer, jurist and investigator. He was a member of the Azerbaijani Bar Association. Ismayilov was part of the most well-known trials in Azerbaijan during the 1990s and 2000s. He was born in Goychay, Soviet Union.

Ismayilov died on 3 December 2020 from COVID-19 in Baku, Azerbaijan at the age of 63.

[[Gérard Gourgue]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2020 deaths, Haitian people, Politicians

Gérard Gourgue (1 December 1925 – 4 December 2020) was a Haitian politician and human rights activist. He ran for President in 1988. He was born in Port-au-Prince. He was a member of the Haitian National Council of Government from February 1986 to March 1986.

Gourgue died on 4 December 2020 in Port-au-Prince at the age of 95.

[[Pierre Bernard (Tarn politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, French mayors

Pierre Bernard (6 June 1934 – 5 December 2020) was a French politician. He was born in Alban, France. He was a member of the Socialist Party. He was Mayor of Trébas from 1970 to 2001. From 1980 to 1993, he was a member of the National Assembly.

Bernard died on 5 December 2020 in Trébas at the age of 86.

Trébas is a commune in the Tarn department and Occitanie region of southern France.

Alban is a commune of the Tarn department in southern France.

[[Phyllis Eisenstein]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, Deaths from stroke, American novelists, American editors, Writers from Chicago, Cardiovascular disease deaths in Chicago, Infectious disease deaths in Chicago

Phyllis Eisenstein (February 26, 1946 – December 7, 2020) was an American author of science fiction and fantasy short stories and novels. She was nominated for both the Hugo Award and Nebula Award. Eisenstein was born in Chicago. Her best known works were Born to Exile (1977), Sorcerer's Son (1979) and The Crystal Palace (1988).

Eisenstein died on December 7, 2020 in Chicago from COVID-19 and a stroke at the age of 74.

[[Jimmy McLane]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, American swimmers, American Olympic gold medalists, American Olympic silver medalists, Sportspeople from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania

James Price McLane Jr. (September 13, 1930 – December 13, 2020) was an American competition swimmer. He was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. McLane won two golds and a silver medal at the 1948 Summer Olympics and one gold medal at the 1952 Summer Olympics. 

McLane died at his home in Ipswich, Massachusetts on December 13, 2020, at the age of 90.

[[Paul Wass]]

Paul Wass (July 7, 1925 – December 13, 2020) was an American Republican politician. He was a member of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives from 1977 to 1990. Wass was born in Young Township, Pennsylvania. 

Wass died on December 13, 2020 in Indiana, Pennsylvania at the age of 95.

[[Young Township, Indiana County, Pennsylvania]]

CATEGORIES: Townships in Pennsylvania

Young Township is a township in Indiana County, Pennsylvania, United States. About 1,775 people as of the 2010 census. 

[[Florida's 1st congressional district]]

CATEGORIES: Government of Florida

Florida's 1st congressional district is a congressional district in the U.S. state of Florida. It is in the state's western Panhandle. It includes all of Escambia, Okaloosa, Santa Rosa, and Walton counties and portions of Holmes county. 

The district is currently represented by Republican Matt Gaetz.

[[Paulo César dos Santos]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from multiple organ failure, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil, Brazilian singers, Brazilian musicians, Deaths from cardiopulmonary arrest

Paulo César dos Santos (September 6, 1952 – December 14, 2020), better known as Paulinho, was a Brazilian singer and percussionist. He was a member of the group Roupa Nova. He was born in Rio de Janeiro.

Paulinho died at the age of 68, from multiple organ failure and cardiopulmonary arrest caused by COVID-19 in Rio de Janeiro.

[[Colic]]

CATEGORIES: Diseases

Colic is a form of pain that starts and stops quickly and out of nowhere. It happens because muscular contractions of a hollow tube (colon, gall bladder, ureter, etc.). This is done to remove an obstruction by forcing content out. It may cause sweating and vomiting. 

[[Totilas]]

CATEGORIES: Individual animals, Racehorses

Totilas (May 23, 2000 – December 14, 2020), also known from 2006 to 2011 as Moorlands Totilas, and nicknamed "Toto", was a Dutch Warmblood stallion. Totilas was thought to be one of the most outstanding competitive dressage horses in the world. Totilas was retired from competition in August 2015.

Totilas died of colic on December 14, 2020 at the age of 20.

[[Seppo Vainio]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Finnish Olympians, Finnish ice hockey players

Seppo Vainio (3 January 1937 – 14 December 2020) was a Finnish ice hockey player. He competed in the men's tournament at the 1960 Winter Olympics. He was born in Helsinki.

Vainio died on 14 December 2020 in Rauma, Finland at the age of 83.

[[Sudhir Chakraborty]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Indian scientists, Indian writers, Indian educators, Asian anthropologists

Sudhir Chakravarti (19 September 1934 – 15 December 2020) was a Indian anthropologist and essayist. He was born in Shibpur, British India.

Chakravarti was known for his research works on Folk religion, Lalan Fakir and Cultural Anthropology in Bengal. He spent 30 years researching the folk culture by traveling to different villages all over the West Bengal. 

He was a professor of Bengali literature from 1958 to 1994. Chakravarti worked in Krishnagar Government College. He wrote and edited more than 85 books on many subjects like music, art, folk-religion, cultural anthropology. He was the editor of Bengali literary Magazine Dhrubapada.

Chakraborty died on 15 December 2020 in Kolkata, India from a heart attack at the age of 86.

[[Donald Fowler]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, American political scientists, Deaths from leukemia, People from Spartanburg, South Carolina, Politicians from South Carolina, US Democratic Party politicians

Donald L. Fowler (September 12, 1935 – December 15, 2020) was an American political scientist. He was National Chair of the Democratic National Committee from 1995 to 1997. He was born in Spartanburg, South Carolina. From 1971 to 1980, he was Chair of the South Carolina Democratic Party. 

Fowler died on December 15, 2020 from leukemia in Columbia, South Carolina at the age of 85.

[[Bruce Seals]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2020 deaths, Seattle SuperSonics players, Sportspeople from Boston, Massachusetts

Bruce A. Seals (June 18, 1953 – December 15, 2020) was an American basketball player. He was born in New Orleans, Louisiana. His career lasted from 1973 to 1984. Seals played for the Utah Stars, Seattle SuperSonics, Pallacanestro Varese and for Reyer Venezia. 

Seals died on December 15, 2020 in Boston, Massachusetts at the age of 67.

[[Petro Slobodyan]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2020 deaths, Soviet sportspeople, Ukrainian footballers, Ukrainian football managers

Petro Petrovych Slobodyan (Петро Петрович Слободян, Пётр Петрович Слободян; 2 July 1953 – 15 December 2020) was a Soviet-Ukrainian football player and manager. He was born in Sheparivtsi, Kolomyia Raion. He made two appearances for the Soviet Union national football team in 1976. 

Slobodyan died on 15 December 2020 at the age of 67.

[[Ian Armstrong (politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Politicians from New South Wales

Ian Morton Armstrong (17 July 1937 – 16 December 2020) was an Australian politician. He was the Deputy Premier of New South Wales from 1993 to 1995. He was a member of the Parliament of New South Wales from 1981 to 2007. Armstrong was a member of the National Party.

Armstrong died on 16 December 2020 at the age of 83.

[[Caroline Cellier]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, French movie actors, French television actors

Caroline Cellier (7 August 1945 – 15 December 2020) was a French actress. She was born in Montpellier, France. Her career lasted from 1964 to 2011. She was known for her roles in This Man Must Die, L'emmerdeur and A Thousand Billion Dollars.

From 1978 to 1992, Cellier was married to actor Jean Poiret. They had one child. 

Cellier died on 15 December 2020 at the age of 75.

[[Jean Poiret]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 1992 deaths, French movie actors, French television actors, French theatre directors, Movie directors from Paris, Writers from Paris, French playwrights, Actors from Paris, French screenwriters

Jean Poiret, born Jean Poiré, (17 August 1926 – 14 March 1992) was a French actor, director, and screenwriter. He was known as the author of the original play La Cage aux Folles.

[[Leticia Lee]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, 2020 deaths, Activists from Hong Kong, Chinese politicians, Political activists, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic

Leticia Lee See-yin (李偲嫣, 17 August 1964 – 16 December 2020) was a Hong Kong political activist. She was pro-China. Lee ran unsuccessfully in the 2016 Hong Kong legislative election. In 2018, Lee was accused of corruption. She had conservative views and her views of anti-LGBT rights made her controversial.

Lee died on 16 December 2020 at a Hong Kong hospital at the age of 56. She tested positive for COVID-19 in the simple test before she died but it's still not confirmed that she died from COVID-19.

[[Hanna Stankówna]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Polish movie actors, Polish stage actors, People from Poznań

Hanna Stanek-Lisowska (4 May 1938 – 14 December 2020) was a Polish actress. She was born in Poznań, Poland. She was known for her roles in The Real End of the Great War, Lokis and The Third Part of the Night.

Stankówna died on 14 December 2020 in Warsaw at the age of 82.

[[José María de la Torre Martín]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Mexico, Roman Catholic bishops, People from Mexico City

José María de la Torre Martín (9 September 1952 – 14 December 2020) was a Mexican Roman Catholic bishop. De la Torres Martín was born in Mexico City. He became a priest in 1980. He was titular bishop of Panatoria and as auxiliary bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Guadalajara, Mexico from 2002 to 2008 and as bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Aguascalientes, Mexico, from 2008 until his death in 2020.

De la Torre Martín died on 14 December 2020 from COVID-19 in Aguascalientes, Mexico at the age of 68.

[[Manuel Costas (footballer, born 1942)]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Spanish footballers

Manuel Costas Sanromán (8 May 1942 – 15 December 2020) was a Spanish professional footballer. He played as a defender. Costas was born in Panxón, Spain. He played for Sevilla FC from 1963 to 1974. He also played for Recreativo de Huelva from 1964 to 1965. 

Costas died on 15 December 2020, aged 78.

[[Yaakov Agmon]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Columnists, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Israel, Israeli journalists, Israeli businesspeople, Israeli writers, People from Tel Aviv, Theatre directors, Theatre producers

Yaakov Agmon (יעקב אגמון) (24 June 1929 – 16 December 2020) was an Israeli theater producer, manager, and director. He was born in Tel Aviv. He was director of United Jewish Appeal and also as a columnist and the secretary of the Rimon weekly publication.

In 1978, he founded Beit Lessin Theater. In 1995, Agmon was appointed general and artistic director of the Habima Theatre. In 2010, Agmon was appointed general manager of the Arabic-Hebrew theater of Jaffa.

Agmon died on 16 December 2020 at a hospital in Ramat Gan from COVID-19 at the age of 91.

[[Feng Duan]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, Chinese politicians, Physicists

Feng Duan (冯端; June 11, 1923 – 15 December 2020) was a Chinese physicist and politician. He was an expert in solid-state physics. He was a member of the Chinese Academy of Sciences from 1980 until his death. He was a delegate to the National People's Congress from 1983 to 1994. Feng was born in Suzhou, Jiangsu.

Feng died on 15 December 2020 in Nanjing, Jiangsu at the age of 97.

[[Tesfaye Gessesse]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Theatre directors, Ethiopian people, Stage actors

Tesfaye Gessesse (September 27, 1937 – December 16, 2020) was an Ethiopian actor and theatre director. He was born in Addis Ababa. He became the General Director of Hager Fikir Theatre in 1974. In 1975, he was removed and sent to prison by the Derg government after his play "Iqaw" which criticized as state terrorism.

Gessesse died on 16 December 2020, at the age of 84.

[[David Byrd (politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, Living people, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Tennessee, US Republican Party politicians

David Byrd (born September 8, 1957) is an American politician and retired basketball coach. He is a  Republican. Byrd represented the 71st district of the Tennessee House of Representatives since 2015. He was born in Waynesboro, Tennessee. 

On December 10, 2020 Byrd was hospitalized in Waynesboro with COVID-19 and placed in a ventilator.

[[Waynesboro, Tennessee]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Tennessee, County seats in Tennessee

Waynesboro is a city in and the county seat of Wayne County, Tennessee, United States. 2,449 lived here since the 2010 census.

[[Wayne County, Tennessee]]

Wayne County is a county located in Tennessee. As of the 2010 census, 17,021 people lived here. Its county seat is Waynesboro.

[[Waldemaro Bartolozzi]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, Italian cyclists

Waldemaro Bartolozzi (26 October 1927 – 16 December 2020) was an Italian racing cyclist. He finished in ninth place in the 1956 Giro d'Italia. He was born in Scandicci, Italy.

Bartolozzi died on 16 December 2020 in Scandicci at the age of 93.

[[Scandicci]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Tuscany

Scandicci (skanˈdittʃi) is a comune (municipality) in the Metropolitan City of Florence in the Italian region Tuscany. It is located about 6 southwest of Florence.

[[Crystal Lowe]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 births, Living people, Canadian models, Canadian movie actors, Canadian television actors, Canadian voice actors, Canadian child actors, Canadian stage actors, Actors from Vancouver

Crystal Lowe (born January 20, 1981) is a Canadian actress and model. She is best known for her roles in horror movies such as roles as Children of the Corn: Revelation (2001), Final Destination 3 (2006), Black Christmas (2006) and Wrong Turn 2: Dead End (2007).

[[Kawasaki theorem]]

CATEGORIES: Mathematics

The Kawasaki theorem is a theorem relating to the mathematics of paper folding. It states that when folding paper, a figure will be flat, if and only if all of the angles have an alternating sum of zero.

[[Western Conference (MLS)]]

CATEGORIES: 1996 in association football, Soccer in the United States, Football leagues

The Western Conference is one of Major League Soccer's two conferences. The other conference is the Eastern Conference.

[[Taipei frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Asia, Frogs

The Taipei frog also referred to as Taipeh frog, Taipei grass frog, two-striped grass frog, striped slender frog, Taipei slender frog, Taipeh slender frog, white-banded frog, Taiwanese frog or stripe-backed frog (Hylarana taipehensis) is a frog from China, Thailand, Laos, Cambodia, and Vietnam.

The adult frog is 4.0 cm long.  It is bright yellow, green, brown, or mixed in color with some dark brown on the sides of its head.  During the day, this frog stays where the trees are close to each other.  It can live near humans, on farms and in cities.

[[La vida de Lazarillo de Tormes]]

CATEGORIES: Articles with unsourced statements, Literature

The life of Guide of Tormes and of his fortunes and adversities (more known like Guide of Tormes) is an Spanish novel. It was written by an unknown author.  It is written in first person and in style epistolar (like an single long letter). The first editions known are from date of 1554. The book is an  autobiographical form of the life of a boy, Lázaro of Tormes, in the century XVI, from his birth and childhood problemsy until his wedding, already in the adulthood. It is considered precursor of the pictoresque novel by elements like the realism, the narration in first person, the itinerant structure, the service to several masters and the moralistic and pessimistic ideas

Guide of Tormes is an ironic and merciless outline of the society of the moment, of which show  his vices and attitudes hipócritas, especially the ones of the clergymen and religious. There is different hypothesis on his authorship. Probably the author was simpatizante of the ideas erasmistas. This motivated that the Inquisition forbade it and that, later, allowed his publication, once expurgada. The work did not go back to be published entirely until the century XIX

[[Letterlike Symbols]]

CATEGORIES: Unicode blocks, Latin letters

Letterlike Symbols is a Unicode block (a group of symbols in Unicode). It has 80 symbols. Many of these symbols are used in mathematics and look like letters. 

[[Dressed to Kill (1980 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 movies, 1980s LGBT movies, 1980s thriller movies, American thriller movies, Movies directed by Brian De Palma

Dressed to Kill is a 1980 American thriller movie directed by Brian De Palma and starring Michael Caine, Angie Dickinson, Nancy Allen, Keith Gordon, Dennis Franz, David Margulies. It was distributed by Filmways Pictures.

[[Julie Fisher]]

CATEGORIES: Year of birth missing (living people), Living people, American diplomats, Women diplomats

Julie D. Fisher is an American diplomat. In December 2020, the U.S. Senate unanimously approved her designation as ambassador to Belarus. She will be the first American ambassador to that country since 2008, when the United States withdrew its ambassador as part of political tensions between the two countries. Previously, Ms. Fisher had been the U.S. chargé d'affaires and acting ambassador to Russia.  She served as Deputy Assistant Secretary at the Bureau of European and Eurasian Affairs from September 1, 2018 until July 22, 2020 after being the Deputy Permanent Representative of the U.S. Mission to NATO.

[[Aydın Büyükşehir Belediyespor]]

CATEGORIES: Sports clubs

Aydın Büyükşehir Belediyespor is the women's volleyball department of Aydın Büyükşehir Belediyespor Kulübü, a Turkish sports club based in Aydın, Turkey. Aydın Büyükşehir Belediyespor was established on 7 November 2014. The team plays its home matches at the Mimar Sinan Spor Salonu hall in Aydin.

[[Samdari]]

CATEGORIES: Barmer district

Samdari is a tehsil of Barmer district in Rajasthan, northern India.

[[Mena Report]]

CATEGORIES: Jordan, Websites established in 2001, Magazines of Asia

Mena Report (Middle East and North Africa Business Report) is a business news source established in 2001 and run by Al Bawaba (Amman, Jordan, and Dubai). It covers business and economics across the Arabic world.

[[Enclosed Alphanumerics]]

CATEGORIES: Unicode blocks

Enclosed Alphanumerics is a Unicode block (a group of symbols in Unicode). It has 160 symbols. Most of the symbols in the block are letters and numbers inside of circles or in parentheses. In the first Unicode plane (Basic Multilingual Plane), the blocks Dingbats and Enclosed CJK Letters and Months have more numbers inside of circles. In the next plane, the block Enclosed Alphanumeric Supplement has symbols of letters inside of more circles, parentheses, and squares.

Many of the symbols were made to be used as bullets when writing lists. The numbers and letters in parentheses were made to look like how typewriters showed numbers and letters in circles. Unicode was made to think that the characters in this block look different than similar copyright symbols (for example, the copyright symbol (left) and the enclosed C (right): © and Ⓒ). The circled S (Ⓢ) was used by German missionaries at around 1900 as a symbol for the ditto mark.

[[Eric Lopez]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 births, Living people, American voice actors, American video game actors, People from Havana

Eric Lopez (born April 20, 1978) is an American voice actor, best known for his voice role of Blue Beetle in Young Justice. He was born in Havana, Cuba.

Lopez is the current voice of the Bumblebee Man in The Simpsons.

[[Vinland]]

CATEGORIES: History of North America

Vinland is an area of the coast of North America, which Leif Erikson discovered around AD 1000. The name appears in the Vinland Sagas. It probably describes Newfoundland and the Gulf of Saint Lawrence, as far north as New Brunswick. 

[[Guaraní language]]

CATEGORIES: Paraguay, Languages of South America

Guaraní is an American Indian language from Paraguay. It is an official language of Paraguay. Guaraní is written using the Guaraní alphabet.

Guaraní is one of the most widely spoken American languages. It is often used among the Paraguayan people and neighboring communities. This is unique among American languages. Language shift towards European colonial languages (in this case, Spanish) has been nearly universal in the Western Hemisphere. However, Paraguayans have kept their traditional language while also adopting Spanish.

[[Hugues Le Bars]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2014 deaths, French composers, French composers by genre

Hugues Le Bars (13 October 1950 in Versailles Yvelines – 1 November 2014) was a French film music composer.

[[Calamites]]

CATEGORIES: Extinct plants

Calamities were horsetail like trees that went extinct about 250 to 360 million years ago. These plants were medium-sized trees, growing to heights of 30-50 meters and about 100-160 feet. The trunk of these trees had an appearance like a bamboo trunk while the leaves were needle-shaped. These calamities reproduced by cloning

[[Cantar de mio Cid]]

CATEGORIES: 13th century books

The Cantar de mio Cid (Song of My Lord) is an anonymously written poem about the life of the Spanish knight El Cid. The original manuscript is believed to have been written around the year 1200.

It is the oldest Spanish epic poem that is nearly complete; the only missing pages are the first page along with 2 others within the writing. However, other accounts of the work have led historians to produce what is likely to have been in the missing segments. Along with this poem, there exists three other works chronicling the life of El Cid:  Mocedades de Rodrigo (circa 1360), the Cantar de Roncesvalles (circa 1270), and an epitaph, the Epitafio épico del Cid (circa 1400).

The poem has literary significance, and is credited with being the original work of the discipline of the study of Spanish literature: the study has been given credit to historian Ramón Menéndez Pidal (1869-1968), who sparked interest in the work and popularized the study of Spanish literature.

[[Congress of the Republic of Guatemala]]

CATEGORIES: Guatemala

The Congress of the Republic (Congreso de la República) is the unicameral legislature of the Republic of Guatemala. The Guatemalan Congress is made up of 160 deputies who are elected to serve four-year terms. 

31 of the deputies are elected on a nationwide list, while the rest of the 127 deputies are elected in 22 multi-member constituencies.

[[Michigan's 2nd congressional district]]

CATEGORIES: Michigan

Michigan's 2nd congressional district is a United States congressional district in Western Michigan. From 2003 to 2013, it was made-up of the counties of Benzie, Manistee, Wexford, Mason, Lake, Oceana, Newaygo, Muskegon, Ottawa, and the northern portion of Allegan and the northwest portion of Kent.

Zeeland (ˈ ZEE) is a city in Ottawa County in the U.S. state of Michigan. About 5,504 lived here since the 2010 census.

Hudsonville is a city in Ottawa County in the U.S. state of Michigan.  About 7,116 people lived here since the  2010 census.

[[Richard Laird]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Georgia (U.S. state), US Democratic Party politicians

Richard Laird (July 4, 1939 – December 14, 2020) was an American Democratic politician. He was a member of the Alabama House of Representatives from 1978 to 2014. He was born in Rome, Georgia.

[[Jack Page (politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, Politicians from Alabama, US Democratic Party politicians, State legislators of the United States

Jack Page (January 18, 1950 – December 14, 2020) was an American Democratic politician. He was a member of the Alabama House of Representatives from the 29th district from 1993 to 2010. He was born in Kokura, Kyushu, Japan.

Page died of COVID-19 on December 14, 2020, in Gadsden, Alabama at age 70.

[[Anthony Casso]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, Mobsters, Criminals from New York City, American people convicted of murder, People who died in prison custody in the United States

Anthony Salvatore Casso (May 21, 1942 – December 15, 2020), nicknamed "Gaspipe", was an American mobster and former underboss of the Lucchese crime family. 

Casso was known as a "homicidal maniac" in the Italian-American Mafia. 

He is suspected of having done dozens of murders, and had confessed to involvement in between 15 and 36 murders.

Following his arrest in 1993, Casso became one of the highest-ranking members of the Mafia to turn informant. In 1998, sentenced him to 455 years in prison for racketeering, extortion, and murder.

Casso died on December 15, 2020 while in prison in Tucson, Arizona from COVID-19 at the age of 78.

[[Kálmán Sóvári]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Hungarian footballers

Kálmán Sóvári (21 December 1940 – 16 December 2020) was a Hungarian footballer. He played for Újpesti Dózsa as a defender. He played 17 games for the Hungary national football team from 1960 to 1966. He was born in Budapest.

Sóvári died on 16 December 2020 in Budapest at the age of 79.

[[Lorenzo Taliaferro]]

CATEGORIES: 1991 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, American football fullbacks, Sportspeople from Virginia

Lorenzo Taliaferro (December 23, 1991sndDecember 16, 2020) was an American football fullback. He played college football at Coastal Carolina. He was drafted by the Baltimore Ravens in 2014. He was born in Yorktown, Virginia.

Taliaferro died on December 16, 2020 in Williamsburg, Virginia from a heart attack, aged 28.

[[Adela de Torrebiarte]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from lung cancer, Guatemalan politicians, People from Guatemala City

Adela Ana María del Rosario Camacho Sinibaldi de Torrebiarte (March 30, 1949 – December 15, 2020) was a Guatemalan politician. She was born in Guatemala City, Guatemala. She was a member of the Commitment, Renewal and Order. 

She was Minister of the Interior from 2007 to 2008. De Torrebiarte was President of the National Football Federation from 2016 to 2017. In 2020, she became a member of the Congress of the Republic of Guatemala.

De Torrebiarte died of lung cancer in Guatemala City on 15 December 2020.

[[Renê Weber]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil, Brazilian footballers, Brazilian football managers, People from Rio Grande do Sul

Renê Carmo Kreuz Weber (16 July 1961 – 16 December 2020), was a Brazilian football player and manager. He was born in Roque Gonzales, Rio Grande do Sul. 

In 1986, he played for the national team. He mainly played for Fluminense and Vitória.

On 16 December 2020, Weber died in Rio de Janeiro at the age of 59 from COVID-19.

[[Sigillaria]]

CATEGORIES: Trees, Fossil plants

Sigillaria is a lycopod fossil of the late Carboniferous and early Permian. They were typical coal forest trees similar to the Lepidodendron. These swamp forest trees grew to 50 meters. They were anchored by an extensive network of branching underground roots. 

It was a lycopod, an early land plant. This was one of the trees which made up the Carboniferous coal-forests.

It had thin grasslike leaves that grew on the stem. The stem of the plant was green. Sigillaria reproduced with spores. It went extinct about 300 million years ago.

[[Hennadiy Kernes]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Germany, Ukrainian politicians, Mayors

Hennadiy Adolfovych Kernes (Геннадій Адольфович Кернес, Генна́дий Адо́льфович Ке́рнес 27 June 1959 – 17 December 2020) was a Ukrainian politician. In 2010, he became Mayor of Kharkiv. He was born in Kharkiv.

Kernes was hospitalized in September 2020 with COVID-19 in Berlin. He died on 17 December 2020 from kidney failure caused by COVID-19 at the age of 61.

[[R. N. Shetty]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Indian businesspeople, Indian educators, Indian philanthropists, Business people

Dr. Rama Nagappa Shetty (15 August 1928 – 17 December 2020)  was an Indian entrepreneur, philanthropist and an educator. He was born in Murudeshwar, British India. He was in charge of the Upper Krishna Project. His company makes mangalore tiles.

Shetty died of a heart attack on 17 December 2020 in Bengaluru, India at the age of 92.

[[Satya Deo Singh]]

Satya Deo Singh (27 February 1945 – 17 December 2020) was an Indian politician. He was elected to the Lok Sabha in 1991 and resigned in 1998. He was a member of the Bharatiya Janata Party. He was President of Bharatiya Janata Yuva Morcha from 1980 to 1985. Singh was born in Kolkata, West Bengal.

Singh died on 17 December 2020 in Kolkata from cardiac arrest caused by COVID-19, aged 75.

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from lymphoma, Brazilian movie actors, Brazilian television actors, Brazilian stage actors, People from São Paulo

Rosaly Davidman Papadopol (23 February 1956 – 16 December 2020) was a Brazilian actress. She was born in São Paulo, São Paulo. Her career began in 1975. Papadopol was known for her roles as Florinda in the 1987 drama Night Angels and as Sofia in the 2001 crime Bellini and the Sphinx.

Papadopol died of lymphoma on 16 December 2020 in São Paulo at the age of 64.

[[Stephen Tjephe]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2020 deaths, Burmese people, Roman Catholic bishops

Stephen Tjephe (1 August 1955 – 16 December 2020) was a Burmese Roman Catholic prelate. Tjephe was born in Danoku, Myanmar. He became a priest in 1984. In 2009, Pope Benedict XVI made Tjephe the Titular Bishop of Nova Barbara. In 2015, Pope Francis made him Bishop of Loikaw.

Tjephe died on 16 December 2020 in Loikaw, Myanmar at the age of 65.

Penang Football Club (or simply known as Penang FC) is a Malaysian professional football club based in George Town, Penang that currently plays in the Malaysia Premier League.

Grubski died on 17 December 2020 in Łódź from COVID-19 at the age of 52.

[[Happiest Season]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 comedy movies, 2020s romance movies, 2020s LGBT movies, American romantic comedy movies, American LGBT movies

Happiest Season is a 2020 American romantic comedy movie directed by Clea DuVall. The movie stars Kristen Stewart, Mackenzie Davis, Alison Brie, Aubrey Plaza, Dan Levy, Mary Holland, Victor Garber and Mary Steenburgen.

The movie is about a woman who has a hard time to tell her conservative parents that she is a Lesbian and in a relationship with her roommate during Christmas. 

It was released in the United States on November 25, 2020 by Hulu to strong positive reviews.

[[Group 8 element]]

CATEGORIES: Periodic table, Transition metals

Group 8 is a group of elements in the periodic table.

Group 8 has iron (Fe), ruthenium (Ru), osmium (Os) and hassium (Hs).

Group 8 is in the transition metals section.

[[Mekozhoor]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Pathanamthitta district

Mekozhoor is a village in Kerala, Pathanamthitta. It is in the Panchayat called Mylapra.

[[Jacques Lambinon]]

CATEGORIES: Botanists

Jacques Lambinon (born 28 September 1936 in Namur and died in Liège on 14 November 2015) was a Belgian botanist. He was a professor at the University of Liège and member of the Royal Academy of Sciences, Letters and Fine Arts of Belgium.

He is the main author of the New Flora of Belgium, the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, Northern France and neighbouring regions which is used by thousands of students.

He was a recognized specialist of:

Among his very numerous functions, we can mention his role in the direction of the herbarium (Vascular plants) of the University of Liege.

He was a member of many scientific committees such as the Flore de Corse or the National Botanical Conservatory of Bailleul.

He was editor, proofreader and relentless proofreader, he was editorial secretary of "Lejeunia, Revue de Botanique", secretary of the Society for the Exchange of Vascular Plants of Europe and the Mediterranean Basin and correspondent (since 1983) of the Med-Checklist editorial committee (Geneva & Berlin).

[[Interstate 296]]

Interstate 296 (I-296) is an Interstate Highway near Grand Rapids in Kent County, Michigan, United States. It runs between the Interstate 196 near Downtown Grand Rapids; and the Interstate 96 in Walker. It is around 3 long and is part of the U.S. Route 131 for most of the route. It first opened in December 1962, but is now not shown on signs and is only shown as the U.S. Route 131.

[[El cerco de Numancia]]

CATEGORIES: Plays

El cerco de Numancia (The siege of Numancia) is a tragedy written in 1585 by the Spanish writer and soldier Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra. It tells the story of the defeat of Numancia by the Roman Empire in the 2nd century BC.

The play is also known as The Numancia, Comedy of the siege of Numancia, The destruction of Numancia and Tragedy of Numancia. Two handwritten copies of the play have survived.  One copy is in the National Library of Spain which is an actor's script from the 17th century. Another copy, the codex Sancho Rayón, is held by the Hispanic Society of America. This copy was made by Antonio of Sancha in 1784, with modern spelling, together with another play, the Trip of the Parnaso. Both copies are believed to be based closely on the original, although the modern editors prefer to use The Numancia from the manuscript Sancho Rayón.

[[Arizona (1940 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 movies, 1940s western movies, American western movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Wesley Ruggles

Arizona is a 1940 American western movie directed by Wesley Ruggles and was based on the 1939 novel of the same name by Clarence Budington Kelland. It stars Jean Arthur, William Holden, Warren William, Porter Hall, Edgar Buchanan, George Chandler, Colin Tapley and was distributed by Columbia Pictures. It was nominated for 2 Academy Awards in 1941.

[[Too Many Husbands]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 movies, 1940s romance movies, 1940s comedy movies, American romantic comedy movies, Movies based on plays, Movies directed by Wesley Ruggles

Too Many Husbands is a 1940 American romantic comedy movie directed by Wesley Ruggles and was based on the 1919 play of the same name by W. Somerset Maugham. It stars Jean Arthur, Fred MacMurray, Melvyn Douglas, Harry Davenport, Dorothy Peterson, Meville Cooper and was distributed by Columbia Pictures. It was nominated for an Academy Award in 1941.

[[Monster's Ball]]

Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence (Japanese: 戦場のメリークリスマス, Hepburn: Senjō no Merī Kurisumasu - "Merry Christmas on the Battlefield", also known in many European editions as , is a 1983 British Japanese New Zealand World War II movie directed by Nagisa Oshima and was based on the 1963 novel The Seed and the Sower by Laurens van der Post. [[Michael S. Regan]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, Living people, American environmentalists, Politicians from North Carolina, US Democratic Party politicians, Administrators of the United States Environmental Protection Agency

Michael Stanley Regan (born August 6, 1976) is an American environmentalist and politician. Regan is the 16th Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency since 2021. He was the secretary of North Carolina's Department of Environmental Quality from 2017 until 2021.

He was an air quality specialist in the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). 

On December 17, 2020, it was reported that then President-elect Joe Biden nominated Regan to serve as Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. He was confirmed by the United States Senate on March 11, 2021.

[[Juan Pérez-Giménez]]

Juan Manuel Pérez-Giménez (March 28, 1941 – December 10, 2020) was an American lawyer and politician. He was a Judge on the United States District Court for the District of Puerto Rico from 1979 until his death. He was chief judge of the court from 1984 to 1991. Pérez-Giménez was nominated to the court by President Jimmy Carter. He was born in Río Piedras, Puerto Rico.

Pérez-Giménez died on December 10, 2020 in Guaynabo, Puerto Rico at the age of 79.

[[Sal Rocca]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Italian politicians, Italian businesspeople, State legislators of the United States, Businesspeople from Detroit, Michigan, Politicians from Detroit, Michigan, US Democratic Party politicians, US Republican Party politicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States

Sal Rocca (October 29, 1946 – December 13, 2020) was an Italian-born American politician and real estate developer. He was born in Casalvieri, Italy. He was a member of the Michigan House of Representatives from 1975 to 1980, 1983 to 1994, and 2001 to 2004.

Before 1992, he was a member of the Democratic Party. Afterwards, Rocca was a Republican. Rocca was raised in Detroit, Michigan.

Rocca died of COVID-19 in Troy, Michigan on December 13, 2020 at the age of 74.

[[Segundo Galicia Sánchez]]

Segundo Galicia Sánchez (August 11, 1938 – December 14, 2020) was a Peruvian professor and sociologist. He was born in Virú, Peru. He was a full-time professor and researcher, "C" holder of the Faculty of Social Sciences of the Autonomous University of Sinaloa, (UAS), Mexico. He also was a member of the Sistema Nacional de Investigadores. 

Galicia Sánchez died on December 14, 2020 in Mazatlán, Mexico at the age of 82.

Nyagarama (1946 – 18 December 2020), formally known as John Obiero Nyagarama, was a Kenyan politician. He was the first Governor of Nyamira County from 2013 until his death. He was a member of the Orange Democratic Movement. Nyagarama was born in Nyamira County, Kenya.

Nyagarama was diagnosed with COVID-19 on 15 December 2020 and was hospitalized in Nairobi, Kenya. He died three days later from respiratory failure caused by the infection, aged 74.

[[Pierre Buyoya]]

[[Hypovolemic shock]]

CATEGORIES: Medical emergencies

Hypovolemic shock is a medical emergency and an advanced form of hypovolemia. It is caused by low amounts of blood and/or fluid inside the human body to let the heart pump enough blood to the body.

Hypovolemic shock happens when there is a low amount of intravascular volume to the point of heart failure. The hypovolemic shock could be due to severe dehydration or from blood loss.

[[His Kind of Woman]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 movies, 1950s crime movies, American crime movies, Movies directed by John Farrow, Movies directed by Richard Fleischer

His Kind of Woman is a 1951 American crime movie directed by John Farrow and Richard Fleischer and starring Robert Mitchum, Jane Russell, Vincent Price, Tim Holt, Charles McGraw, Raymond Burr, Marjorie Reynolds, Leslie Banning. It was distributed by RKO Radio Pictures.

[[Stanley Cowell]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, American jazz musicians, American pianists, Musicians from Ohio, People from Toledo, Ohio, American educators, Deaths from hemorrhage

Stanley Cowell (May 5, 1941 – December 17, 2020) was an American jazz pianist. He was the co-founder of the Strata-East Records label. Cowell was born in Toledo, Ohio. 

During the late 1980s, Cowell was part of a regular quartet led by J.J. Johnson. Cowell taught in the Music Department of the Mason Gross School of the Arts at Rutgers University in New Jersey.

Cowell died at a hospital in Dover, Delaware from hypovolemic shock-related problems on December 17, 2020 at the age of 79.

[[Enrico Ferri (politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, MEPs for Italy, Former MEPs

Enrico Ferri (17 February 1942 — 17 December 2020) was an Italian politician and lawyer. He was born in La Spezia, Italy. Ferri was a member of the Italian Democratic Socialist Party. 

Ferri was Minister of Public Works from 1988 to 1989 during the Ciriaco De Mita cabinet. From 1992 to 1994, he was a member of the Chamber of Deputies. From 1993 to 1995, he was Secretary of the Italian Democratic Socialist Party. From 1989 to 1994, he was a Member of the European Parliament.

Ferri died on 17 December 2020 in Pontremoli, Italy after a long-illness, aged 78.

Wacław Szybalski (9 September 1921 – 16 December 2020) was a Polish-American oncologist and biotechnologist. He worked at the McArdle Laboratory for Cancer Research in the University of Wisconsin–Madison Medical School. He discovered the Szybalski's rule. Szybalski was born in Lwów, Poland.

Szybalski died on 16 December 2020 in Madison, Wisconsin at the age of 99.

[[Coal forest]]

CATEGORIES: Forests, Fossil plants, Carboniferous, Continents

Coal forests were huge areas of wetlands which covered much of the Earth's tropical land areas in the late Carboniferous (Pennsylvanian) and Permian times.  

At the time most continents were crowded together in the supercontinent Gondwana. They lay on the path of tropical rainfall. As vegetable matter from these forests decayed, enormous deposits of peat accumulated, which later changed into coal. Now those continents are wide apart, but they have the coalfields which those ancient forests left behind.

Much of the carbon in the peat deposits produced by coal forests came from photosynthetic splitting of carbon dioxide. This released oxygen into the atmosphere. This increased the oxygen level, perhaps as high as about 35%. This had the effect of making the air more easily breathable by animals with limitrd respiratory systems. This may explain the size of Meganeura compared to modern dragonflies.

The coal forests covered tropical Euramerica (Europe, eastern North America, northwesternmost Africa) and  China. Eventually, climate change devastated these tropical rainforests. The so-called Carboniferous rainforest collapse was caused by a cooler drier climate which broke up the rainforest ecosystem. The cause of this change was mountain uplift, no doubt caused by the continental plates squeezing against each other.  During most of the rest of Carboniferous times, the coal forests were restricted to North America (such as the Appalachian and Illinois coal basins) and central Europe.

At the very end of the Carboniferous period, the coal forests underwent a resurgence, expanding mainly in eastern Asia, notably China. They never recovered fully in Euramerica.  The Chinese coal forests continued to flourish well into Permian times.  

[[Aristóteles Sandoval]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 births, 2020 deaths, Mexican politicians, Assassinated people, Murders by firearm

Jorge Aristóteles Sandoval Díaz (22 January 1974 – 18 December 2020) was a Mexican politician. He was a member of the Institutional Revolutionary Party. Sandoval was Governor of Jalisco from 2013 to 2018. Sandoval was born in Guadalajara, Jalisco.

Sandoval was assassinated on 18 December 2020 in Puerto Vallarta, Jalisco at the age of 46.

[[Arsphenamine]]

CATEGORIES: Antibiotics

Arsphenamine, also known as Salvarsan or compound 606, is a drug. It was introduced at the beginning of the 1910s. It was the first effective treatment for syphilis and African trypanosomiasis. This organoarsenic compound was the first modern antimicrobial  agent.

Arsphenamine was first synthesized in 1907 in Paul Ehrlich's lab by Alfred Bertheim. 

The antisyphilitic activity of this compound was discovered by Sahachiro Hata in 1909. He surveyed hundreds of newly synthesized organic arsenical compounds. Ehrlich thought that by screening many compounds, a drug could be discovered which would have anti-microbial activity but not kill the patient.

Ehrlich's laboratory developed a more soluble (but slightly less effective) arsenical compound, Neosalvarsan (neoarsphenamine), which was easier to prepare.

[[Puerto Vallarta]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Mexico, Jalisco

Puerto Vallarta (ˈpweɾto βaˈʎaɾta, PV or simply Vallarta) is a Mexican beach resort city located on the Pacific Ocean's Bahía de Banderas in the Mexican state of Jalisco.

[[Hawk Junction]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Ontario

Hawk Junction is a community with a local services board in the Canadian province of Ontario, found just north of Highway 101, about 30 east of Wawa.

The community was made by people of Italian, Scottish and French ancestry in 1909 when the Algoma Central Railway was made through the area. In 1923-1924 it was destroyed by fire. The community was rebuilt and is now a terminal for the Algoma Central Railway.

In September 2017, the last business, the Big Bear Hotel closed, leaving Hawk Junction without any services. Residents had needed to drive to the  town of Wawa for any services. It is a popular starting point for wilderness hunting and fishing trips. During the winter Hawk Junction is a major snowmobile drop off point. The Big Bear has now recently reopened its doors under a new owner.

[[Wawa, Ontario]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Ontario

Wawa is a township in the Canadian province of Ontario, located within the Algoma District and associated with Wawa Lake. Previously known as the township of Michipicoten, after a nearby river of that name, the township was officially renamed in 2007 for its largest  community of Wawa.

This area was first made for fur trading. In the late 19th century, both gold and iron ore were found and mined, leading to the region's rise as the steel industry developed in Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario. From 1900-1918 the Helen Mine had the highest production of iron ore of any mine in Canada.

The township includes the smaller communities of Michipicoten and Michipicoten River, which are small port settlements on the shore of Lake Superior. These names are from the Ojibwe term for the river.

[[FIFA Puskás Award]]

CATEGORIES: FIFA, Sports trophies and awards, 2009 establishments

The FIFA Puskás Award is an award that is organized by FIFA. It is awarded to the player who scored the best goal in each year. The award was first awarded in 2009.

[[Territory (animal)]]

CATEGORIES: Ethology

In ethology, territory is the area that a species of  animal consistently defends against related animals. Sometimes it means areas defended against animals of other species. Animals that defend territories in this way are referred to as territorial.

Territoriality is not shown by most species. More commonly, a  group of animals has an area that they use but do not necessarily defend. This is called their home range. The home ranges of different groups of animals often overlap, and in the overlap areas, the groups tend to avoid each other. 

Many animals use vocalisations to advertise their territory. These are short-term signals given only when the animal is present. The sound can travel long distances and through various habitats. Examples include birds, frogs and canids.

Scent markings are used by many mammals. Some have special scent glands; others squirt urine on key places. Domestic cats have graded ritualized aggression. This starts off with vocalizations and sometimes mounts to direct attack.

Territories may be held by an individual, a mated or unmated pair, or a group, and it may vary at different times of the year.

[[Similar frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Asia, Frogs

The similar frog (Papurana attigua) is a frog from Laos, Cambodia, and Vietnam.  Scientists saw it between 700 and 1200 meters above sea level.

[[Eustace IV , Count of Boulogne]]

Eustace IV (c. 1130 - August 1153) was the son of Stephen of England, He was Count of Boulogne from 1150 until his death in 1153.

[[Hypergamy]]

CATEGORIES: Marriage, Human sexuality

Hypergamy is the practice of dating or marrying someone of a higher social status than oneself. Hypergamy is usually associated with women. Some sociologists believe that harems formerly existed because of female hypergamy. Some analysts also believe that people have twice as many female ancestors as male ancestors because of female hypergamy.

[[2020 United States Senate elections]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 United States Senate elections

Elections happened on November 3, 2020 to elect 33 class 2 members to the United States Senate. The winners were elected into a six-year term from January 3, 2021, to January 3, 2027. Two special senate elections were also held on the same day: one in Arizona after John McCain died and one in Georgia after Johnny Isakson resigned. In Arizona, a Democrat won where there was a Republican before. In Georgia, two Democratic senators won against the Republican senators, changing the state to Democrat and changing the power of the senate from Republican to Democrat.

[[Eltham]]

CATEGORIES: Areas of London, London Borough of Greenwich

Eltham is a district in the south of London in the Royal Borough of Greenwich. The London Plan says Eltham is one of 35 major centres in Greater London. As a residential area (a suburb), the main features, apart from the housing, are the schools and the shops.

It was once an elite area with a palace (Eltham Palace) that dates back to the 13th century. It is now the biggest shopping area in S.E. London. 

The Palace was made over in the 1930s. Stephen Courtauld had it made up in art deco style. The Courtauld family was immensely rich at the time. The Palace still has a few parts which date back in time to its former royal use. It is now owned by English Heritage.

The three wards of Eltham North, South and West have a total population of 35,459. 

Eltham College is a public school (independent fee-paying school) in Mottingham, southeast London. Eltham and Mottingham were part of the same parish.

Secondary schools in Eltham include Eltham Hill School for Girls, Harris Academy Greenwich, St Thomas More Catholic School and Stationers' Crown Woods Academy (built upon the land of King Henry VIII's hunting grounds).

A campus of the University of Greenwich is in Avery Hill Park, on the borders of Eltham and New Eltham .

You, the Living is a 2007 Swedish German French Danish Norwegian Japanese drama movie directed by Roy Andersson and starring Elisabet Helander, Leif Larsson, Björn Englund, Ollie Olson, Jessika Lundberg.

[[Margaret Mead]]

CATEGORIES: 1901 births, 1978 deaths, American anthropologists, Writers from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Deaths from pancreatic cancer

Margaret Mead (December 16, 1901 – November 15, 1978) was an American cultural anthropologist. She was an author and speaker in the mass media in the 1960s and 1970s. She was President of the American Advancement for the Association of Sciences in 1975.

Mead was a communicator of anthropology in modern American and Western culture. As an academic, she was often controversial. Her reports about attitudes toward sex in the South Pacific and Southeast Asian culture traditions influenced the 1960s sexual revolution.

Mead was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. She died from pancreatic cancer in New York City.

[[One Night of Love]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 movies, 1930s romance movies, 1930s musical movies, American romance movies, American musical movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Victor Schertzinger

One Night of Love is a 1934 American romantic musical movie directed by Victor Schertzinger and was adapted from the novel Don't Fall in Love. It stars Grace Moore, Lyle Talbot, Tullio Carminati, Mona Barrie, Jessie Ralph and was distributed by Columbia Pictures. It was nominated for 6 Oscars and won 2 Academy Awards in 1935.

It was distributed by Universal Pictures.

[[Ralph K. Winter Jr.]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, American judges, American lawyers, Politicians from Connecticut, People from Waterbury, Connecticut, US Republican Party politicians, American conservatives

Ralph Karl Winter Jr. (July 30, 1935 – December 8, 2020) was an American politician and lawyer. He was born in Waterbury, Connecticut. He was known as a conservative judge. Winter Jr. was the Judge of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit from 1981 until his death. He was nominated to the court by President Ronald Reagan.

Winter Jr. died on December 8, 2020 in North Haven, Connecticut from esophageal cancer, aged 85.

[[Greg Burdine]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, 2020 deaths, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Alabama, People from Florence, Alabama, US Democratic Party politicians

Burdine died on December 13, 2020, in Florence, Alabama at age 61.

[[Collie]]

CATEGORIES: Dogs

Collies form a type of herding dogs, including many similar landraces and  standardized breeds. The type began in Scotland and Northern England.  Collies are usually medium-sized, fairly lightly-built dogs, with pointed noses.  Many breeds have a white color over the shoulders.  Collies are very active, and most types of collies are excellent at herding.  Collie breeds have spread through many parts of the world (especially Australia and North America), and have then made many varieties, sometimes mixed with other dog types (cross breeding, for example, the Borador).  Some collie breeds are still used as working dogs for herding cattle, sheep, and other livestock, while others are kept as pets, show dogs or for dog sports, in which they display great agility, stamina and trainability. While the American Kennel Club has a breed they call "collie", in fact collie dogs are a type of herding dog including many related landraces and formal breeds. There are usually major differences between show dogs and those bred for herding trials or dog sports: the herding dogs show good agility, stamina and trainability and behaviour.

Common use of the name "collie" in some areas is limited to certain breeds — the name means Rough Collie in parts of the United States, and Border Collie in many parts of Great Britain.  Most collie dog types do not actually include "collie" in their name (see Welsh Sheepdog at right).

[[Michael F. Land]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, British biologists, Neurologists, People from Sussex

Michael Francis Land FRS (12 April 1942 – 14 December 2020) was a British neurobiologist. He was a professor of neurobiology in the vision laboratory at the Sussex Centre for Neuroscience, University of Sussex, England. He was known for his visual information of the retinas of mosquitoes.

Land died on 14 December 2020 at the age of 78.

[[Frank Christopherson Jr.]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Wisconsin, US Democratic Party politicians

Christopherson Jr. died on December 15, 2020 in Duluth, Minnesota at the age of 93.

[[Jeff Clayton]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from kidney cancer, Cancer deaths in Los Angeles, American saxophonists, American jazz musicians, Musicians from Los Angeles, California

Jeff Clayton (February 16, 1954 – December 17, 2020) was an American jazz alto saxophonist and flautist. He was born in Los Angeles. He recorded with Gladys Knight, Kenny Rogers, Michael Jackson, Patti Labelle, and Madonna. Clayton founded The Clayton Brothers in 1977, and later formed the Clayton-Hamilton Jazz Orchestra with Jeff Hamilton.

Clayton died on December 17, 2020 from kidney cancer-related problems in Los Angeles at the age of 66.

[[Hybristophilia]]

CATEGORIES: Paraphilias

Hybristophilia or Scelerophilia is a paraphilia where someone is romantically attracted to mean people or delinquents. Literature about hybristophilia or scelerophilia is in general use used to describe female attraction to bad boys or to obnoxious guys.

[[Mekere Morauta]]

Sir Mekere Morauta, KCMG (12 June 1946 – 19 December 2020) was a Papua New Guinean politician and economist. He was the 7th Prime Minister of Papua New Guinea from 1999 to 2002. Morauta was born in Kukipi, Territory of Papua. Morauta was a member of the People's Democratic Movement.

Morauta died on 19 December 2020 in Brisbane, Queensland, Australia. He was 74.
