[[Rubén Tierrablanca Gonzalez]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Turkey, Turkish people, Mexican people, Roman Catholic bishops, Roman Catholic priests

Rubén Tierrablanca González (24 August 1952 – 23 December 2020) was a Mexican-born Turkish Roman Catholic bishop. Tierrablanca González was born in Guanajuato, Mexico. He became a priest in 1978. He was titular bishop of Tubernuca and as Vicar Apostolic of Apostolic Vicariate of Istanbul and Apostolic Administrator of Greek Catholic Apostolic Exarchate of Istanbul, from 2016 until his death in office in 2020.

Tierrablanca Gonzalez died in Istanbul, Turkey at age 68, from COVID-19 in Istanbul, Turkey.

[[Magnon]]

CATEGORIES: Quantum mechanics, Magnetism

A magnon in physics is a quasiparticle with magnetic properties. It is not a  thing which exists on its own   in free space but exists only within the structure being studied  usually a crystalline solid.

Each atom in a solid has a magnetic field generated by its electrons as they spin. If these  spins all align then the solid becomes magnetic at the bulk everyday level. Usually they do not align and the magnetic field of individual atoms cancel each other out. 

Individual atoms can have their spin reversed by interaction with energy from elsewhere. A spin reversal itself  can influence the spin of the electrons in neighbouring atoms.  A wave of change in electron spins can then move through the electrons in the crystal lattice as it dissipates like waves on a pool of water.  Since the electrons are very small and governed by quantum mechanics, this wave, can be treated as though it is a number of particle like entities. These are magnetic quasi particles or magnons. 

[[Tuck Tucker]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, 2020 deaths, American animators, American songwriters, American television writers, American television directors, Writers from Virginia, People from Lynchburg, Virginia

William Osborne "Tuck" Tucker III (August 20, 1961 – December 22, 2020) was an American writer, artist, animator, songwriter, and director. He was born in Lynchburg, Virginia. He was known for having worked on SpongeBob SquarePants, The Simpsons and Hey Arnold!.

Tucker died in California on December 22, 2020 at the age of 59.

[[Antonio Vacca]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from throat cancer, Italian Roman Catholics, Roman Catholic bishops

Antonio Vacca (8 August 1934 – 22 December 2020) was an Italian Roman Catholic bishop. He became a priest in 1957. He was bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Alghero-Bosa, Italy, from 1994 to 2006.

Vacca died of throat cancer on 22 December 2020 at the age of 86.

[[Mouloud Achour]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Academics, Journalists, Algerian people

Mouloud Achour (19 March 1944 – 24 December 2020) was an Algerian writer, professor, and journalist.

Achour was a member and then chairman of the executive council of the Public Establishment of Television. He also directed the cabinet for the Ministry of Communications. He was editorial director of Casbah Éditions in Algiers.

Achour died on 24 December 2020 at the age of 76.

[[National Assembly (Mali)]]

CATEGORIES: Mali

The National Assembly of Mali is the unicameral country's legislative body of 147 voting members.

Members of the National Assembly, called deputies, are elected by direct universal suffrage for a five-year term.

[[Mohamad Aziz]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Malaysian politicians

Mohamad bin Aziz (29 July 1940 – 24 December 2020) was a Malaysian politician. He was a member of the Parliament of Malaysia for the Sri Gading constituency in the state of Johor from 1999 to 2013. He was a member of the United Malays National Organisation (UMNO) party. Aziz was born in Batu Pahat, Johor.

Aziz died on 24 December 2020 at the age of 80.

[[Rosario Cordero]]

CATEGORIES: 1966 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from colorectal cancer, Spanish politicians, Mayors, Cancer deaths in Spain

Maria Rosario Cordero Martin (13 August 1966 – 24 December 2020) was a Spanish politician. She was a member of the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party. Cordero was born in Cáceres, Spain. From 2015 until her death, she was President of the Province of Cáceres. From 2003 until her death, Cordero was Mayor of Romangordo.

Cordero died on 24 December 2020 in Romangordo, Spain from colorectal cancer, aged 54.

[[Romangordo]]

CATEGORIES: Municipalities in Extremadura

Romangordo is a municipality located in the province of Cáceres, Extremadura, Spain.

[[Ivry Gitlis]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2020 deaths, Israeli musicians, Violinists, People from Haifa

Ivry Gitlis (עברי גיטליס‎;‎ 25 August 1922 – 24 December 2020) was an Israeli violinist. He performed with the world's top orchestras, including the London Philharmonic, New York Philharmonic, Berlin Philharmonic, Vienna Philharmonic, Philadelphia Orchestra, and Israel Philharmonic Orchestra. Gitlis was born in Haifa, Palestine Mandate.

Gitlis died on 24 December 2020 in Paris at the age of 98.

[[Yehuda Henkin]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Israeli rabbis, Israeli Jews, People from Jerusalem

Rabbi Yehuda Herzl Henkin (1945 – December 24, 2020) was an Israeli rabbi and modern orthodox posek. He was born in Jerusalem. Henkin was the founder and head of Nishmat, the Institute for Advanced Jewish Studies for Women.

Henkin died in Jerusalem on December 24, 2020 at the age of 75.

[[Thoriq Husler]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Indonesia, Indonesian politicians

Thoriq Husler (19 April 1963 – 24 December 2020) was an Indonesian politician. He was born in Palopo, Indonesia. He was the Regent of the East Luwu Regency from 2016 until his death.

Husler died on 24 December 2020 in Makassar, Indonesia from COVID-19 at the age of 57.

[[AKM Jahangir Hossain]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Indonesia, Indonesian politicians

AKM Jahangir Hossain (1954 – 24 December 2020) was a Bangladeshi Bangladesh Awami League politician. He was a member of the Jatiya Sangsad from 1991 to 1995, 1996 to 2006 and from 2014 to 2018. From 1998 to 2001, he was Minister of Textiles and Jute.

Hossain died on 24 December 2020 at a Dhaka hospital from COVID-19 at the age of 66.

[[Milorad Janković]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Serbian footballers

Milorad Janković (10 August 1940 – 24 December 2020) was a Yugoslav footballer. He played at both professional and international levels as a striker. He played club football for Radnički Niš between 1964 and 1974, and made one appearance for Yugoslavia in 1966.

Janković died on 24 December 2020 at the age of 80.

[[Aleksandar Ivoš]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Serbian footballers

Aleksandar Ivoš (Serbian Cyrillic: Александар Ивош; 28 June 1931 – 24 December 2020) was a Serbian footballer. In 1962, he made three appearances for the Yugoslavia national football team.

Ivoš started his football career in neighbouring FK Loznica before moving to FK Mačva Šabac in 1951. He played for FK Sloboda Tuzla before moving abroad to play in Austria and Belgium. He played with Wiener Sport-Club.

[[B. J. Marsh]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Missouri, Businesspeople from Missouri, US Republican Party politicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States

B.J. Marsh (February 21, 1940 – December 24, 2020) was an American politician and businessman. He was a member of the Missouri House of Representatives from 2000 to 2008 and 1988 to 1992. He was a member of the Republican Party. Marsh was born in Dade County, Missouri.

Marsh died on December 24, 2020 in Springfield, Missouri from problems caused by COVID-19. He was 80 years old.

[[Greenfield, Missouri]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Missouri, County seats in Missouri

Greenfield is a city in Dade County, Missouri, United States. 1,371 people lived here at the 2010 census. It is the county seat of Dade County.

[[Pir Noor Muhammad Shah Jeelani]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 deaths, 1951 births, Pakistani politicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Pakistan

Pir Noor Muhammad Shah Jeelani (پیر نور محمد شاہ جیلانی; 15 September 1951 – 24 December 2020) was a Pakistani politician. He was a member of the National Assembly of Pakistan from August 2018 until his death. He was also a member of the assembly from June 2013 to May 2018. Jeelani was a member of the Pakistan Peoples Party.

Jeelani died in Karachi on 24 December 2020, at age 66, from COVID-19, during the pandemic in Pakistan.

[[Irawaddy frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Asia, Frogs

The Irawaddy frog ("Hylarana" margariana) is a frog from Myanmar.

Scientists are not sure which genus this frog should be in. That is why they write "Hylarana" in quotation marks instead of just Hylarana margariana.

[[Benhur Salimbangon]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cancer, Filipino politicians

Benhur L. Salimbangon (June 3, 1945 – December 24, 2020) was a Filipino politician. He was a member of KAMPI and the One Cebu party. Salimbangon was a member of the House of Representatives of the Philippines from 2007 until 2019. He was born in Cebu City.

Salimbangon died on 24 December 2020 in Cebu City from cancer, aged 75.

[[Mojmir Sepe]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Slovenian writers, Composers, Conductors, Trumpeters

Mojmir Sepe (11 July 1930 – 24 December 2020) was a Slovenian composer, conductor, arranger and trumpeter. His career began in 1950. Sepe was born in Jazbina, Črna na Koroškem, Kingdom of Yugoslavia. He composed two Eurovision songs: "Brez besed" (1966) and "Pridi, dala ti bom cvet" (1970).

Sepe died on 24 December 2020 at the age of 90. 

[[Felis attica]]

CATEGORIES: Felines

Felis attica is a wild cat in the Felinae subfamily.  It is extinct.

Scientists say Felis attica lived about nine million years ago. It was about the size of a bobcat and looked a little like a lynx. It may have been the ancestor of the African wildcat and of dimestic cats today.

[[Guy N. Smith]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, English novelists, People from Staffordshire

Guy Newman Smith (21 November 1939 – 24 December 2020) was an English writer. He wrote pulp fiction-style horror. He also wrote non-fiction, softcore pornography, and children's literature. Smith was born in Hopwas, Staffordshire. He wrote the novel versions of many Disney animated movies.

Smith died on December 24, 2020 at the age of 81.

[[Davie Sneddon]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Scottish football managers, Scottish footballers

David Sneddon MBE (24 April 1936 – 24 December 2020) was a Scottish football player and manager. He managed Kilmarnock to their 1979 Tennent Caledonian Cup victory. Sneddon played once for the Scotland national under-23 football team in 1958.

He was awarded an MBE in 2014. 

Sneddon died on 24 December 2020 at the age of 84.

[[Minoru Makihara]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Japanese businesspeople, Businesspeople from London, Deaths from heart failure

Minoru Makihara (January 12, 1930Spaced en dashDecember 13, 2020) was a British-born Japanese business executive. He was the chief executive of the Mitsubishi Corporation from 1992 to 1998 and chairman from 1998 to 2004. He was born in London.

Makihara died on December 13, 2020 in Tokyo from heart failure at the age of 90.

[[John Cremona]]

CATEGORIES: 1918 births, 2020 deaths, Maltese politicians, Maltese lawyers, Judges

John Joseph Cremona (January 6, 1918 – December 24, 2020) was a Maltese politician and lawyer. He was the Attorney General of Malta during independence talks in 1964. He helped write the Constitution of Malta. He was the chief justice of Malta from 1971 to 1981.

Cremona died at the age of 102 on December 24, 2020.

[[Siv Widerberg]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Swedish journalists, Writers from Stockholm

Siv Widerberg (12 June 1931 – 24 December 2020) was a Swedish writer and journalist. She received doctor honoris causa from the University of Umeå.  She was born in Bromma, Sweden. She was a member of the Swedish Academy for Children's Books. 

Widerberg died on 24 December 2020 in Stockholm, aged 89.

[[Reginald Foster (Latinist)]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Roman Catholic priests, American Roman Catholics, Writers from Milwaukee, Wisconsin

Reginald Thomas Foster OCD (November 14, 1939 – December 25, 2020) was an American Catholic priest and friar of the Order of Discalced Carmelites. From 1970 until his retirement in 2009, he worked in the Latin Letters section of the Secretariat of State in the Vatican.

Foster died on December 25, 2020 at the age of 81.

[[Dab (dance)]]

CATEGORIES: Internet memes, Dance

Dabbing, or the dab, is a simple dance move in which a person drops their head into their bent upwardly angled arm, while raising the opposite arm out straight in a parallel direction. 

Since 2015, dabbing has been used as a playful manner, becoming a youthful fad and Internet meme.

The move looks like someone sneezing into their elbow.

[[Milka Babović]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Croatia, Croatian writers, Female athletes, Journalists, People from Skopje, Sprinters

Milena "Milka" Babović (27 October 1928 – 26 December 2020) was a Croatian sprint and hurdles runner and journalist. Babović was born in Skopje and grew up in Sarajevo, but moved to Ruma and Belgrade. She came in fifth place at the 1954 European Championships. 

She was a journalist for Narodni sport. She was a multiple-time president of the sport journalist section of the Croatian Journalist Association and was a member of the Yugoslav Olympic Committee.

Babović died of COVID-19 in Zagreb on 26 December 2020 at the age of 92.

[[Brian Binley]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, UK MPs 2005–2010, UK MPs 2010–2015, Former Conservative MPs (UK), People from Northamptonshire

Brian Arthur Roland Binley (1 April 1942 – December 2020) was a British Conservative Party politician. He was the Member of Parliament (MP) for Northampton South from 2005 to 2015. Binley was born in Wellingborough, Northamptonshire.

Binley died in December 2020 at the age of 78.

[[George Blake]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2020 deaths, British criminals, Spies, People from Rotterdam

George Blake (ne Behar; 11 November 1922 – 26 December 2020) was a British spy. He worked as a double agent for the Soviet Union. He became a Communist and decided to work for the KGB while a prisoner during the Korean War. 

His crimes as a double agent was discovered in 1961 and sentenced to 42 years in prison. He escaped from Wormwood Scrubs prison in 1966 and fled to the Soviet Union. 

Blake died on 26 December 2020, aged 98, in Moscow.

[[Cambridge Five]]

CATEGORIES: Spies, World War II, Cold War, 1940s in England, 1950s in the United Kingdom, University of Cambridge

The Cambridge Spy Ring was a group of spies in the United Kingdom that passed information to the Soviet Union during and after World War II. It was active from the later 1930s until at least into the early 1950s. 

None was ever prosecuted for spying. The number and membership of the ring became public slowly, since the 1950s. Their most damaging achievement was to pass information about the Manhattan Project to the Soviet Union.

The sudden flight of Donald Maclean (cryptonym: Homer) and Guy Burgess (cryptonym: Hicks) to the Soviet Union in 1951 was the first public news. 

In 1961, defector Anatoliy Golitsyn provided information which pointed to Kim Philby. Philby (cryptonyms: Sonny, Stanley), fled the country in 1963. He spent the rest of his life in Moscow.

After Philby's flight, British intelligence got confessions from Anthony Blunt (cryptonyms: Tony, Johnson) and then John Cairncross (cryptonym: Liszt), who were the last two of a group of five. Their involvement was kept secret for many years: until 1979 for Blunt, and 1990 for Cairncross.  

The group became known as the Cambridge Five. All five spies met as students or teachers at Cambridge University.

[[Anthony Blunt]]

CATEGORIES: 1907 births, 1983 deaths, Academics of the University of Cambridge, Alumni of the University of Cambridge, British historians, British military personnel of World War II, Deaths from myocardial infarction, English LGBT people, Gay men, LGBT academics, People from Bournemouth, Spies, Writers from Hampshire

Anthony Frederick Blunt (26 September 1907 – 26 March 1983), styled Sir Anthony Blunt KCVO from 1956 to 1979, was a British art historian and spy. In 1964, he confessed to having been a spy for the Soviet Union and was part of the spy group the Cambridge Five.

[[Chic McLelland]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2020 deaths, Scottish footballers, Scottish football managers, Sportspeople from Glasgow

Chic McLelland (24 March 1953 – 26 December 2020) was a Scottish football player and manager. He played for Aberdeen, Motherwell, Dundee and Montrose. His playing career lasted from 1973 to 1990. His managing career lasted from 1990 to 1991.

McLelland was born in Glasgow. He died on 26 December 2020 at the age of 63.

[[Tito Rojas]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Puerto Rican singers

Julio César Rojas López (June 14, 1955 – December 26, 2020) known as Tito Rojas a.k.a. "El Gallo Salsero" was a Puerto Rican salsa singer. He was born in Humacao, Puerto Rico. His career began in 1972. He was known for his albums: Tres Mujeres (1987), Sensual (1990), Vida (2010), Independiente (2011) and El Viajero (2014).

Rojas died on December 26, 2020, at the age of 65, after suffering a heart attack in Humacao.

[[Humacao, Puerto Rico]]

CATEGORIES: Municipalities of Puerto Rico

Humacao (umaˈka.o) is a municipality in Puerto Rico.

[[Nomvuzo Shabalala]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, 2020 deaths, South African politicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in South Africa

Nomvuzo Francisca Shabalala (1960 – 26 December 2020) was a South African politician. She was a member of the African National Congress and the South African Communist Party. From 2011 to 2016 she was the deputy mayor of the eThekwini Metropolitan Municipality. In 2018, Shabalala was elected a member of the National Assembly.

Shabalala died on 26 December 2020 at the age of 60. The cause of death was problems caused by COVID-19.

[[Kadambur R. Janarthanan]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Indian politicians, Indian businesspeople, Trade unionists

Kadambur R. Janarthanan (22 October 1929 – 26 December 2020) was an Indian politician and trade unionist. He was born in Tamil Nadu, India. He was first elected to the Lok Sabha in 1984. He left the parliament in 1996 only to serve again from 1998 to 1999.

Janarthanan died on 26 December 2020 at the age of 91.

[[Leader of the Opposition (Scotland)]]

CATEGORIES: Opposition leaders, Scottish politicians

The Leader of the Opposition is an informal term given to the leader of the largest party not in government in the Scottish Parliament. Since 11 August 2020, this has been Ruth Davidson  of the Scottish Conservative Party.

[[Ruma]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Serbia

Ruma (Рума) is a town and municipality in the Srem District of the Autonomous Province of Vojvodina, Serbia. As of 2011, 30,076 people lived there.

[[More Cowbell]]

CATEGORIES: 2000 in American television

"More Cowbell" is a comedy sketch. It is a part of Saturday Night Live. It was first shown on television on April 8, 2000. The sketch is shown as a fake episode of Behind the Music. It is about the real band Blue Öyster Cult making a sound recording for the song "(Don't Fear) The Reaper". Will Ferrell is shown in the sketch as a man playing the cowbell. He plays the cowbell very loud and annoys the members of Blue Öyster Cult. Christopher Walken is in the sketch as a music producer that keeps asking for the cowbell to be louder.

Many people thought that it was one of the best sketches of Saturday Night Live. Rolling Stone named it the 9th best sketch of Saturday Night Live. "More Cowbell" became a catchphrase in popular culture.

[[Rastamouse]]

CATEGORIES: British television

Rastamouse is a British animated program on CBeebies.

The show was created in 2011.

[[Peter Parker (Marvel Cinematic Universe)]]

CATEGORIES: Fictional characters introduced in 2016, Fictional orphans, Marvel Comics mutates, Marvel Comics superheroes, Spider-Man movie characters

Peter Parker, known as Spider-Man, is a fictional character who appears in some movies in the Marvel Cinematic Universe such as Captain America: Civil War, Spider-Man: Homecoming, Avengers: Infinity War, Avengers: Endgame, and Spider-Man: Far from Home. He is based on the Marvel Comics superhero of the same name and is portrayed by Tom Holland. This is the fourth time Spider-Man has been played in the movies, following after Tobey Maguire's portrayal in Sam Raimi's film series and Andrew Garfield's portrayal in Marc Webb's The Amazing Spider-Man movies.

[[Slovene Americans]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in the United States

Slovene Americans or Slovenian Americans are Americans of Slovene or Slovenian descent.

[[Latvian Americans]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in the United States

Latvian Americans are Americans who are of Latvian ancestry. According to the 2008 American Community Survey, there are 93,498 Americans of full or partial Latvian descent.

[[Turn]]

CATEGORIES: 2014 American television series debuts, 2017 American television series endings, 2010s American drama television series, Spy television series, English-language television programs

Turn or Turn: Washington's Spies is an American television show. It is set during the American Revolutionary War.  It is about the spies and the beginning of espionage.  It was on television for four seasons.  It started in 2014.

[[Icelandic Americans]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in the United States

Icelandic Americans are Americans of Icelandic descent or Iceland-born people who reside in the United States. Icelandic immigrants came to the United States primarily in the period 1873–1905 and after World War II.

[[Estonian Americans]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in the United States

Estonian Americans (Ameerika eestlased) are Americans who are of Estonian ancestry, mainly descendants of people who left Estonia before and especially during World War II. According to the 2013 American Community Survey, there were over 27,000 Americans of full or partial Estonian descent, up from 26,762 in 1990.

[[Faroese Americans]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in the United States

Faroese Americans are Americans of Faroese descent or Faroe Islands-born people who reside in the United States. The Faroe Islands are a group of eighteen islands between Iceland and Norway, and they are a part of the Kingdom of Denmark. There are approximately 50,000 Faroese people living in the Faroe Islands today. It is not known how many Faroese Americans there are.

[[Monacan Americans]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in the United States

Monacan Americans are Americans born in or with ancestry from the principality of Monaco. It can also refer to people born in the United States residing in Monaco.

[[Kazakh Americans]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in the United States

Kazakh Americans are Americans of full or partial Kazakh ancestry. Although in the 1960s the population of Kazakh origin in United States was estimated in 3,000 people, the Census 2000 puts the population size in less of 300 people. According to the American Community Survey in 2010-2012 there were more than 23,000 people born in Kazakhstan, but not all of them are of Kazakh ethnicity.

[[Kashubian Americans]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in the United States

Kashubian Americans are Americans of Kashubian descent. The two earliest Kashubian American settlements in the United States were located around Winona, Minnesota, and Portage County, Wisconsin, which are across the Mississippi River from each other.

[[Sorbian Americans]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in the United States

Sorbian Americans or Wendish Americans are Americans of Sorb/Wend descent. The largest community of Sorbs in the United States is in Texas, with a population of around 588 Sorbs/Wends.

[[Liechtensteiner Americans]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in the United States

Liechtensteiner Americans are Americans of Liechtensteiner descent.

[[Luxembourgian Americans]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in the United States

Luxembourgish Americans  are Americans of Luxembourgish ancestry. According to the United States' 2000 Census, there were 45,139 Americans of full or partial Luxembourgish descent. In 1940 the number of Americans with Luxembourgish ancestry was around 100,000.

[[Cajuns]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in the United States

The Cajuns, also known as Acadians, are an ethnic group mainly living in the U.S. states of Louisiana and Texas, and in the Canadian maritimes providences consisting in part of the descendants of the original Acadian exiles-French-speakers from Acadia in what are now The Maritimes of Eastern Canada.

[[Uruguayan Americans]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in the United States

Uruguayan Americans (uruguayo-americanos, norteamericanos de origen uruguayo or estadounidenses de origen uruguayo) are Americans of Uruguayan ancestry or birth. The American Community Survey of 2006 estimated the Uruguayan American population to number 50,538, a figure that notably increased a decade later.

[[Bolivian Americans]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in the United States

Bolivian Americans (bolivio-americanos, norteamericanos de origen boliviano or estadounidenses de origen boliviano) are Americans of at least partial Bolivian descent.

[[Costa Rican Americans]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in the United States

Costa Rican Americans (estadounidenses de origen costarricense) are Americans of at least partial Costa Rican descent.

[[Nancy Kress]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, American science fiction writers, Award winning writers, Writers from Buffalo, New York, Living people

Nancy Kress (born January 20, 1948) is an American science fiction writer. She began writing in 1976. She has achieved her greatest notice since her Hugo and Nebula Award winning novella Beggars in Spain. The book, in 1993, became a novel.

Kress later won the Nebula Award for Best Novella for another book: After the Fall, Before the Fall, During the Fall in 2013. She also won in 2015 for the book Yesterday's Kin.

Kress, in addition to her novels, has written a number of short stories. She is a regular columnist for Writer's Digest. 

Kress was born in Buffalo, New York.

[[Ina Garten]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, American television personalities, Writers from Brooklyn, Living people

Ina Rosenberg Garten (pronounced EYE-nuh; born February 2, 1948) is an American author and host of the Food Network show Barefoot Contessa. She was a staff member of the White House Office of Management and Budget. Garten has a number of best-selling cookbooks, magazine products and a popular Food Network television show.

Garten was born in Brooklyn, New York.

[[2020 Nashville bombing]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 crimes, 2020 in the United States, 21st century in Tennessee, Attacks on buildings and structures in the 2020s, Building bombings in the United States, December 2020 events, Explosions in 2020, History of Nashville, Tennessee, Suicide bombings in the 2020s, Suicide car and truck bombings, Suicide in 2020

On December 25, 2020, a recreational vehicle (RV) exploded in downtown Nashville, Tennessee, United States, injuring three people and damaging many buildings. 

Human remains were found at the site of the explosion. The explosion took place at 166 Second Avenue North between Church Street and Commerce Street at 6:30 am.

Many people heard gunshots, and loudspeakers on the vehicle telling people to evacuate before the explosion happened. 

The explosion was felt many miles away from the crime site. The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) is leading the investigation. 

Authorities said the next day that the attack was likely a suicide bombing. The FBI named a 63-year-old man as a person of interest in the investigation. The FBI searched his home in Nashville on December 26. However it was later confirmed that the perpetrator of the bombing, Anthony Quinn Warner, was killed in the explosion.

[[Ned Wynn]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, Actors from New York City, Screenwriters from New York City, Deaths from Parkinson's disease

Ned Wynn (April 27, 1941 – December 20, 2020) was an American actor and screenwriter. He was born in New York City. He played Alonzo in The Absent-Minded Professor (1961) and Son of Flubber (1963). He also played Luke in Stagecoach (1966).

Wynn was the son of actor Keenan Wynn and grandson of Ed Wynn.

Wynn died on December 20, 2020 in Sonoma County, California from Parkinson's disease-related problems, aged 79.

[[William Magee (politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from New York, Businesspeople from New York

William D. "Bill" Magee (June 21, 1939 – December 24, 2020) was an American Democratic politician. He was a  member of the New York State Assembly, who represented the 121st Assembly District from 1991 until 2018. He was born in Oneida, New York. He was also a businessman.

Magee died on December 24, 2020 in Nelson, New York at the age of 81.

[[Oneida, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in New York

Oneida (oʊ) is a city in Madison County.

[[Wampsville, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in New York, County seats in New York

Wampsville is a village found inside the Town of Lenox in Madison County, New York. About 543 people lived here as of the 2010 census. It is the county seat of Madison County.

[[Lenox, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New York

Lenox is a town in Madison County, New York, United States. 9,112 lived here as of the 2010 census.

[[Nelson, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New York

Nelson is a town in Madison County, New York, United States. About 1,980 people lived here at the 2010 census.

[[Amit Mitra]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, Living people, Indian politicians, Indian businesspeople, Indian economists, People from Kolkata

Amit Mitra (born 20 December 1947) is an Indian economist and politician. He is a member of the All India Trinamool Congress and the current Finance, Commerce & Industries Minister of the government of Indian state of West Bengal.

He is the current MLA in the West Bengal state assembly from the Khardaha state assembly constituency. He was awarded Padma Shri at 2007. He beat Asim Dasgupta, the ex-West Bengal Finance Minister.Clarify

He was the Secretary general of the Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry (FICCI).

[[Danny Hodge]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from Alzheimer's disease, American Olympic silver medalists, American wrestlers, American boxers, Sportspeople from Oklahoma

Daniel Allen Hodge (May 13, 1932 – December 25, 2020) was an American wrestler and boxer. He was born and raised in Perry, Oklahoma. He was known for being able to crush apples with one hand. He won a silver medal at the 1956 Summer Olympics.

Hodge died of Alzheimer's disease-related problems in Perry on December 25, 2020 at the age of 88.

[[Barry Lopez]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from prostate cancer, American novelists, American essayists, Writers from New York, American environmentalists

Barry Holstun Lopez (January 6, 1945spndDecember 25, 2020) was an American writer. He won the National Book Award for Nonfiction for Arctic Dreams (1986) and his Of Wolves and Men (1978) was a National Book Award finalist.

Lopez died on December 25, 2020 from prostate cancer in Eugene, Oregon at the age of 75.

[[Gregorio Salvador Caja]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, Spanish writers, Linguists

Gregorio Salvador Caja (11 July 1927 – 26 December 2020) was a Spanish linguist. Salvador Caja was born in Cúllar, Granada, Spain. His works were about structural semantics. He wrote for the Spanish newspaper ABC. Salvador Caja was elected to the Real Academia Española on 5 June 1986.

Salvador Caja died on 26 December 2020 at the age of 93.

[[French Sailing Federation]]

CATEGORIES: 1940s establishments in France, 1946 establishments in Europe, Sports organizations

The French Sailing Federation (FFV) (Fédération Française de Voile) is the governing body of sailing in France.

[[Mike Sutton (footballer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from dementia, English footballers, People from Norwich, Sportspeople from Norfolk

Michael John Sutton (5 October 1944 – 26 December 2020) was an English professional footballer. He was born in Norwich, England. His playing career lasted from 1962 to 1984. He played for Norwich City, Chester City, Carlisle United and Great Yarmouth Town.

Sutton died of dementia-related problems on 26 December 2020 at the age of 76.

[[Sunil Kothari]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cardiac arrest, Indian historians, Indian educators, Critics, Indian journalists

Sunil Kothari (20 December 1933 – 27 December 2020) was an Indian dance historian, scholar and critic. He was a professor at Ravindra Bharti University in Kolkata. He started his career with The Times of India. He also taught at Sydenham College of Commerce and Economics. In 2001, he was honored with the Padma Shri.

Kothari died on 27 December 2020 from cardiac arrest in Kolkata, one week after his 87th birthday.

[[Hector and the Search for Happiness (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2014 comedy-drama movies, British comedy-drama movies, American comedy-drama movies, German drama movies, Canadian comedy movies, Canadian drama movies, South African movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Peter Chelsom

Hector and the Search for Happiness is a 2014 comedy-drama movie directed by Peter Chelsom. It was based on François Lelord's book. 

The movie stars Simon Pegg, Rosamund Pike, Toni Collette, Jean Reno, Stellan Skarsgård, Barry Atsma and Christopher Plummer with Togo Igawa.

The movie was released on 15 August 2014 to negative reviews and has a 37% on Rotten Tomatoes.

Barry Atsma (born 29 December 1972) is an English-born Dutch actor. Atsma played Michael in the 2014 comedy-drama Hector and the Search for Happiness and Christie in the 2018 British television series The Split.

[[One Blackfriars]]

CATEGORIES: Skyscrapers in the United Kingdom, Buildings and structures in London

One Blackfriars is a skyscraper in London located at No. 1 Blackfriars Road in Bankside. It has 52 floors and 274 apartments, a hotel and retail shops. The building is 170 tall. It is also known as The Vase or The Boomerang due to its shape.

[[Carlos Eduardo Cadoca]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil, Brazilian lawyers, Brazilian politicians

Carlos Eduardo Cintra da Costa Pereira (April 23, 1940 – December 13, 2020), better known as Carlos Eduardo Cadoca or simply Cadoca, was a Brazilian politician and lawyer. He was born in Recife, Pernambuco. 

Cadoca was a member of the Brazilian Democratic Movement, Social Christian Party and the Communist Party.

Cadoca was a member of the Recife city council from 1983 to 1995. He later was a member of the Pernambuco Legislative Assembly from 1995 to 1999. From 1999 to 2019, he was a member of the Chamber of Deputies.

On December 13, 2020, Cadoca died in Recife from problems caused by COVID-19, aged 80.

[[Aaron Ehasz]]

In November 2019, Ehasz was accused of sexism while working for Netflix.

[[Cooper pair]]

CATEGORIES: Physics

A Cooper pair is a pair of free electrons within a solid that act together as one quasiparticle and in large numbers  give rise to superconductivity.

Physicists explain superconductivity by describing what happens when temperatures get cold. The thermal energy in a solid or liquid shakes the atoms so they randomly vibrate, but this gets less as the temperature drops. Electrons carry the same negative electric charge which makes them repel each other. At higher temperatures each unbound electron behaves as if it were a free particle. There is also however a very weak attraction between electrons when they are in any solid or liquid. This is due to the way bound electrons distort the spacing of the atomic structure they find themselves in. At relatively rather large distances (many hundreds of nanometers apart) and low temperatures (near absolute zero), the attractive effect and lack of thermal energy allows pairs of electrons to hang together. This is called a cooper pair and it is a quasiparticle, that is it acts as if it were a new kind of particle in its own right even though it is made up of two fundamental electrons. 

Many overlapping cooper pairs can exist in the same nanometer sized space. Since paired electrons constitute a boson the motions of all of the cooper pairs within a single superconductor synchronise and they function as if they are a single entity. This is known as the Bose–Einstein condensation. The Cooper pairs  form this condensate, which is superfluid or super-conducting.  Small disturbances such as scattering of electrons are forbidden in this state  as long as the temperature remains low.  It moves as one showing no resistance to its motion. It is hence now a superconductor.

[[Operculum]]

CATEGORIES: Animal anatomy, Fish

In fish, an operculum is a structure made of bone that covers and protects the gills.

[[Mohamed El Ouafa]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic, Moroccan politicians, Ambassadors

Mohamed El Ouafa (محمد الوفا - 1948 – 27 December 2020) was a Moroccan politician. He was a member of Istiqlal Party. He was Minister of Education in  Abdelilah Benkirane's cabinet from 2012 to 2013. Between 2000 and 2012 he was Ambassador to India, Iran and Brazil.

Ouafa died of COVID-19 on 27 December 2020 in Rabat, Morocco at the age of 72.

[[Chandrakant Chiplunkar Seedi Bamba Wala]]

CATEGORIES: 2014 Indian television series debuts, 2014 Indian television series endings

Chandrakant Chiplunkar Seedi Bambawala is a Hindi comedy television series that aired on SAB TV. The show was premiered on August 18th, 2014, and ended on November 12th, 2014. The show revolved around a fire brigade employee of Marathi origin who belonged to a middle-class family.

The show hit the small screen every week from Monday to Friday at 10 p.m. The TV series showcased the funny incidents in which the firefighter gets involved and which then results in a comedy of errors. Every time he gets trapped into hilarious events, his cosmopolitan friends or family members or his neighbors assist him.

The serial explores the life of the Chiplunkar family and their interesting mix of neighbours who always come together to help each other. The lead protagonist is being played by Prashant Damle, as Chandrakant Chiplunkar, a fire brigade employee. Kavita Lad and Anang Desai played supportive cast in the serial.

[[Yuichiro Hata]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 births, 2020 deaths, Politicians from Tokyo

Yuichiro Hata was a Japanese politician. He was a member of the Democratic Party of Japan. He was a member of the House of Councillors in the Diet from 1999 until his death. Hata was born in Tokyo.

He was the Minister of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism from June 4, 2012 until December 26, 2012 during the Yoshihiko Noda cabinet. Hata was the son of Prime Minister Tsutomu Hata. 

Hata died in Tokyo on December 27, 2020 after being hospitalized with a fever, aged 53. He was about to be tested for COVID-19 at the time of his death.

[[Sergio Pintor]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Italian Roman Catholics, Roman Catholic bishops, Roman Catholic priests

Sergio Pintor (16 November 1937 – 27 December 2020) was an Italian Roman Catholic prelate. He was an Diocesan Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Ozieri from 2006 to 2012. Pintor was born in Oristano, Italy. In 1961, he became a priest.

Pintor died on 27 December 2020 in Ozieri, Italy at the age of 83.

[[Carmen Calvo]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, Living people, Deputy Prime Ministers of Spain, Spanish writers

María del Carmen Calvo Poyato (born 9 June 1957) is a Spanish politician and author. She became the Deputy Prime Minister of Spain in June 2018 and Minister of the Presidency, Relations with the Cortes and Equality in January 2020. Calvo is a member of the Spanish Socialist Workers Party. 

Calvo was born in Cabra, Spain. She studied at University of Seville and the University of Córdoba.

From 2004 until 2011, she was a member of the Congress of Deputies. In 2019, she was re-elected to the congress.

On 25 March 2020, Calvo tested positive for COVID-19 during the COVID-19 pandemic in Spain. She made a recovery from the illness in May 2020.

[[Spanish Socialist Workers' Party]]

CATEGORIES: 19th century establishments in Spain, 1879 establishments in Europe, Political parties in Spain

The Spanish Socialist Workers' Party (Partido Socialista Obrero Español paɾˈtiðo soθjaˈlista oβɾeɾo espaˈɲol; PSOE peˈsoe) is a social-democratic political party in Spain. The PSOE has been in government for a longer time than any other political party in modern democratic Spain.

The party was in charge of the Spanish government from 1982 to 1996 under Felipe González; from 2004 to 2011 under José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero; and currently since 2018 under Pedro Sánchez.

The PSOE was founded in 1879, making it the oldest party currently active in Spain. When it was founded, it was a Marxist party, however they stopped supporting Marxism in 1979.

[[Cabra, Spain]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Spain, Municipalities in Andalusia

Cabra is a town in Córdoba province, Andalusia, Spain. About 20,940 lived here in 2005.

[[Alfonso Guerra]]

Alfonso Guerra González (born 31 May 1940) is a Spanish politician. From 1982 to 1991, he was Deputy Prime Minister of Spain.

[[Rodolfo Martín Villa]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, Living people, Deputy Prime Ministers of Spain

Rodolfo Martín Villa (born 3 October 1934) is a Spanish engineer and politician. He was the Deputy Prime Minister of Spain from 1981 to 1982.

He is being investigated in Argentina for murder and crimes against humanity during the 1976 Vitoria massacre.

[[Leader of the Opposition (Spain)]]

CATEGORIES: Spanish politicians

The Leader of the Opposition (Líder de la oposición) is an unofficial honorary title held by the leader of the largest party in the Congress of Deputies—the lower house of the Spanish parliament.

[[Miguel Herrero y Rodríguez de Miñón]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, Living people, Spanish politicians, People from Madrid

Miguel Herrero y Rodríguez de Miñón (born 18 June 1940) is a Spanish jurist and politician. He is a member of the Union of the Democratic Centre until 1982, then of People's Alliance and the People's Party. 

He is one of the "Fathers of the Constitution", the seven politicians who were part of the draft of the Spanish constitution in 1978.

[[Joaquín Almunia]]

Joaquín Almunia Amann (born 17 June 1948) is a Spanish politician. He was President of the European Commissioner for Competition (2009–2014). 

From 1997 to 2000, he was the leader of the opposition as secretary general of the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party.

[[Antonio Hernández Mancha]]

Antonio Hernández Mancha (born 1 April 1951) is a Spanish politician, lawyer and businessman. He was president of the People's Alliance political party and Spain's Leader of the Opposition from 1987 to 1989.

[[People's Party (Spain)]]

CATEGORIES: 1980s establishments in Spain, 1989 establishments in Europe, Political parties in Spain, Conservative parties

The People's Party (Partido Popular paɾˈtiðo popuˈlaɾ; known mostly by its acronym, PP peˈpe) is a conservative and Christian-democratic political party in Spain.

The People's Party was founded in 1989 from the People's Alliance (AP). This party was created as a more centre-right party instead of a far-right party.

[[Next Spanish general election]]

CATEGORIES: 21st century in Spain, 21st-century elections

The next Spanish general election will be held no later than Sunday 10 December 2023, to elect the 15th Cortes Generales of the Kingdom of Spain. All 350 seats in the Congress of Deputies will be up for election, as well as 208 of 265 seats in the Senate.

[[Happiness pump]]

CATEGORIES: Philosophy

A happiness pump is an idea in philosophy.  A happiness pump is someone who will do anything to make other people happy even if it makes them very unhappy themselves.  They have turned themselves into a machine (a "pump") that makes happiness.

The happiness pump is a way of showing problems in utilitarianism.  Utilitarianism is a moral philosophy.  It is a way of deciding which actions are good and which are bad.  In utilitarianism, actions that make more happiness or stop pain are good.  Actions that stop happiness or make pain are bad.  In utilitarianism, it does not matter who is becoming happier or feeling less pain.  That means that, in utilitarianism, helping strangers is good.  The happiness pump is a person who has taken utilitarianism too far and will give themselves lots of pain so long as they believe it makes other people somewhere in the world much happier.

The happiness pump is only an idea.  Philosopher Joshua David Greene says it is almost impossible to be a happiness pump for real.  People who even tried would give up.

[[Inés Arrimadas]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 births, Living people, Spanish politicians

Inés Arrimadas García (iˈnes ariˈmaðas; born 3 July 1981) is a Spanish lawyer and politician. She has been a member of the Congress of Deputies since 2019 and Spokesperson of Citizens party in the Congress. In 2020, she was elected party leader.

[[April 2019 Spanish general election]]

CATEGORIES: April 2019 events, 2010s in Spain, 2019 in Europe, 2019 elections

The April 2019 Spanish general election was held on Sunday, 28 April 2019, to elect the 13th Cortes Generales of the Kingdom of Spain. All 350 seats in the Congress of Deputies were up for election, as well as 208 of 266 seats in the Senate.

With a turnout of 71.8%, the controlling party PSOE of Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez won a victory—the first for the party in a nationwide election in eleven years—with 28.7% of the vote and 123 seats. In the Senate, the PSOE became the largest party in the chamber for the first time since 1995, winning its first majority of seats in that chamber since the 1989 election. 

However, no party won an outright majority and the top three winners of this race had the option for a coalition government. To prevent this, Prime Minister Sánchez ordered a new election to be held seven months later.

[[November 2019 Spanish general election]]

CATEGORIES: November 2019 events, 2010s in Spain, 2019 in Europe, 2019 elections

The November 2019 Spanish general election was held on Sunday, 10 November 2019, to elect the 14th Cortes Generales of the Kingdom of Spain. All 350 seats in the Congress of Deputies were up for election, as well as 208 of 265 seats in the Senate.

Voter turnout was the lowest since 1975. The opposition party People's Party (PP) won a few seats while the far-right Vox party won many seats, taking away from the Citizens (Cs). 

However, the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party won the majority of the seats and popular vote and formed a coalition government with the Unidas Podemos party.

[[Oriol Junqueras]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 births, Living people, Spanish historians, Politicians from Barcelona, Academics, Former MEPs

Oriol Junqueras i Vies (uɾiˈɔl ʒuŋˈkeɾəz i ˈβi.əs; born 11 April 1969) is a Spanish politician, historian and academic.

He was mayor of Sant Vicenç dels Horts. He was Vice President of Catalonia from January 2016 to October 2017. He is president of the Republican Left of Catalonia (ERC). 

[[President of the Government of Catalonia]]

CATEGORIES: Presidents of the Government of Catalonia

The president of the Government of Catalonia (President de la Generalitat de Catalunya, pɾəziˈðen də lə ʒənəɾəliˈtad də kətəˈluɲə) is one of the main parts of government that make up the Statute of Autonomy of Catalonia. The president also is head of government of Catalonia.

The current acting president is Pere Aragonès following Quim Torra's disqualification as president in 28 September 2020.

[[Josep Tarradellas]]

[[Southeast Region, Brazil]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Brazil

Southeast Brazil (Portuguese: Sudeste Do Brasil) is one of five official regions in Brazil.  It borders South Brazil, Center-West Brazil, and Northeast Brazil.  It makes 60% of Brazil's gross domestic product.  Sao Paulo, Rio de Janeiro,  Minas Gerais and Espirito Santo  are all in Southeast Brazil.

[[Beyond the Forest]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 movies, 1940s crime movies, 1940s drama movies, American crime drama movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by King Vidor

Beyond the Forest is a 1949 American crime drama movie directed by King Vidor and was based on the novel of the same name by Stuart Engstrand. It stars Bette Davis, Joseph Cotten, David Brian, Ruth Roman, Minor Watson, Regis Toomey and was distributed by Warner Bros.. It was nominated for an Academy Award in 1950.

[[Ólafur Darri Ólafsson]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, 1973 births, Actors from Connecticut, American movie actors, American movie producers, American television actors, American screenwriters, Icelandic people, Writers from Connecticut

Ólafur Darri Ólafsson (born 13 March 1973) is an Icelandic actor, producer and screenwriter. He is known for roles in movies such as Children (2006), The Deep (2012), The Secret Life of Walter Mitty (2013) and The Vanishing (2018). His television work includes shows such as Trapped and Lady Dynamite.

Ólafur was born in Connecticut, United States, the son of Icelandic parents. He holds dual citizenship of Iceland and the United States. He has two children with dancer Lovísa Ósk Gunnarsdóttir.

[[John André]]

CATEGORIES: 1750 births, 1780 deaths, British military people, Spies

Major John André (b. 1750 - d. 1780) was a British officer in the American War for Independence.  He helped Benedict Arnold change sides to the British army and tried to take West Point.  He was executed for being a spy.

[[New York's 21st congressional district]]

CATEGORIES: Congressional districts of New York (state)

New York's 21st congressional district is a congressional district in the state of New York in the United States of America. As of the 2020 United States presidential election Republican representative Elise Stefanik is the current representative for the district. The district is the largest district in New York and is made up of the entire counties of, Clinton, Essex, Franklin, Fulton, Hamilton, Jefferson, Lewis, St. Lawrence, Warren, and Washington. Parts of Herkimer and Saratoga counties are also part of the 21st district.

[[Tostig Godwinson]]

CATEGORIES: English people

Tostig Godwinson was a man who lived in England in the 1000s c.e.  He was the younger brother of King Harold II. He was the third son of Earl Godwine of Wessex and his Danish wife Gytha, who was the daughter of Thorkell Sprakaleg.

Tostig, his father, and his brothers were banished from England in 1051 by the Saxon King Edward the Confessor but they came back in 1052. After Earl Siward died three years later, he was appointed Earl of Northumbria, Northamptonshire and Huntingdonshire.

He rebelled against Harold and fought alongside Viking forces at the battle of Stamford bridge, where he died in battle.

[[Munchos]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 establishments in the United States, Snack foods

Munchos are a potato chips snack food. They are manufactured from dehydrated potatoes by Frito-Lay. 

They are somewhat similar to Lay's Stax and Pringles. These are also made with dried potatoes. They are kosher.

The chips were first made in 1969.

[[Lay's Stax]]

CATEGORIES: Snack foods

Lay's Stax is a potato chip snack food. It was produced by Frito-Lay. It was introduced in 2003 as a direct competition to Pringles.

Lay's Stax potato chips are heavier and thicker than Pringles. The shape of Stax is a simple curve called a hyperbolic cylinder. Pringles are formed into a double-curve.

[[The Eve of St. Mark]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 movies, 1940s war movies, 1940s fantasy movies, American war movies, American fantasy movies, World War II movies, Movies based on plays, Movies directed by John M. Stahl

The Eve of St. Mark is a 1944 American World War II fantasy movie directed by John M. Stahl and was based on the 1942 play of the same name by Maxwell Anderson. It stars Vincent Price, Harry Morgan, Ruth Nelson, Anne Baxter and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Langbian Plateau frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Asia, Frogs

The Langbian Plateau frog  or Chantaburi Stream frog ("Hylarana" montivaga) is a frog from Vietnam and Thailand. Scientists think it may also live in Cambodia and Laos.

[[Dodie Stevens]]

CATEGORIES: Singers from Chicago, American rock singers, American pop singers, 1946 births, Living people

Dodie Stevens (born Geraldine Ann Pasquale; February 17, 1946) is an American pop and rock singer. She's best known for her 1959 song "Pink Shoe Laces". It began at #96 on the United States Billboard Hot 100. It peaked at #3 on the chart.

Other Stevens songs are "Merry, Merry Christmas Baby."

Stevens was born in Chicago, Illinois. She and her family moved to the San Gabriel Valley in California when she was a child.

The San Gabriel Valley is one of the main valleys in Southern California. It lies generally to the east of Los Angeles. The surrounding areas include:

The San Gabriel Valley gets its name from the San Gabriel River.

[[While the City Sleeps (1956 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 movies, 1950s crime movies, 1950s thriller movies, American crime thriller movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Fritz Lang

While the City Sleeps is a 1956 American crime thriller movie directed by Fritz Lang and was based on the 1953 novel The Bloody Spur by Charles Einstein. It stars Dana Andrews, Rhonda Fleming, George Sanders, Howard Duff, Thomas Mitchell, Vincent Price, John Drew Barrymore and was distributed by RKO Radio Pictures.

[[Cup (unit)]]

CATEGORIES: Units of volume

The cup is a unit of measure in the U.S. customary system. It is defined as 8 fluid ounces.

[[Bearberry]]

CATEGORIES: Ericaceae

Bearberry is the name for three species of  small woody plants in the heath family, Ericaceae. They grow well in cold places. Each species has subspecies. They can grow well in poor soil (for example soil that is mostly sand). 

They have edible fruit. Their leaves are sometimes used for folk medicine. The common name comes from the fact that bears often eat them.

[[Mobilizon]]

CATEGORIES: Free software

Mobilizon is a free and open source software with focus on event organization and group management. It is developed by small but prominent French tech cooperative Framasoft with aim to offer a free alternative to the commercial platforms (like Facebook, Meet-Up, EventBrite).

It was announced in 2019 and launched publicly in October 2020. 

[[Barbara Rose]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from breast cancer, American critics, American historians, American academics, American screenwriters, Writers from Washington, D.C.

Barbara Ellen Rose (June 11, 1936 – December 25, 2020) was an American art historian, art critic, curator, college professor, and filmmaker. She was born in Washington, D.C.. She wrote the screenplay for the 1977 documentary North Star: Mark di Suvero. Rose wrote for Vogue, Art in America, Artforum, and Partisan Review. 

Rose died on December 25, 2020 from problems caused by breast cancer in Concord, New Hampshire, aged 84.

Kowalska died on 26 December 2020 from COVID-19 in Warsaw at the age of 65.

[[José Luiz Carbone]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Brazilian footballers, Brazilian football managers, Deaths from liver cancer, People from São Paulo

José Luiz Carbone (22 March 1946 – 27 December 2020) was a Brazilian footballer and coach. He was born in São Paulo. He played for São Paulo, Ponte Preta, Metropol, Internacional, Botafogo and Nacional (SP).

He played for the Brazilian national team from 1973 to 1974 making six appearances.

Carbone died of liver cancer in hospital in Campinas, Brazil on 27 December 2020 at the age of 74.

[[Antonio Velasco Piña]]

CATEGORIES: Mexican writers, 1935 births, 2020 deaths

Antonio Velasco Piña (8 September 1935 – 27 December 2020) was a Mexican novelist, spiritual writer and essayist. He was the founder of La Nueva Mexicanidad, a group supporting Aztec religion. He was born in Buenavista de Cuellar, Guerrero.

Velasco Piña died on 27 December 2020 in Mexico City at the age of 85.

[[Phil Niekro]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in the United States, Atlanta Braves players, New York Yankees players, Cleveland Indians players, Toronto Blue Jays players, Sportspeople from Ohio

Philip Henry Niekro (ˈ NEE; April 1, 1939 – December 26, 2020), nicknamed "Knucksie", was an American baseball pitcher. He played 24 seasons in Major League Baseball (MLB), 20 of them with the Milwaukee / Atlanta Braves. He played with New York Yankees, Cleveland Indians and Toronto Blue Jays.

Niekro was honored into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1997. He was born in Blaine, Ohio.

Niekro died of cancer on December 26, 2020 in Flowery Branch, Georgia at the age of 81.

[[Margaret Weis]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, American science fiction writers, American novelists, Writers from Missouri, People from Independence, Missouri, Living people

Margaret Weis (born March 16, 1948) is an American fantasy and science fiction writer and author of dozens of novels and short stories. She is one of the creators of the Dragonlance game world.

[[Murder of Dee Dee Blanchard]]

CATEGORIES: June 2015 events, 2015 in the United States, 2015 murders in the United States, Murders by blade weapons

On June 14, 2015, Clauddine "Dee Dee" Blanchard was murdered in the bedroom of her house in Greene County, Missouri. Her body was lying on the bed covered in blood from stab wounds which were caused days earlier. 

Dee Dee's daughter Gypsy Rose, who, according to Blanchard suffered from leukemia, asthma, muscular dystrophy, and brain damage was not in the house at the time the body's discovery. 

The following day, police found Gypsy Rose in Wisconsin, where she had traveled with her boyfriend Nicholas Godejohn. Dee Dee faked all the illness that Gypsy had and many people were mad at Dee Dee because of it. 

Godejohn and Gypsy planned and killed Dee Dee while she was sleeping. Many believed Gypsy killing her mother was justified because the mother was mentally abusing her. 

Gypsy Rose was found guilty to second-degree murder and is serving a 10-year sentence. After a brief trial in November 2018 Godejohn was convicted of first-degree murder and sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole.

[[Arbutus]]

CATEGORIES: Ericaceae

Arbutus is a genus of flowering plants in the Ericaceae family. There are 12 species, which mostly grow around the Mediterranean, and in Central America. The type species is Arbutus unedo, which is known as strawberry tree in English. All species are either trees or shrubs.

Certain Lepidoptera species use Arbutus as food. Some species are cultivated as ornamental plants outside their range.

[[2021 Atlantic hurricane season]]

CATEGORIES: Atlantic hurricane seasons, 2021 disasters

More sources

The 2021 Atlantic hurricane season is an ongoing Atlantic hurricane season, which is part of the annual tropical cyclone season in the Northern Hemisphere. It officially began on June 1, 2021, and will end on November 30, 2021. These dates, adopted by convention, historically describe the period in each year when most Atlantic tropical cyclones form. However, tropical cyclogenesis is possible at any time of the year, as demonstrated by the early formation of Subtropical Storm Ana on May 22, making 2021 the seventh consecutive year that a storm formed before the official start of the season. In June 3 named storms formed during the month making June 2021 the most active June since 1968 and also tied with 1886, 1909, and 1936.

Starting this season, the National Hurricane Center (NHC) began to issue regular Tropical Weather Outlooks on May 15, two weeks earlier than it did in the past. This change was implemented in light of the fact that named systems had formed in the Atlantic Ocean prior to the official start of the season in each of the preceding six seasons.

[[Norman Thavaud]]

Norman Thavaud (born 14 April 1987) is a French YouTuber.

[[A Star Is Burns]]

"A Star Is Burns" is the 18th episode of the 6th season of The Simpsons. It was first shown on the Fox network on March 5, 1995.

[[Dobsonian telescope]]

CATEGORIES: Telescopes

A Dobsonian telescope is an Newtonian telescope design.

It is "altazimuth-mounted".  An altazimuth or alt-azimuth mount is a simple two-axis mount. It supports and rotates an instrument about two perpendicular axes – one vertical and the other horizontal. 

Rotation about the vertical axis varies the compass bearing of where the instrument points (the azimuth). Rotation about the horizontal axis varies the altitude (angle of elevation) of the pointing direction.

It was popularised by John Dobson in 1965. It increased the size of telescopes for amateur astronomers. Dobson's telescopes had a simplified mechanical design that was easy to make from readily available components. It made a large, portable, low-cost telescope. 

The design works for looking at faint, deep-sky objects such as nebulae and galaxies. This type of observation needs a large objective diameter (i.e. light-gathering power) of relatively short focal length. It can be taken to less light-polluted places.

[[Lava lamp]]

CATEGORIES: Lamps

A lava lamp is a decorative lamp, invented in 1963 by British entrepreneur Edward Craven Walker, who made the lighting company Mathmos. The lamp usually takes 2 to 6 hours to heat up, but this also depends on the light bulb which is heating the wax. The lamps are designed in a variety of styles and colours, for example, a mixture of blue and red. The wax inside usually reflects the colours.

[[Arthur Berckmans]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Comics writers, Belgian writers

Arthur Berckmans (3 May 1929 – 28 December 2020), better known as Berck, was a Belgian comics writer. He wrote Sammy. He was born in Leuven, Belgium. He retired in 1994. He also worked on Zonneland.

Berckmans died on 28 December 2020 at the age of 91.

[[Maria Gąsienica Bukowa-Kowalska]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Polish Olympians, Skiers

Maria Gąsienica Bukowa-Kowalska (2 January 1936 – 27 December 2020) was a Polish cross-country skier. She competed in the women's 10 km and the women's 3 × 5 km relay events at the 1956 Winter Olympics. Bukowa-Kowalska was born in Kościelisko, Poland.

Bukowa-Kowalska died on 27 December 2020 at the age of 84.

[[Armando Manzanero]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Grammy Award winners, Mexican singer-songwriters, Mexican musicians, Composers, North American pianists, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Mexico

Armando Manzanero Canché (7 December 1935 – 28 December 2020) was a Mexican bolero singer-songwriter, composer and pianist. He was born in Mérida, Yucatán. His career began in 1950. His record label was RCA Records. His best known singles were: "Somos Novios (It's Impossible)", "Mía" and "Adoro".

In 2014, Manzanero was honored with a Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award.

On 17 December 2020, Manzanero was hospitalized in Mexico City after being diagnosed with COVID-19. He died five days later from the infection, aged 85.

[[Yaël Braun-Pivet]]

Yaël Braun-Pivet (born 7 December 1970 in Nancy) is a French lawyer, activism associative and politician.

Yaël was member of the Socialist Party (PS) and then of En Marche (now La République en Marche). She was elected as member of the national assembly for Yvelines 5th constituency

She is Chair of the Committee on Constitutional Laws, Legislation and the General Administration of the Republic in the French National Assembly.

[[Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2007 movies, 2000s fantasy movies, Harry Potter movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by David Yates

Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix is a 2007 fantasy movie directed by David Yates. It is based on J. K. Rowling's 2003 novel of the same name. The fifth movie in the Harry Potter movie series, it was written by Michael Goldenberg and produced by David Heyman and David Barron.  

The movie stars Daniel Radcliffe as Harry Potter, alongside Rupert Grint and Emma Watson as Harry's best friends Ron Weasley and Hermione Granger. 

The movie had a budget between £75 and 100 million ($150–200 million). Warner Bros. released the movie in North America on 11 July 2007 and in the United Kingdom on 12 July. It is the first Potter movie to be released in IMAX 3D.

Order of the Phoenix opened to a worldwide five-day opening of $333 million. The movie was nominated for two BAFTA Film Awards in 2008.

[[Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2009 movies, 2000s fantasy movies, Harry Potter movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by David Yates

Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince is a 2009 fantasy movie directed by David Yates. It is based on J. K. Rowling's 2005 novel of the same name. The movie, which is the sixth one in the Harry Potter movie series. 

It stars Daniel Radcliffe as Harry Potter, alongside Rupert Grint and Emma Watson as Harry's best friends Ron Weasley and Hermione Granger. 

With a budget of $250 million, it is one of the most expensive movies ever made and the most expensive movie in the Harry Potter movie series.

[[National Democratic Alliance]]

CATEGORIES: 1990s establishments in India, 1998 establishments in Asia, Political parties in India

The National Democratic Alliance (NDA) is an Indian political alliance. It made up of center-right and right-wing political parties and led by the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP). It was founded in 1998. It currently controls the Indian union government as well as the government of 18 Indian states.

Its first chairman was Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee. L. K. Advani, the former Deputy Prime Minister, took over as chairman in 2004 and served until 2014. Afetr that, Amit Shah has been the chairman since 2014. The coalition ruled from 1998 to 2004. The alliance returned to power in the 2014 general elections with a combined vote share of 38.5%. Its leader, Narendra Modi, was sworn in as Prime Minister of India on 26 May 2014. In the 2019 general election, the alliance further increased its tally to 353 seats with combined vote share of 45.43%.

[[Younger Dryas]]

CATEGORIES: Climate change, Neolithic

The Younger Dryas (around 12,900 to 11,700 years ago) was a cold period. It reversed the gradual climatic warming which started around 20,000 years ago. 

At this time there was a sharp fall in temperature over most of the Northern Hemisphere.  This occurred at the end of the Pleistocene epoch and just before the present, warmer, Holocene epoch. 

The last glacial maximum (LGM) was about 27,000 to 24,000 years ago. The Younger Dryas was the most recent and longest of several interruptions to the gradual warming of the Earth's climate. The change was relatively sudden, and it resulted in a decline of temperatures in Greenland by 4 to 10 °C (7.2 to 18 °F) Glaciers and dry conditions spread over much of the temperate Northern Hemisphere. It may have been caused by an influx of fresh, cold water from North America to the Atlantic.

The Younger Dryas was a period of climatic change. The effects were complex and variable. In the Southern Hemisphere and some areas of the Northern Hemisphere, such as southeastern North America, a slight warming occurred.

[[Isolation centers (Belarus)]]

CATEGORIES: Prisons, Belarus

Isolation centers in Belarus are prisons where people are held in camera or with no one to turn to for some time.

The Belarusian "isolation centers" became very known as part of the 2020 Belarusian protests after 2020 Belarusian presidential election. The government and Alexander Lukashenko let punishments on protesters be done. People have been moved in isolation centers. There have been news on bad handling of people and torture in isolation centers. The most known isolation center is Okrestina.

[[GB DIY Store]]

GB DIY Store is a UK based company that offers a range of uPVC window and door repair parts, tools and fitting supplies to both the public and trade. It is the UK's largest specialised supplier of uPVC window and door repair parts to the public.

The Headington Shark (Untitled 1986) is a sculpture on the top of a house. It is at 2 New High Street, Headington, Oxford. The sculpture is a shark breaking the roof of the house.

[[Prison–industrial complex]]

CATEGORIES: Prisons, Politics

The prison–industrial complex is a term for the relationship between the government and businesses and how prisons are involved.  Some sources say the government makes sure that many people are locked up in prison to provide cheap workers for businesses. It is similar to the term military–industrial complex.

It is an expression used to describe the overlapping interests of government and industry that use surveillance, policing and imprisonment as solutions to economic, social and political problems.

The United States has the largest prison population in the world. Many of those prisons are private prisons run by companies rather than the government.

[[EcuRed]]

CATEGORIES: Establishments in Cuba, 2010 establishments in North America, Websites

EcuRed is a Cuban online encyclopedia. Some people have called it the "Cuban Wikipedia". It was launched in 2010. As of now, it has over 200,000 articles.

[[Reactionary]]

CATEGORIES: Social sciences

A reactionary or reactionist is a person or organization that is against social progress and wants society to return to the old way of doing things.

The word reactionary comes from the word "reaction," which describes movement in the opposite direction. In this case, reactionary beliefs and actions are opposed to the direction of social progress.

Some parts of right-wing politics is based on reactionary thinking and a wish to return to the way things were. Being a reactionary should not be confused with being a conservative, which is someone who wishes to keep (conserve) things the way they are.

The words counter-revolutionary or anti-revolutionary are sometimes used in place of the word reactionary.

[[Martin Lambie-Nairn]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, BBC people, Artists from London

Martin John Lambie-Nairn (5 August 1945 – 25 December 2020) was an English designer and animator. He was the founder of Lambie-Nairn. He was known for creating the original Channel 4 logo. He was born in Croydon.

Lambie-Nairn died on 25 December 2020, aged 75.

Lambie-Nairn also animating the title sequence for British comedy TV series Mind Your Language.

Lambie-Nairn held an Honorary Doctor of Arts from the University of Lincoln, and was a Visiting Professor at the Faculty of Art, Architecture and Design. He also held an Honorary Doctor of Arts from the University of Northampton.

[[Grey hat]]

CATEGORIES: Computing, Internet security

A grey hat is a hacker that sometimes can do illegal stuff, but does not exploit it or tell others how to do so.

[[Football League Third Division North]]

CATEGORIES: Football in England, English Football League

The Third Division North was the 3rd division of the English football league system between 1921 to 1958. It ran along with the Third Division South, with clubs being either elected to the League or relegated from a higher division allocated to either league based on their geographical location. Some clubs in the English Midlands shuffled between the Third Division North and the Third Division South based on the composition of the two leagues.

Its final season was the 1957–58 season. After that season, the North and South sections were merged to form the Third Division and the Fourth Division.

[[Humoresque (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 movies, 1940s drama movies, 1940s romance movies, American romantic drama movies, Movies based on short stories, Warner Bros. movies, Movies directed by Jean Negulesco

Humoresque is a 1946 American romantic drama movie directed by Jean Negulesco and is the second adaption of the 1919 short story of the same name by Fannie Hurst. It stars Joan Crawford, John Garfield, Oscar Levant, Joan Chandler, Peggy Knudsen, Paul Cavanagh and was distributed by Warner Bros.. It was nominated for an Academy Award in 1947.

[[Leg before wicket]]

CATEGORIES: Cricket

Leg before wicket (LBW) is one way a batsman can get out in cricket. There must be an appeal to the umpire at the bowler's end, and he makes the decision.

LBW happens when the ball touches a batsman's body before it touches the bat or a hand/glove holding the bat, and the ball would otherwise have hit the wicket. 

Leg before wicket first appeared in the laws of cricket in 1774, as batsmen began to use their pads to prevent the ball hitting their wicket.

[[Pramod Sawant]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 births, Indian politicians, Bharatiya Janata Party politicians, Living people

Pramod Pandurang Sawant (born 24 April 1973) is an Indian politician. He is the current Chief Minister of Goa.

Sawant represents the Sanquelim constituency in the Goa Legislative Assembly. He is a member of the Bharatiya Janata Party.

He is an Ayurveda Medical practitioner by profession.

He was serving as the speaker of the Goa assembly before being sworn in as Chief Minister. After the death of the sitting chief minister Manohar Parrikar, he became chief minister of Goa.

[[Jean Graetz]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from lung cancer, American civil rights activists, People from Pennsylvania, People from Montgomery, Alabama

Jean Graetz (born Jean Ellis; December 24, 1929 – December 16, 2020) was an American civil rights activist. She and her clergyman husband Robert Graetz were well known white supporters of the Montgomery bus boycott in 1955. Graetz was born in East Springfield, Pennsylvania. 

Graetz died of lung cancer in Montgomery, Alabama on December 16, 2020 at the age of 90.

Quirihue (kiˈɾiwe) is a Chilean city in Quirihue, Itata Province, Ñuble Region.

It is about 72 kilometers northwest of Chillán and 410 km southwest of Santiago.

[[Progressive bulbar palsy]]

CATEGORIES: Diseases, Nervous system

Progressive bulbar palsy (PBP) is a medical condition. It is a type of motor neuron disease. PBP is a disease that attacks the nerves in the bulbar muscles. They make the cerebral cortex, spinal cord, brain stem, and pyramidal tracts weaker.

[[Florentino Domínguez Ordoñez]]

Florentino Domínguez Ordoñez (16 October 1962 – 27 December 2020) was a Mexican politician. He was a member of the Institutional Revolutionary Party. In 2014, he became a member of the Mexican Chamber of Deputies representing Tlaxcala. He was born in Chiautempan, Tlaxcala.

Domínguez Ordoñez died during the COVID-19 pandemic in Mexico on 27 December 2020 at the age of 58.

[[Roberto Junguito]]

Roberto Junguito Bonnet  (1943 – 27 December 2020) was a Colombian politician. He was Minister of Agriculture and Rural Development from 1983 to 1984 and Minister of Finance and Public Credit from 1984 to 1985 and again from 2002 to 2003. He was born in Bogotá.

Junguito was the Ambassador to the European Union from 1983 to 1984 and of France from 1986 to 1987.

Junguito died on 27 December 2020 in Bogotá, aged 77.

[[Marc Basnight]]

Marc Basnight (May 13, 1947 – December 28, 2020) was an American politician and businessman. He was a member of the Democratic Party. Basnight was born in Manteo, North Carolina. From 1985 to 2011, he was a member of the North Carolina Senate. From 1993 to 2011, he was President pro tempore of the state senate.

Basnight died on December 28, 2020 in Manteo from problems caused by progressive bulbar palsy at the age of 73.

[[Jaan Rääts]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Estonian people, Composers

Jaan Rääts (15 October 1932  – 25 December 2020) was an Estonian composer. He worked on movie scores in the 1960s and 1970s. He became a member of the Estonian Composer's Union in 1957. He was born in Tartu, Estonia. He composed the movie scores for Ohtlikud mängud (1974) and Aeg elada, aeg armastada (1976).

Rääts died on 25 December 2020 in Tallinn, Estonia at the age of 88.

[[Peter Schmidhuber]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, European Union politicians, German politicians, People from Munich

Peter Schmidhuber (15 December 1931 – 26 December 2020) was a German politician. He was a member of the CSU party. Schmidhuber was born in Munich. He was a member of the Munich city council from 1960 to 1966. From 1965 to 1969 and again from 1972 to 1978, he was a member of the Bundestag.

Schmidhuber also held many political posts in the European Union during the Jacques Delors commission.

Schmidhuber died on 26 December 2020 in Munich at the age of 89.

Stelly died on December 26, 2020 in Lake Charles, Louisiana from problems caused by COVID-19 at the age of 79. His wife, Terry Bass, died hours after him from the same infection.

[[The Act (TV series)]]

CATEGORIES: 2019 television series debuts, American crime television series, American drama television series, Television series about dysfunctional families, English-language television programs

The Act is an American true crime drama television series that was made by Hulu. The series had eight parts, the first episode was released on March 20, 2019. The final episode came out on May 1, 2019.

The show is about the real life story of Gypsy Blanchard and the murder of her mother, Dee Dee Blanchard. Dee Dee abused her daughter Gypsy by lying about her age, faking medical illnesses about Gypsy and physically tying her up.

Joey King played Gypsy and Patricia Arquette played her mother, Dee Dee Blanchard. AnnaSophia Robb, Chloë Sevigny, and Calum Worthy also star.
