[[Haugesund]]

CATEGORIES: Municipalities of Norway

Haugesund is a town within the Municipality of Haugesund, and is the capital of the municipality. It is within the Rogaland county in the country of Norway. It had a population of roughly 32,000 (42,000 including all of the suburbs) as of January 2020. The "birthplace of Norway", as it is called, Avaldsnes, is approximately 8.5km away from the town. The town is named after the nearby Haugesundet strait which is close to the town.

The residents of the town are nicknamed "Maake" (Seagulls), especially those who live in the east side of the town and support the local soccer team.

[[Battle of Monmouth]]

CATEGORIES: Battles of the American Revolutionary War, 1770s in the United States, 18th century in New Jersey, September events

The Battle of Monmouth or Battle of Monmouth Courthouse was a battle of the American Revolutionary War. It was fought on June 28, 1778 in Monmouth, New Jersey. The British army retreated, but neither side won.  Monmouth was the longest battle between the main Continental Army and the main British Army.

[[Anubias]]

CATEGORIES: Araceae

Anubias is a genus of tropical plants in the family Araceae. Members of this genus are popular as aquarium plants. Because of the often shady places where the plants grow, the genus was named after the Egyptian god Anubis, the god of the afterlife. The genus was first described in 1857 by Heinrich Wilhelm Schott, with A. afzelii as its type species. Besides A. afzelii, the genus has the following species:  A. barteri, A. gigantea, A. gilletii, A. gracilis, A. hastifolia, A. heterophylla, and A. pynaertii.

[[Edward Craven Walker]]

Edward Craven Walker (4 July 1918 – 15 August 2000) was a British inventor, who invented the lava lamp. He is also known for being a naturist.

[[Luis Enrique Mercado]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2020 deaths, Politicians from Mexico City, Mexican journalists, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Mexico

Luis Enrique Mercado Sánchez (19 January 1952 – 28 December 2020) was a Mexican journalist and politician. He was a member of the National Action Party. From 2009 to 2012 he was Deputy of the Mexican Congress representing Zacatecas.

He began his career as a journalist for El Universal and founded El Economista in 1988.

Mercado died from COVID-19 during the COVID-19 pandemic in Mexico on 28 December 2020 at the age of 68.

[[Browser engine]]

CATEGORIES: Web browsers

For computers, a browser engine (also called a layout or rendering engine) is a main part of a web browser that is responsible for showing a web page. It is separate from other parts, such as a JavaScript engine.

[[Electronic tagging]]

CATEGORIES: Electronics

There are special electronic devices, that can be permanently attached to a person. These devices are called electronic tags. Using wireless or mobile phone networks, it is then possible to monitor where the person is, all the time. The device can also have extra functions, such as measuring certain parameters.

There are two basic use cases:

Especially in the case of monitoring old people, there have been concerns about privacy.

In the case of monitoring a criminal or someone on probation, the person has to report to a base station at given times. When the base station no longer detects the signal from the tag, it will alert the authorities.

Parviz Parastui (also spelt Parastooee or Parastouei, پرویز پرستویی‎, born 24 June 1955) is an Iranian actor.

[[Sumatra frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Asia, Frogs

The Sumatra frog ("Hylarana" persimilis) is a frog from Indonesia.

[[Agni Sakshi (2017 TV Series)]]

CATEGORIES: 2017 Indian television series debuts

Agni Sakshi (2017 TV Series) was an Indian Telugu Language Soap Opera aired on Star Maa. 

It Stars Arjun Ambati and Aishwarya Pisse in lead roles.

[[Kasthuri]]

CATEGORIES: Soap operas, Indian television series

Kasthuri is an Indian Telugu language soap opera airing on Star Maa. 

The plot revolves around the life of a female doctor. She is happily serving the needy and another doctor falls in love with her. The story is about the romantic life of the couple after marriage and the challenges they face in life together.

It stars Nagarjun Ballappa and Aishwarya Pisse in lead roles.

[[Saracen]]

CATEGORIES: Arab people, Christian terminology

Saracens (ˈ) were Arab Muslims during the Middle Ages. 

In the early centuries of the Common Era, Greek and Latin writings used the term to talk about the people who lived in desert areas in and near the Roman province of Arabia Petraea, and in Arabia Deserta. 

The oldest known source mentioning Saracen dates to the 7th century.

[[Mole (espionage)]]

CATEGORIES: Espionage

In espionage jargon a mole ("deep cover agent", or "sleeper") is a long-term spy. 

The spy is recruited before having access to secret intelligence. Later, if he gets into the target organization, he or she becomes active. 

However, it is popularly used to mean any long-term clandestine spy or informer in an organization, government or private. In police work, a mole is an undercover law-enforcement agent who joins an organization in order to collect incriminating evidence about its operations, and so bring its members to justice.

The term was introduced to the public by British spy novelist John Le Carré in his 1974 novel Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy.

[[Arnulf of Carinthia]]

CATEGORIES: 850 births, 899 deaths, Kings and Queens in Germany, Kings and Queens of Italy, Holy Roman Emperors

Arnulf of Carinthia (circa 850 – December 8, 899) was the duke of Carinthia who removed his uncle, Emperor Charles the Fat from power. He was the disputed King of Italy from 894 and the disputed Holy Roman Emperor from February 22, 896 until his death at Regensburg, Bavaria.

[[Lambert of Italy]]

CATEGORIES: 9th century births, 898 deaths, Kings and Queens of Italy

Lambert (c. 880 – 15 October 898) was the King of Italy from 891, Holy Roman Emperor, co-ruling with his father from 892, and Duke of Spoleto and Camerino (as Lambert II) from his father's death in 894. 

He was the son of Guy III of Spoleto and Ageltrude, born in San Rufino. He was the last ruler to issue a capitulary in the Carolingian tradition.

[[Lean on Me (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1980s biographical movies, 1989 drama movies, American biographical movies, American drama movies, Movies directed by John G. Avildsen

Lean on Me is a 1989 American biographical drama movie written by Michael Schiffer, directed by John G. Avildsen and starring Morgan Freeman.

Lean on Me is based on the story of Joe Louis Clark, a real life high school principal in Paterson, New Jersey. The school is at risk of being taken over by the New Jersey state government unless students improve their test scores on the New Jersey Minimum Basic Skills Test. 

This movie's title is based on the 1972 Bill Withers song of the same name.

[[Marcus D'Amico]]

CATEGORIES: 1965 births, 2020 deaths, German movie actors, German television actors, German stage actors, British movie actors, British television actors, British stage actors, People from Frankfurt

Marcus D'Amico (4 December 1965 – 16 December 2020) was an German-born British actor. He was best known for his role as Michael "Mouse" Tolliver in the 1993 Tales of the City miniseries. He was born in Frankfurt, Germany. 

D'Amico died on 16 December 2020 at the age of 55.

[[Frederik Batti Sorring]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2020 deaths, Indonesian politicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Indonesia

Frederik Batti Sorring, also known by FBS, (May 28, 1955 – December 21, 2020) was an Indonesian politician. He was a member of the Democratic Party. He was the Regent of North Toraja Regency from 2011 until 2016. He was the first Vice Regent of Asmat Regency in Papua province from 2005 to 2010.

In December 2020, Batti Sorring tested positive for COVID-19. He died from problems of COVID-19 at Grestelina Hospital at the age of 65.

[[William Link]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, American television producers, American television writers, Screenwriters from Pennsylvania, Writers from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Emmy Award winners, Deaths from heart failure

William Theodore Link (December 15, 1933 – December 27, 2020) was an American screenwriter and producer. He was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Link was known for creating the television programs Columbo, Murder, She Wrote and Mannix. He won two Primetime Emmy Award in 1970 and 1972. 

Link died on December 27, 2020 in Los Angeles from heart failure at the age of 87.

[[Csaba Ali]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Hungarian sportspeople, Hungarian swimmers

Csaba Ali (4 November 1946 – 27 December 2020) was a Hungarian swimmer. He competed in two events at the 1964 Summer Olympics. He was born in Eger, Hungary.

Ali died on 27 December 2020 at the age of 74.

[[Paul Sueo Hamaguchi]]

Paul Sueo Hamaguchi (1 August 1948 – 28 December 2020) was a Japanese Roman Catholic bishop. Hamaguchi was born in Oita, Japan. He became a priest in 1975. He was bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Oita, Japan, from 2011 until his death.

Hamaguchi died on 28 December 2020 at the age of 72.

[[Hatem Ali]]

Ali died on 29 December 2020 in Cairo from a heart attack at the age of 58.

[[Josefina Echánove]]

CATEGORIES: 1920s births, 2020 deaths, Mexican movie actors, Mexican television actors, Mexican models, Mexican journalists

Josefina Echánove (September 29, 1927 – December 29, 2020) was a Mexican actress, model and journalist. She was nominated for two Ariel Award nominations. Echánove was known for her movies roles on El hombre de los hongos (1976), Amityville 3-D (1983), Gringo Viejo (1989), Cabeza de Vaca (1991) and Perdita Durango (1997). She also appeared in many telenovelas.

Echánove died on December 29, 2020 in Mexico City at the age of 93.

Miguel Ángel Gutiérrez Machado (26 March 1960 – 29 December 2020) was a Mexican politician. He was a member of the National Action Party. From 2000 to 2003, he was Deputy of the Mexican Congress from Yucatán.

Gutiérrez Machado died at age 60 from COVID-19, during the pandemic in Mexico.

[[Luke Letlow]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, Politicians from Louisiana, US Republican Party politicians

Luke Joshua Letlow (December 6, 1979 – December 29, 2020) was an American politician. He was a member of the Republican Party. He was elected to the United States House of Representatives for LA in November 2020 but died before he could take office. 

Before his election to Congress, Letlow served as chief of staff to retiring Representative Ralph Abraham and former Governor Bobby Jindal. He was born in Monroe, Louisiana.

On December 18, 2020, during the COVID-19 pandemic, Letlow announced that he had tested positive for the virus and was hospitalized in Monroe. He was later trasnferred to Shreveport, Louisiana on December 23. He died six days later at the age of 41.

[[Elaine McCoy]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Politicians from Alberta, People from Manitoba, People from Ottawa

Elaine McCoy,  CAN (March 7, 1946 — December 29, 2020) was a Canadian politician. She was born in Brandon, Manitoba. McCoy was a member of the Progressive Conservative Party. McCoy was a member of the Legislative Assembly from Alberta from 1986 to 1993. She was the Senator from Alberta from 2005 until her death.

McCoy died on December 29, 2020 in Ottawa, Alberta at the age of 74.

Nandy died on 29 December 2020 in Nagerbazar, India at the age of 88.

[[Corrado Olmi]]

Corrado Olmi (24 October 1926 – 29 December 2020) was an Italian actor and comedian. He was born in Jesi, Italy. His career lasted from 1956 to 2000. He played Bobino in Wake Up and Die, Don Ermino in Scandal in the Family and as the Mayor in Madly in Love.

Olmi died on 29 December 2020 in Rome from COVID-19 at the age of 93.

Daniel S. Paletko (December 21, 1950sndsDecember 29, 2020) was an American Democratic politician. He was born in Dearborn Heights, Michigan. From 2003 to 2004, he was a member of the Michigan House of Representatives. Paletko was Mayor of Dearborn Heights from 2004 until his death.

Paletko died on December 29, 2020 in Dearborn Heights from COVID-19 at the age of 70.

[[Howard J. Rubenstein]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, American lawyers, Businesspeople from New York City

Howard J. Rubenstein (February 3, 1932 – December 29, 2020) was an American lawyer and public relations expert. Rudolph Giuliani called him "the dean of damage control". He was known for working with many top New York City officials. His clients included the New York Yankees, News Corporation, Columbia University, the New York Philharmonic, and The Metropolitan Opera.

Rubenstein died on December 29, 2020, at age 88.

[[Luigi Snozzi]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Swiss businesspeople, Academics, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Switzerland, Architects

Luigi Snozzi (29 July 1932 – 29 December 2020) was a Swiss architect. He was born in Mendrisio, Ticino. From 1962 to 1971, Snozzi worked with architect Livio Vacchini.

From 1982 to 1984, he was a Visiting Professor and in 1985 he was appointed Professor of Architecture at École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne.  Snozzi was a professor of the University of Sassari, at the Faculty of Architecture of Alghero, Sardinia.

Snozzi died in Minusio, Switzerland on 29 December 2020 from COVID-19, at the age of 88.

[[Arne A. Jensen]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, 2020 deaths, Norwegian businesspeople

Arne Agnar Jensen (15 November 1954 – 29 December 2020) was a Norwegian media and corporate executive. He was born in Bergen, Norway. From 1989 to 1993, he was the chief executive of BSB Bates Group. He then became chief executive of TV 2, and then chief executive of the airline Braathens from 1999 until 2001.

He then became chief executive of Merkantildata, later Ementor, from 2001 to 2004.

Jensen died on 29 December 2020 at the age of 66.

[[Richard Choruma]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 births, 2020 deaths, Zimbabwean people, Deaths from renal failure, African footballers

Richard Choruma (23 November 1978 – 29 December 2020) was a Zimbabwean football winger. His career lasted from 1999 to 2011. He made 54 appearances with Bloemfontein Celtic from 2002 to 2006. Choruma played for Highlanders from 1999 to 2002, 2003 to 2004 and 2007 to 2011. He made eight appearances for the national team from 2001 to 2004.

Choruma died on 29 December 2020 in Thembisa, South Africa from kidney failure at the age of 42.

[[Pat Gillick]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, Living people, Businesspeople from California, Sportspeople from California

Lawrence Patrick David Gillick (born August 22, 1937) is an American professional baseball executive. He was the general manager of four MLB teams: the Toronto Blue Jays (1978–1994), Baltimore Orioles (1996–1998), Seattle Mariners (2000–2003), and Philadelphia Phillies (2006–2008). He was born in Chico, California.

In 2011, he was elected into the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum.

Turman played Lew Miles on the prime-time soap opera Peyton Place, Leroy "Preach" Jackson in Cooley High, Bradford Taylor on the NBC sitcom A Different World and Mayor Clarence Royce on the HBO drama series The Wire. 

Turman was married Aretha Franklin from 1978 and they divorced in 1984.

[[Lazar Matveev]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, Living people, Russian military people, Soviet military people

Lazar Lazarevich Matveev (Russian: Ла́зарь Лазаре́вич Матве́ев; born 17 April 1927) is a Russian intelligence leader and former Soviet intelligence leader. He was a senior KGB liaison officer during 1982 to 1989. He was the boss of Vladimir Putin when Putin worked for the KGB. Matveev was born in Krasnoyarsk Krai, Soviet Union.

Grosse Pointe Woods is a suburban city in Wayne County in the U.S. state of Michigan. 16,135 people lived there at the 2010 census.  It about 10 northeast of downtown Detroit.

[[Ma Rainey's Black Bottom (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 drama movies, Netflix movies, Movies set in Chicago, Illinois, Movies set in the 1920s, American drama movies, Movies based on plays

Ma Rainey's Black Bottom is a 2020 American drama movie directed by George C. Wolfe and written by Ruben Santiago-Hudson. It is based on the play of the same name by August Wilson. 

The movie was produced by Denzel Washington, Todd Black, and Dany Wolf. It stars Viola Davis and Chadwick Boseman, with Glynn Turman, Colman Domingo, and Michael Potts.

The movie is about Ma Rainey and talks about her career in Chicago during the 1920s and how her career was affected by racism.

It was released on a limited theatrical release on November 25, 2020, before beginning to stream on Netflix on December 18.

[[George C. Wolfe]]

CATEGORIES: Tony Award winners, Drama Desk Award winners, 1954 births, Living people, American movie directors, American playwrights, American theatre directors, Writers from Kentucky

George Costello Wolfe (born September 23, 1954) is an American playwright and movie-theatre director. He won a Tony Award in 1993 for directing Angels in America: Millennium Approaches and another Tony Award in 1996 for his direction of the musical Bring in 'da Noise/Bring in 'da Funk.

He was Artistic Director of The Public Theater from 1993 until 2004.

[[James Hormel]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2021 deaths, Ambassadors of the United States, American philanthropists, American LGBT rights activists, Businesspeople from Minnesota, Politicians from Minnesota, US Democratic Party politicians, LGBT businesspeople, LGBT politicians, Gay men, Politicians from San Francisco, Businesspeople from San Francisco

James Catherwood Hormel (January 1, 1933 – August 13, 2021) was an American philanthropist, LGBT activist, and Democratic politician. He was the United States Ambassador to Luxembourg from 1999 to 2001 during the Bill Clinton presidency. Hormel was born in Austin, Minnesota. He was the first openly gay ambassador ever nominated in the United States. 

Hormel died on August 13, 2021 in San Francisco, California at the age of 88.

[[George Smiley]]

CATEGORIES: Fictional British people, Characters in written fiction, Fictional characters introduced in 1961

George Smiley OBE is a fictional character created by John le Carré. Smiley is an intelligence officer with "The Circus". This is the Secret Intelligence Service (SIS), commonly known as MI6. 

He is a central character in the novels Call for the Dead, A Murder of Quality, Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy, The Honourable Schoolboy, and Smiley's People, and a supporting character in The Spy Who Came In from the Cold, The Looking Glass War, The Secret Pilgrim and A Legacy of Spies. The character has also appeared in a number of film, television, and radio adaptations of le Carré's books.

Le Carré, who created Smiley, wanted to show that Ian Fleming's James Bond series was an inaccurate picture of espionage life. Smiley is polite, shy and humble. He often allows others to mistreat him, especially his unfaithful wife. But his humility masks his inner cunning, excellent memory, mastery of tradecraft, and occasional ruthlessness. His genius being underestimated helps Smiley achieve his goals. In the end, he becomes one of the most powerful agents in Britain.

The character is held in high esteem in Britain, where he has become a pop-culture icon on par with Bond. The Guardian called him "the sort of spy Britain believes it ought to have: a bit shabby, academic, basically loyal, and sceptical of...  his political masters".

[[Intelligence officer]]

CATEGORIES: Spies, Researchers

An intelligence officer is a person employed to collect and or analyze information (known as "intelligence") which is of use to the organization.

The word officer is a working title, not a  rank. It is used in the same way a "police officer" can be a sergeant, or in the military, where non-commissioned staff may serve as intelligence officers. 

Organizations which employ intelligence officers include armed forces, police, and customs agencies. Mainly, though, the term is used by government intelligence agencies like MI5 and MI6.

[[Angelica Schuyler Church]]

CATEGORIES: 1756 births, 1814 deaths, History, Socialites, People from Albany, New York

Angelica Schuyler Church was an American woman from New York. She knew Alexander Hamilton, Benjamin Franklin, the Marquis de Lafayette and Thomas Jefferson.

[[Flag of Montserrat]]

CATEGORIES: National flags, Montserrat

The flag of Montserrat was first used after the West Indies Federation was taken apart in 1958.

[[All This and Rabbit Stew]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 movies, English-language movies, American movies

All This and Rabbit Stew is a cartoon with Bugs Bunny. It was first made for viewing on September 13, 1941. Tex Avery is the director of the cartoon. It is about an African American hunter trying to hunt Bugs Bunny.

The cartoon is a part of the Censored Eleven. The Censored Eleven is a group of cartoons that can not be shown on television because they use racial stereotypes. All This and Rabbit Stew shows stereotypes of African Americans.

[[Nectanebo II]]

CATEGORIES: Pharaohs

Nectanebo II ruled in 360–342 BC. He was the third and last pharaoh of the Thirtieth Dynasty of Egypt, and the last native ruler of ancient Egypt.

[[Murder of Jo Cox]]

CATEGORIES: June 2016 events, Terrorist incidents in 2016, Murder in 2016, 2010s murders in the United Kingdom, Murders by firearm in England

British Member of Parliament for Batley and Spen Jo Cox was killed after being shot and stabbed many times on 16 June 2016. Thomas Alexander Mair, a 53-year-old gardener, was found guilty of the murder in September. He held far-right views and attacked her because she supported the European Union and immigration. He was sentenced to life imprisionment with a whole life order.

This was the first time a sitting MP had been killed since 1990, when Ian Gow was killed by the Provisional Irish Republican Army.

Calcutta is a 1947 American crime thriller movie directed by John Farrow and starring Alan Ladd, Gail Russell, William Bendix, June Duprez, Lowell Gilmore, Benson Fong, Edith King. It was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

[[Jolly Fellows]]

Jolly Fellows (Vesyolye rebyata), also translated as Happy-Go-Lucky Guys, Moscow Laughs and Jazz Comedy, is a 1934 Russian musical comedy movie directed by Grigori Aleksandrov and starring Lyubov Orlova, Leonid Utyosov, Valentin Parnakh. It was distributed by Mosfilm.

[[Encounter at the Elbe]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 movies, 1940s war movies, Russian movies, World War II movies, Movies directed by Grigori Aleksandrov

Encounter at the Elbe (in Vstrecha na Elbe) is a 1949 Russian World War II movie directed by Grigori Aleksandrov and Aleksey Utkin. It stars Vladlen Davydov, Konstantin Nassonov, Boris Andreyev, Lyubov Orlova, Ivan Lyubeznov, Faina Ranevskaya, Andrei Fajt and was distributed by Mosfilm.

Two Cars, One Night is a 2004 New Zealand short drama movie directed by Taika Waititi and starring Rangi Ngamoki and Hutini Waikato. It was nominated for an Academy Award in 2005.

[[New Mexico Legislature]]

CATEGORIES: New Mexico, State legislatures of the United States

The New Mexico Legislature (Legislatura de Nuevo México) is the legislative branch of the state government of New Mexico. It is made up of two parts: New Mexico House of Representatives (lower house) and New Mexico Senate (upper house). Both are currently controlled by the Democratic Party.

[[The Passion of Joan of Arc]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 movies, 1920s drama movies, French drama movies, Silent movies, Movies directed by Carl Theodor Dreyer

The Passion of Joan of Arc (La Passion de Jeanne d'Arc) is a 1928 French drama movie directed by Carl Theodor Dreyer and starring Renée Jeanne Falconetti, Eugène Silvain, André Berley, Maurice Schutz, Antonin Artaud.

[[Easter Parade]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 movies, 1940s musical movies, American musical movies, MGM movies, Movies directed by Charles Walters

Easter Parade is a 1948 American musical movie directed by Charles Walters and starring Judy Garland, Fred Astaire, Peter Lawford, Ann Miller, Clinton Sundberg. It was distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and won an Academy Award in 1949.

[[Texas Legislature]]

CATEGORIES: Texas, State legislatures of the United States, 1836 establishments in the United States, 1830s establishments in Texas

The Texas Legislature is the state legislature of Texas. It is made up of two parts: the Texas House of Representatives (lower house) and the Texas Senate (upper house). The House has 150 members and the Senate has 31 members. The legislature meets at the Texas State Capitol in Austin, Texas.

Both houses are currently controlled by the Republican Party, with Dan Patrick as President of the Senate and Dennis Bonnen as Speaker of the House. Both are Republicans.

[[Texas House of Representatives]]

CATEGORIES: Texas, State lower houses in the United States

The Texas House of Representatives is the lower house of the Texas Legislature. It has 150 members, who each one district of Texas. They serve for a two-year term with no term limits. The house meets at the Texas State Capitol in Austin, Texas.

[[Texas Senate]]

CATEGORIES: Texas, State upper houses in the United States

The Texas Senate is the upper house of the Texas Legislature. It has 31 members who each represent one district. They serve for 4-year terms with no term limits. The house meets at the Texas State Capitol in Austin, Texas. The Republican Party currently controls the house.

[[G. Kishan Reddy]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, Indian politicians, Bharatiya Janata Party politicians, Living people

Gangapuram Kishan Reddy (born 15 June 1960) is an Indian politician. He is currently serving as Minister of State for Home Affairs, Government of India. He is a member of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP).

He is an MP representing Secunderabad (Lok Sabha constituency) since 2019. He served the floor leader of the BJP in the Andhra Pradesh Legislative Assembly in 2009. He gave it up after being elected as the state BJP president of erstwhile Andhra Pradesh.

[[Names of Vietnam]]

CATEGORIES: History of Vietnam

Throughout history of Vietnam, besides official names, there are names that are used unofficially to refer to the territory of Vietnam. Vietnam was ever called Văn Lang during the Hùng Vương Dynasty, Âu Lạc when An Dương was king, Nam Việt during the Triệu Dynasty, Van Xuan during the Anterior Lý Dynasty, Đại Cồ Việt during the Đinh dynasty and Early Lê dynasty. Starting in 1054, Vietnam was called Đại Việt (Great Viet). During the Hồ dynasty, Vietnam was called Đại Ngu.

Việt Nam (Vietnam.ogg in Vietnamese) is a variation of Nam Việt (Southern Việt), a name that can be traced back to the Triệu dynasty (2nd century BC, also known as Nanyue Kingdom). The word "Việt" originated as a shortened form of Bách Việt, a word used to refer to a people who lived in what is now southern China in ancient times. The word "Việt Nam", with the syllables in the modern order, first appears in the 16th century in a poem by Nguyễn Bỉnh Khiêm. "Annam", which originated as a Chinese name in the seventh century, was the common name of the country during the colonial period. Nationalist writer Phan Bội Châu revived the name "Vietnam" in the early 20th century. When rival communist and anti-communist governments were set up in 1945, both immediately adopted this as the country's official name. In English, the two syllables are usually combined into one word, "Vietnam". However, "Viet Nam" was once common usage and is still used by the United Nations and by the Vietnamese government.

[[Nityanand Rai]]

CATEGORIES: 1966 births, Bharatiya Janata Party politicians, Indian politicians, Living people

Nityanand Rai (born 1 January 1966) is an Indian politician. He is current Minister of State for Home Affairs in the Government of India. He was elected in the 2014 and 2019 General Election from Ujiarpur. He is a member  of the Bharatiya Janata Party. He had continuously represented Hajipur constituency in Bihar legislative assembly winning elections since 2000 (2000, Feb-2005, October- 2005 and 2010).

[[Kiren Rijiju]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 births, Indian politicians, Indian lawyers, Bharatiya Janata Party politicians, Living people

Kiren Rijiju (born 19 November 1971) is an Indian lawyer and politician. He is also a member of the Bharatiya Janata Party. Rijiju is the current Minister of State (Independent Charge) of the Ministry of Youth Affairs and Sports and Minister of State in the Ministry of Minority Affairs of Government of India.

[[Lidar]]

CATEGORIES: Measuring tools, Meteorology, Sensory system

Lidar is a method for measuring distances by using a laser on a target and measuring its reflection with a sensor.

[[Eemsdelta]]

CATEGORIES: Eemsdelta, 2020s establishments in the Netherlands, 21st-century establishments in Europe

Eemsdelta, Low Saxon: Emsdelta, is a municipality in the province of Groningen, the Netherlands. It lies in the northeast of Groningen.

About 46,000 people live in Eemsdelta. It covers an area of about 364.

The main settlements are Delfzijl and Appingedam.

Eemsdelta was established on January 1, 2021. It was made by combining the former municipalities of Appingedam, Delfzijl, and Loppersum.

The municipality borders the Ems river in the northeast, and the Dollart bay in the east. On the other side of the Ems and the Dollart lies East Frisia, which is a region in the German state of Lower Saxony.

The Eemskanaal flows through the municipality, and connects the Ems river with the city of Groningen.

Eemsdelta contains the fifth most important seaport of the Netherlands, in the city of Delfzijl.

[[Manchester Grammar School]]

CATEGORIES: 1510s establishments in England, 1515 establishments, Grammar schools in England, Manchester

The Manchester Grammar School (MGS) in Manchester, England, is the largest independent day school for boys in the United Kingdom. It has about 1600 pupils.

It was founded in 1515 as a free grammar school. After WWII, MGS was a direct-grant grammar school. It chose to become an independent school in 1976 after the Labour government abolished the Direct Grant System.  Fees for 2016–2017 were £11,970 per annum.

The school is known for its outstanding academic results. In 2017 91% of all A-Level grades were A*-B and at GCSE/IGCSE 68% of all grades were at the A* level.

[[Congo (chimpanzee)]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, 1964 deaths, Individual animals, Artists

Congo was a chimpanzee that learned how to draw and paint. He was born in 1954, and died in 1964. Desmond Morris, who studied his behaviour, gave him materials to paint, but didn't show him how to do it. During his life, Congo made over 400 paintings. People living at the time of Congo thought his paintings resembled abstract art. Nadezhda Ladygina-Kohts had done similar experiments with chimpanzees in Moscow. In 1913, Khots found that the drawings resembled those of her two year old son. At the time when they were done, people did not think highly of them. Despite this, artists such as Herbert Read, Julian Huxley and Pablo Picasso bought some of Congo's paintings.  In 2005, three of Congo's paintings were sold at an auction for  more than 14,000 pound sterling. The auction house at first thought that the paintings would not sell for more than 600 to 800 pounds. 

[[BabyFirst]]

CATEGORIES: American television networks, 2006 establishments in the United States

BabyFirst is an American children's television channel. Its programmes are aimed at babies aged 6–36 months. The channel is owned by FirstMedia.  It is based in Los Angeles, California and can be watched in 33 countries and 13 languages. The channel first started in 2006.

[[Publix]]

CATEGORIES: 20th-century establishments in Florida, 1930 establishments in the United States, Supermarkets of the United States

Publix Super Markets, Inc., known as Publix, is an American supermarket that is based in Lakeland, Florida.

[[Hass avocado]]

CATEGORIES: Avocados

The Hass avocado is a cultivar of avocado (Persea americana) with dark green colored, bumpy skin. It was first grown and sold by Southern California mail carrier and amateur horticulturist Rudolph Hass, who also gave it his name.

The Hass avocado is a big fruit weighing 200 to 300 grams.

[[The Lion Guard]]

CATEGORIES: The Lion King

The Lion Guard is an American animated television series made by Ford Riley and based on Disney's 1994 film The Lion King.

[[Tinga Tinga Tales]]

CATEGORIES: 2010 British television series debuts, 2011 British television series endings, Kenya, BBC Television programmes, Animated television series, CBeebies

Tinga Tinga Tales is a British–Kenyan flash animated children's television series, based on African folk tales, aimed at 4 to 6-year-olds. It was commissioned by the BBC for its CBeebies channel, and by Disney Channel for its Disney Junior block. Named after Tingatinga art from Tanzania, Tinga Tinga Tales was produced in Nairobi, Kenya by Homeboyz Animation, a studio of approximately 50 people. The music is produced by Kenyan singer-songwriter Eric Wainaina. The series comprises 55 episodes.

The series was first conceived by Claudia Lloyd, head of animation at the London-based Tiger Aspect Productions, while travelling through Africa. The first three episodes premiered on the BBC website in early February 2010. The distribution rights have been bought by Entertainment Rights (which in 2009 merged with Classic Media, then in 2012 it was acquired by DreamWorks Animation and renamed into DreamWorks Classics, and ultimately became the property of Universal Television in 2016).

[[Calderstone Productions]]

Calderstone Productions Limited is a subsidiary of UMG that administers the Beatles' music, and three of its solo artists.

[[Tumanay Khan]]

CATEGORIES: Mongolian people, 11th century births

Tumanay Khan (1080-1130), born Tumbinai Setsen, was the 7th Khan of the Mongol Borjigin Tribe. He was the son of Baishinkhor Dogshin and father of Khabul Khan and Khadjuli. He was the direct ancestor of Amir Timur, the founder of the Timurid Empire through one of his Khadjuli Barlus.  He was the ancestor of Genghis Khan, founder of the Mongol Empire, through another son Khabul Khan.

[[Tang Wei]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 births, Chinese movie actors, Chinese television actors, Living people

Tāng Wéi (汤唯) (born 7 October 1979) is a Chinese actress. Tang was best known for her roles in movies Lust, Caution (2007) and Blackhat (2015).

[[Frontonia]]

CATEGORIES: Ciliates

Frontonia is a genus of free-living unicellular ciliate protists.  It is closely related to the genus Paramecium. Frontonia can eat diatoms, cyanobacteria, filamentous algae, testate amoebas, and even members of their own species.  

Frontonia are widespread. Members of the genus are in marine and freshwater environments on every continent.

[[Friedrich Wilhelm von Steuben]]

CATEGORIES: 1730 births, 1794 deaths, German military people, American military people, American Revolutionary War, LGBT military people

Baron Friedrich Wilhelm von Steuben (September 17, 1730 – November 28, 1794) was a German fighter who helped the Continental Army in the Revolutionary War. At Valley Forge, he taught the Continental Army how to fight the European way.

[[Muladi]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Indonesia, Indonesian politicians, Judges, Academics

Prof. Dr. H. Muladi, S.H. (26 May 1943 — 31 December 2020) was an Indonesian academician, judge, and politician. In 1998, he became Minister of Justice in Suharto's seventh and last cabinet on 14 March 1998. 

Muladi tested positive for COVID-19 on 17 December 2020. He died from the infection on 31 December 2020.

[[Narendra Kumar (mountaineer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Indian military people, Mountain climbers

Narendra "Bull" Kumar, PVSM, KC, AVSM,  (also spelled Narinder; (8 December 1933 – 31 December 2020) was an Indian soldier-mountaineer. He was deputy leader of the first Indian successful Everest Expedition in 1965. 

In 1965, Narendra was awarded Padma Shri, the fourth highest civilian award in India, and Arjuna Award

[[Zett Jukassa]]

CATEGORIES: Star Wars characters

Zett Jukassa was a young Jedi who lived on the planet Coruscant with the rest of the Jedi Order. Zett is in Star Wars Episode II: Attack of the Clones. He is killed in Star Wars Episode III: Revenge of the Sith. He was fighting bravelyagainst Clone troopers.

[[Classical architecture]]

CATEGORIES: Architecture

Classical architecture is any architecture that has features from the ancient Greek and Roman style of building. It is also known as the architecture of classical antiquity. Many features of classical architecture come from the writing of the Roman architect Vitruvius.

Different styles of classical architecture might have existed since the Carolingian Renaissance. Styles have definitely existed since the Italian Renaissance. 

Classical architecture buildings can be very different, but all classical architecture uses the same common design features. These features are structural and visual. 

In much of Europe and America, from the Renaissance until World War Two, classical architecture was very popular and important to architecture. It is still important today, but less than it has been in history.  

The term classical architecture is also used to talk about any type of architecture that has become a very specific style. For example, classical Chinese architecture, or classical Mayan architecture. The words "traditional" and "vernacular" can mean something different to "classical", or something similar. 

The phrases New Classical and Neoclassical describe classical architecture that was built in modern times.

[[Da Boom]]

CATEGORIES: Family Guy episodes, 1999 television episodes

"Da Boom" is the 3rd episode of the 2nd season of Family Guy. It was first shown on the Fox network on December 26, 1999. The episode is about the Griffin family after their city is destroyed from a nuclear explosion. This was because of Y2K (the Year 2000 problem). This is the first episode to have Mila Kunis as the voice actor for Meg Griffin.

[[Universal Basic Income]]

CATEGORIES: Politics

[[Admiral Ackbar]]

CATEGORIES: Fictional characters introduced in the 1980s, Star Wars characters, Star Wars Skywalker Saga characters

Gial Ackbar was a Mon Calamari male admiral from Star Wars. Ackbar was an admiral for the Rebel Alliance and led the rebel attack on the Death Star in Star Wars Episode VI: Return of the Jedi. He was born on the planet called Mon Cala, Ackbar helped his people during a battle against the Confederacy of Independent Systems and led the Mon Calamari ships escape the planet many years later from  the Galactic Empire. The ships went on to become the Rebel Alliance fleet. After the Battle of Endor, Ackbar continued his helping the Rebel Alliance when it became the New Republic. He led the Republic fleet to victory over the last Imperial armies at the Battle of Jakku before retiring to his home planet. During his retirement he had a son named Aftab. About 25 years later Ackbar joined Princess Leia Organa when she asked him to stop the threat of the First Order, joining her Resistance. Ackbar was in the movie Star Wars: The Force Awakens helping the Resistance destroy the First Order's Starkiller Base and he was there during the evacuation of the Resistance base. But when the Resistance fleet was stopped by the fleet of the First Order, Ackbar was killed in the attack that happened.

[[Mon Cala]]

CATEGORIES: Star Wars planets

Mon Cala is a water planet in Star Wars home to the Mon Calamari species. Admiral Gial Ackbar is from the planet. The planet first appeared in Star Wars: The Clone Wars and has gone on to appear in many other Star Wars media. The planet was first attacked by the Confederacy of Independent Systems but fended off the attack. It was later under the rule of the Galactic Empire but after the death of their king the species rebelled and used their large cruisers to aid the Rebel Alliance.  Over 30 years later the planet was under control by the First Order after the planet helped the Resistance.

[[Mon Calamari]]

CATEGORIES: Star Wars species

Mon Calamari were species from the water planet of Mon Cala appearing in Star Wars. First appearing in Star Wars Episode VI: Return of the Jedi the species has also appeared in many of the books, comics and TV shows. The most notable Mon Calamari is admiral Gial Ackbar. Many Mon Calamari served in the Rebel Alliance. Mon Calamari are amphibian and are most commonly seen in brown skin but it can vary.

[[Margaret, Maid of Norway]]

CATEGORIES: Norwegian people, Kings and Queens of Scotland, 1283 births, 1290 deaths

Margaret (Margrete Maighread; March/April 1283 – September 1290), was Queen of Scots from 1286 to 1290 after the death of Alexander III of Scotland in 1286.

Margaret was born in Norway.  Her father was King Eric II of Norway and her mother was a Scottish princess, also named Margaret.  Margaret's mother's father was Alexander III, the king of Scotland.  When Alexander died, the Scottish lords decided his granddaughter Margaret should be their queen.  At that time, Margaret was three years old.

The Scottish lords and King Erik agreed that Margaret would marry Edward, an English prince.  Then, Scotland and England would be one kingdom.

In 1290, Margaret got on a ship to go from Norway to Scotland.  On the way, she became sick.  The ship stopped in Orkney, where Margaret died.  She was buried in Bergen, Norway.

[[Domrémy-la-Pucelle]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Vosges

Domrémy-la-Pucelle is a commune of 104 people (2017). It is found in the region Grand Est in the Vosges department in the northeast of France.

It is known for being the birthplace of Joan of Arc (1412–1431).

[[Verona, Pennsylvania]]

CATEGORIES: Boroughs in Pennsylvania

Verona is a borough in Allegheny County, Pennsylvania, in the United States. It is 13 away from Pittsburgh. At the 2010 census, about 2,474 people lived here.

[[Essey-lès-Nancy]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Meurthe-et-Moselle

Essey-lès-Nancy is a commune in the Meurthe-et-Moselle department in north-eastern France.

[[Cyberpunk 2077]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 video games

Cyberpunk 2077 is a 2020 action role-playing video game created by CD Projekt. The story is an open world set in the Cyberpunk universe. 

The game is first-person.

Cyberpunk creator Mike Pondsmith was a consultant, and actor Keanu Reeves has a starring role.

CD Projekt released Cyberpunk 2077 for PlayStation 4, Stadia, Windows, and Xbox One on 10 December 2020, with PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X/S versions planned to come out in 2021.

[[Groupe BPCE]]

CATEGORIES: 2009 establishments

Groupe BPCE is a French banking group, formed by the 2009 merger of CNCE (Caisse Nationale des Caisses d'Epargne) and BFBP (Banque Federale des Banques Populaires), has more than 8,200 branches nationwide under their respective brand names serving nearly 40 million customers. Through its subsidiaries (including Natixis), it provides banking, financial, and real estate financing services to individuals, professionals, small and medium enterprises, large enterprises, and institutions in France and internationally. It provides various deposit and loan products to small and medium enterprises, craftspeople, franchisees, and franchisers; savings collection and management, credit, payment, and wealth management services; and real estate financing and corporate banking services. The company also offers bancassurance products, including life assurance and pensions that comprise automobile and home insurance, legal protection, the guarantee of life accidents, the supplementary health care insurance, welfare professionals and the collective retirement pensions and health, as well as credit insurance and guarantees to individuals, professionals, real estate professionals, and businesses.

[[Carlos do Carmo]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2021 deaths, Portuguese singers, Deaths from aneurysm, People from Lisbon, Eurovision Song Contest entrants

Carlos Manuel de Ascenção do Carmo de Almeida ComIH (21 December 1939 – 1 January 2021) better known as Carlos do Carmo, was a Portuguese fado singer. He began singing and recording in 1963. His first EP record was "Mário Simões e o seu Quarteto Apresentando Carlos do Carmo". His most famous songs are Lágrimas de Orvalho, Lisboa Menina e Moça and Canoas do Tejo. 

Carmo represented Portugal at the 1976 Eurovision Song Contest with "Uma flor de verde pinho". 

Carmo died on 1 January 2021 from problems caused by a ruptured aneurysm in Lisbon, aged 81.

[[Leith Mullings]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, American anthropologists, Jamaican people, Naturalized citizens of the United States, American academics, Writers from New York City, Scientists from New York City, Cancer deaths in New York City

Leith Patricia Mullings (April 8, 1945 – December 13, 2020) was a Jamaican-born author, anthropologist and professor. She was president of the American Anthropological Association from 2011 to 2013. She was a Distinguished Professor of Anthropology at the City University of New York. Mullings was one of the founding members of the Black Radical Congress.

[[Franck Balandier]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, French novelists, French poets

Franck Balandier (11 July 1952 – 17 December 2020) was a French writer. He was a member of the Société des gens de lettres. Balandier wrote his first novel in 1988.

Balandier died on 17 December 2020 in Paris at the age of 68.

[[Lorraine Monk]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2020 deaths

Lorraine Althea Constance Monk CAN (née Spurrell; May 26, 1922 – December 17, 2020) was a Canadian photographer and executive producer. She worked with National Film Board of Canada. Many of her works were seen at the National Gallery of Canada.

She was first made Member of the Order of Canada (1973) and later made Officer of the Order of Canada (1983). She was also a recipient of the Queen Elizabeth II Golden Jubilee Medal (2002), and Order of Ontario (2007).

Monk died on December 17, 2020 in Toronto, Ontario at aged 98.

[[Yvonne Sandberg-Fries]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, Former MEPs, Swedish politicians

Yvonne Sandberg-Fries (14 October 1950 – 20 December 2020) was a Swedish politician. She was a member of the Swedish Social Democratic Party until 2014, when she joined the Green Party. She was a member of the Riksdag from 1982 to 1996. She was also in the European Parliament from 2003 to 2004. She was born in Umeå, Sweden.

Sandberg-Fries died on 20 December 2020 in Blekinge, Sweden at aged 70. 

[[Arnold Wolfendale]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, British astronomers, People from Warwickshire

Sir Arnold Whittaker Wolfendale FRS (25 June 1927 – 21 December, 2020) was a British astronomer. He was Astronomer Royal from 1991 to 1995. He was Emeritus Professor in the Department of Physics at Durham University and was president of the European Physical Society (1999–2001). He was President of the Royal Astronomical Society from 1981 to 1983.

[[Ernst Schütz]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Austrian singers, Austrian movie actors, Austrian stage actors

Ernst Schütz (5 October 1935 – 22 December 2020) was an Austrian singer and actor. He made his debut from 1962 to 1964 at the Graz Opera. In 1966, he moved to Vienna and sang operettas at the Raimund Theater until 1972. He was known for his movie role as Fenton in the 1965 comedy The Merry Wives of Windsor.

Schütz died on 22 December 2020 at the age of 85.

[[George Spriggs (baseball)]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Pittsburgh Pirates players, Kansas City Royals players, Sportspeople from Maryland

Spriggs died on December 22, 2020 in Prince Frederick, Maryland at the age of 83.

[[Irani Barbosa]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil, Brazilian politicians

Irani Barbosa (1950 – 23 December 2020) was a Brazilian politician. He was a member of the Chamber of Deputies from 1991 to 1995. He was elected as a member of the Democratic Movement. Barbosa was born in Belo Horizonte, Minas Gerais.

Barbosa died on 23 December 2020 from COVID-19 in Belo Horizonte at the age of 70.

[[Issaka Assane Karanta]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Nigerien people, Mayors, African politicians, Academics, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic

Issaka Assane Karanta (January 1, 1945 – December 23, 2020) was a Nigerien academic and politician. He was the Mayor of Niamey from 1996 to 1999 and from 2010 to 2011. Karanta also was the Governor of Niamey Capital District from 2018 until his death.

Karanta died of COVID-19 on December 23, 2020, during the pandemic in Niger at the age of 75.

[[Djalma Bastos de Morais]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Brazilian politicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil, Brazilian businesspeople

Djalma Bastos de Morais (16 March 1937 – 25 December 2020) was a Brazilian politician and businessman. He was Minister of Communications from 1993 to 1995. Bastos de Morais was President of CEMIG. He was born in Maceió, Alagoas.

Bastos de Morais died of problems caused by COVID-19 on 25 December 2020 in Rio de Janeiro, aged 83.

[[Deputy Prime Minister of India]]

CATEGORIES: Indian Deputy Prime Ministers

The Deputy Prime Minister of India (IAST: Bhārat kē Uppradhānamantrī) is the deputy head of the Government of India. It is the second highest ranking member of the Union Council of Ministers. A deputy prime minister usually also holds a cabinet portfolio such as the home minister, defence minister or finance minister. In the parliamentary system of government, the prime minister is treated as the "first among equals" in the cabinet; the position of deputy prime minister is used to bring political stability and strength within a coalition government or in times of national emergency, when a proper chain of command is necessary.

The office is having been occupied for a little more than 11 years out of the 73 years since its establisment.

[[George Robert Carruthers]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, American inventors, American physicists, Engineers from Ohio, Scientists from Cincinnati, Ohio

George Robert Carruthers (October 1, 1939 – December 26, 2020) was an American inventor, physicist, engineer and space scientist. He helped create the ultraviolet camera/spectrograph for NASA and they used it on Apollo 16 in 1972. He designed it so astronauts could use it on the lunar surface.

[[Rocco Petrone]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2006 deaths, Deaths from diabetes, Engineers from New York, Scientists from New York

Rocco Anthony Petrone (March 31, 1926 – August 24, 2006) was an American mechanical engineer, U.S. Army officer and NASA official. He was director of launch operations at NASA's Kennedy Space Center (KSC) from 1966 to 1969. He was third director of NASA's Marshall Space Flight Center from 1973 to 1974. He retired from NASA in 1975.

[[Palos Verdes Estates, California]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in California, Settlements in Los Angeles County, California

Palos Verdes Estates (ˈpalos ˈbeɾðes esˈtates) is a city in Los Angeles County, California, United States. 13,438 lived here at the 2010 census.

[[James Bordas]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, French mayors

James Bordas (20 August 1929 – 28 December 2020) was a French politician. He was Mayor of Chambray-lès-Tours from 1981 to 2011. From 1992 to 2001, Bordas was a member of the French Senate. 

Bordas died on 28 December 2020 at the age of 91.

[[Chambray-lès-Tours]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Indre-et-Loire

Chambray-lès-Tours is a commune in the Indre-et-Loire department in central France.

[[Paul Heller]]

CATEGORIES: Movie producers from New York City, 1927 births, 2020 deaths

Paul Heller (also known as Paul M. Heller; 25 September 1927 – 28 December 2020) was an American movie producer. His best known movies include Enter the Dragon, The Wilby Conspiracy, Withnail and I, My Left Foot, The Annihilation of Fish, Skin Games, Hot Potato, The Promise, Black Belt Jones, and David and Lisa.

Heller died on 28 December 2020, aged 93.

[[John Fulton Reid]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cancer, New Zealand cricketers

John Fulton Reid (3 March 1956 – 28 December 2020) was a New Zealand cricketer. He was born in Auckland. Reid played in 19 Test matches and 25 One Day Internationals between 1979 and 1986. From 1975 to 1988, he played for the Auckland cricket team.

Reid died of cancer in Christchurch on 28 December 2020, aged 64.

[[Claude Bolling]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, French pianists, French composers, French movie actors, People from Cannes

Claude Bolling (10 April 1930 – 29 December 2020) was a French jazz pianist, composer, arranger, and actor. He was born in Cannes, France. He was known as the composer of the Lucky Luke animated movies Daisy Town (1971) and La Ballade des Dalton (1978).

Bolling died on 29 December 2020 in Saint-Cloud, France at the age of 90.

[[Agitu Ideo Gudeta]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 births, 2020 deaths, Ethiopian people, African businesspeople, Environmentalists, Deaths by beating, Crime victims

Agitu Ideo Gudeta (አጊቱ ጉደታ; January 1, 1978 − December 29, 2020), was an Ethiopian farmer, businesswoman, and environmentalist. She created a goat farming system using the indigenous breed Pezzata Mòchena to create dairy and beauty products. 

On December 29, 2020, Gudeta was beaten to death with a hammer and raped in her apartment in Frassilongo, Italy at the age of 42.

[[Gregory Ochiagha]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Roman Catholic bishops, Nigerian people

Gregory Obinna Ochiagha (31 August 1931 – 29 December 2020) was a Nigerian Roman Catholic bishop. Ochiagha was born in Orlu, Nigeria. He became a priest in 1960. He was bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Orlu, Nigeria, from 1981 until 2008.

Ochiagha died on 29 December 2020 in Orlu at the age of 89.

[[John Paul Jr. (racing driver)]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, 2020 deaths, American criminals, American racecar drivers, Sportspeople from Indiana, Deaths from neurodegenerative disease, People from Muncie, Indiana

John Lee Paul Jr. (February 19, 1960 – December 29, 2020) was an American racing driver. He competed in CART and the Indy Racing League competitions. He was born in Muncie, Indiana. Paul won the 24 Hours of Daytona twice.

He also was known for drug smuggling.  In May 1986, Paul Jr. received a five-year sentence for racketeering, with the drug charges dropped. 

Paul Jr. died on December 29, 2020 in Los Angeles from problems caused by Huntington's disease, aged 60.

[[Geoffrey Robinson (bishop)]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in Sydney, Australian Roman Catholics, Roman Catholic bishops, People from Sydney

Geoffrey James Robinson (10 August 1937 – 29 December 2020) was an Australian Roman Catholic prelate. He was born in Sydney. He became Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Sydney in 1960. He taught canon law at the Catholic Institute of Sydney. In 1984, he was named an auxiliary bishop of Sydney. Robinson retired in 2004.

Robinson died on 29 December 2020 in Sydney from cancer, aged 83.

MPLA is a communis move in angola in africa MPLA is Participants in the Angolan civil war The MPLA won the civil war in 2002 and killed the leadership of democracy in angola

[[Aldo Andretti]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Italian racecar drivers, American racecar drivers, Sportspeople from Indianapolis, Indiana, Businesspeople from Indianapolis, Indiana

Aldo Andretti (February 28, 1940 – December 30, 2020) was an Italian-born American racing driver. He was the twin brother of Mario Andretti and the father of Adam and John Andretti. He was born in Montona d'Istria, Italy. He raced with USAC and IMCA.

In 1969, Andretti suffered severe facial injuries after crashing during a spring car race in Des Moines. He had face reconstructive surgery.

Andretti died on December 30, 2020 in Indianapolis, Indiana at the age of 80.

[[Guillem Areny]]

CATEGORIES: 1930s births, 2020 deaths, Andorran people, European politicians

Guillem Areny Areny (1931 – 30 December 2020) was an Andorran politician. He was Mayor of La Massana from 1962 to 1963. He also was a member of the Council General from 1966 to 1969 and again from 1974 to 1981.

Areny died on 30 December 2020, aged 89.

[[General Council (Andorra)]]

CATEGORIES: Andorra

The General Council (Consell General d'Andorra, kunˈsɛʎ ʒənəˈɾal dənˈdorə) is the unicameral parliament of Andorra. It is sometimes known as the General Council of the Valleys because it was the historical name and it is to make it different from similarly named parliaments in the Val d'Aran and in France.

[[Jos Compaan]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, 2020 deaths, Dutch Olympians, Rowers

Jos Compaan (2 July 1958 – 30 December 2020) was a Dutch rower. She competed at the 1980 Summer Olympics, 1984 Summer Olympics and the 1988 Summer Olympics. Compaan was born in Purmerend, Netherlands.

Compaan died on 30 December 2020 at the age of 62.

[[Josep Corominas i Busqueta]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Spanish politicians, Spanish physicians

Josep Corominas i Busqueta (24 March 1939 – 30 December 2020) was a Spanish physician and politician. He was a member of the Congress of Deputies from 1989 and 2000. He also was Grand Master of the Spain's Grand Lodge from 2002 and 2006.

Corominas i Busqueta died in Barcelona on 30 December 2020 at the age of 81.

[[Andrew Han Jingtao]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2020 deaths, Roman Catholic bishops, Chinese people

Andrew Han Jingtao (韩井涛; 26 July 1921 – 30 December 2020) was a Chinese Catholic prelate. He was the Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Sipingjie from 1982 until his death. He became a priest in 1947. He was born in Jilin, China.

Han Jingtao died on 30 December 2020, aged 99.

[[Samuel Little]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, People who died in prison custody in the United States, American serial killers, American rapists, People from Georgia (U.S. state)

Samuel Little (June 7, 1940 – December 30, 2020) was an American serial killer and serial rapist. He was convicted in 2012 of the murders of three women in California between 1987 and 1989 as well as in 2018 of the murder of one woman in Texas in 1994. 

He claimed to have killed as many as 93 women, and investigators had evidence that related him to 60 murders. 

The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) said Little's killed at least 50 people, the largest number of proven cases for any serial killer in United States history. He allegedly murdered women across 19 states over a third of a century ending around 2005. Little was born in Reynolds, Georgia.

Little died in prison in Los Angeles County, California on December 30, 2020 at the age of 80.

[[Reynolds, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Georgia (U.S. state)

Reynolds is a town in Taylor County, Georgia, United States. 1,086 lived here at the 2010 census.

[[Yehoshua Matza]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Israeli politicians, Israeli businesspeople, Economists, People from Jerusalem

Yehoshua Matza (יהושע מצא,  8 August 1931 – 30 December 2020) was an Israeli politician, economist and businessman. He was president and CEO of State of Israel Bonds. From 1984 to 2002, he was a member of the Likud. From 1996 to 1999, Matza was Minister of Health during the first Benjamin Netanyahu cabinet. Matza was born in Jerusalem.

Matza died on 30 December 2020 in Jerusalem at the age of 89.

[[Martha Navarro]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Mexican movie actors, Mexican television actors, Mexican stage actors, Actors from Mexico City

Martha Navarro (27 December 1937 – 30 December 2020) was a Mexican actress. She was born in Mexico City. Her career began in 1967. Navarro was known for her roles in El asesino se embarca, The Garden of Aunt Isabel and The Holy Office. She also appeared in many telenovelas.

Navarro died on 30 December 2020 in Mexico City, just three days after her 83rd birthday.

[[Panusunan Pasaribu]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Indonesian politicians

Panusunan Pasaribu (22 June 1946 – 30 December 2020) was an Indonesian politician. He was born in Padangsidimpuan, Indonesia. He was the Regent of the Central Tapanuli Regency from 1995 until 2001. From 2015 until his death, he was a member of the board of trustees for the University of North Sumatra.

Pasaribu died on 30 December 2020 in Padangsidimpuan at the age of 74.

[[Alto Reed]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from colorectal cancer, American jazz musicians, American rock musicians, American pop musicians, American funk musicians, American saxophonists, Musicians from Detroit, Michigan

Alto Reed (born Thomas  Neal Cartmell, May 16, 1948 – December 30, 2020) was an American saxophonist. He was best known as a long-time member of Bob Seger and the Silver Bullet Band. He also was a member of the Grand Funk Railroad. Reed was born in Detroit, Michigan. His career began in 1972.

Reed died of problems caused by colon cancer in Detroit on December 30, 2020. He was 72 years old.

[[Shabba Doo]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2020 deaths, American choreographers, American dancers, American movie actors, Actors from Chicago

Adolfo Gutierrez Quiñones or Adolfo Gordon Quiñones (May 11, 1955 – December 30, 2020), known professionally as Shabba Doo, was an American actor, dancer, and choreographer. He was born in Chicago, Illinois. Quiñones played Orlando "Ozone" in the 1984 breakdancing movie Breakin' and its sequel, Breakin' 2: Electric Boogaloo.

Quiñones died of a short-illness at his Los Angeles home on December 30, 2020 at the age of 65.

[[LaWanna Shurtliff]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Wyoming, Politicians from Utah, People from Ogden, Utah, US Democratic Party politicians

LaWanna "Lou" Shurtliff (June 13, 1935 – December 30, 2020) was an American Democratic politician. He was a member of the Utah House of Representatives from 1999 through 2008 and from 2019 until her death. Shurtliff was born in Lincoln County, Wyoming.

Shurtliff died of pneumonia in Ogden, Utah on December 30, 2020 at the age of 85.

[[Alexander Spirin]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Russian chemists

Alexander Sergeevich Spirin (Russian: Александр Сергеевич Спирин) (4 September 1931 – 30 December 2020) was a Russian biochemist. He was a Distinguished Professor at the Lomonosov Moscow State University. His works focused on nucleic acids and protein biosynthesis. In 1974 he was elected a Member of the German Academy of Sciences Leopoldina. He was elected a foreign associate of the US National Academy of Sciences in April 2019.

Spirin died on 30 December 2020 at the age of 89.

[[Eugene Wright]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, American bass guitarists, American jazz musicians, Musicians from Chicago

Eugene Joseph Wright (May 29, 1923 – December 30, 2020) was an American jazz bassist. He was a member of the Dave Brubeck Quartet.

Wright died on December 30, 2020 in Los Angeles at the age of 97.

[[Grace L. Drake]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Ohio, Politicians from Connecticut, US Republican Party politicians

Grace L. Drake (1926 – 31 December 2020) was an American politician. She was a member of the Ohio Senate from 1984 to 2000. Drake was a member of the Republican Party. She was born in Connecticut.

Drake died on 31 December 2020 at the age of 94.

[[Jolanta Fedak]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, 2020 deaths, Polish politicians

Jolanta Beata Fedak (21 September 1960 – 31 December 2020) was a Polish politician. She was Minister of Labour and Social Policy from 2007 to 2011 during the Donald Tusk cabinet. She was a member of the Polish People's Party. In 2019, Fedak was elected to the Sejm.

Fedak died in Warsaw on 31 December 2020, aged 60. 

[[Michael Kindo]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Indian Olympic bronze medalists, Field hockey players

Michael Kindo (20 June 1947 – 31 December 2020) was an Indian field hockey player. He was born in Odisha, India. He represented India in 1972 Summer Olympics and won the bronze medal. He was a member of the team that won the World Cup in 1975. 

Kindo died on 31 December 2020 at the age of 73.

[[Olivier Royant]]

CATEGORIES: French journalists, 1962 births, 2020 deaths

Olivier Royant (16 July 1962 – 31 December 2020) was a French journalist. He directed the weekly magazine Paris Match. He was born in Rostrenen, France. 

Royant died in Paris from a long-illness on 31 December 2020 at the age of 58.

[[Narsing Yadav]]

CATEGORIES: 1968 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from kidney disease, Indian movie actors, Indian television actors, Indian comedians

Narsing Yadav (15 May 1963 – 31 December 2020) was an Indian actor and comedian. He was born in Hyderabad, India. His career began in 1983. His best known roles were in Kshana Kshanam, Gaayam, Mutha Mestri, Mass, Shankar Dada M.B.B.S., Anukokunda Oka Roju and Nuvvostanante Nenoddantana.

Yadav died on 31 December 2020 from kidney disease in Hyderabad at the age of 57.

[[Roy B. B. Janis]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, 2020 deaths, Indonesian politicians

Roy Binilang Bawatanusa Janis (22 August 1957 – 28 December 2020) was an Indonesian politician. From 1992 to 1997, he was a member of the People's Consultative Assembly. From 1999 to 2005, Janis was a member of the People's Representative Council. In 2005, he became the first chairman of the Democratic Renewal Party. He was born in Jakarta, Indonesia.

Janis died at a Jakarta hospital on 28 December 2020, aged 63.

[[Muhammad Arif (Indonesian politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, 2021 deaths, Indonesian politicians, Deaths from myocardial infarction

Muhammad Arif (1976 – 1 January 2021) was an Indonesian politician. He was elected to the People's Consultative Assembly in 2004. He represented the Riau Islands. He was born in Tanjungpinang, Indonesia.

Arif died of heart attack on 1 January 2021 in Tanjungpinang, aged 44.

[[Traude Dierdorf]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2021 deaths, Mayors, Austrian politicians

Traude Dierdorf (17 November 1947 – 1 January 2021) was an Austrian politician. In 1997 she was elected first mayor of Wiener Neustadt. In 2005, she resigned for health reasons. Dierdorf was a member of the Social Democratic Party.

Dierdorf died on 1 January 2021, at the age of 73.

[[Mark Eden]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from Alzheimer's disease, English television actors, English movie actors, English stage actors, Actors from London

Douglas John Malin (14 February 1928 – 1 January 2021), known as Mark Eden, was an English actor. He played Alan Bradley in Coronation Street from 1986 to 1989. In 1964, he played Marco Polo in Doctor Who. Eden was born in London. His career began in 1958 and he retired in 2013.

Eden died on 1 January 2021 at a hospital in London from problems caused by Alzheimer's disease, aged 92.

[[Dan Fogler]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, Living people, Tony Award winning actors, American movie actors, American stage actors, American television actors, American voice actors, Actors from New York City, Writers from New York City, Comedians from New York City

Daniel Kevin Fogler (born October 20, 1976) is an American actor, comedian and writer. In 2005, he won a Tony Award.

He had roles in Balls of Fury, Good Luck Chuck, Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them, Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald, Kung Fu Panda, Horton Hears a Who!, and Mars Needs Moms. 

[[Charles Osgood]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, Living people, American voice actors, American television news anchors, American radio personalities, Television personalities from New York City, Actors from New York City

Charles Osgood Wood III (born January 8, 1933), known professionally as Charles Osgood, is a retired American radio and television commentator and writer. He was born in New York City.

Osgood is best known for being the host of CBS News Sunday Morning from April 10, 1994, until September 25, 2016. He was also the narrator of the 2008 animated movie Horton Hears a Who!.

[[Niecy Nash]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American television producers, American television presenters, Models from California, Actors from California, Businesspeople from California, Television personalities from California, Comedians from California

Carol Denise Nash (née Ensley; born February 23, 1970) is an American comedian, actress, television host, model, and producer.

Nash hosted the Style Network show Clean House from 2003 to 2010. She won an Emmy Award in 2010. She played the role of Deputy Raineesha Williams in the Comedy Central comedy series Reno 911! (2003–2009).

[[2020 Aden attacks]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 crimes in Asia, 2020s explosions in Asia, 21st century in Yemen, Attacks on buildings and structures in Asia, Attacks on buildings and structures in the 2020s, December 2020 events, Explosions in 2020, Mass shootings in Asia, Mass shootings in the 2020s, Terrorist incidents in 2020, Terrorist incidents in Asia in the 2020s

On 30 December 2020, a plane which had members of the newly formed Yemeni government landed at Aden International Airport in the southwest of Yemen. As passengers left the plane, there were explosions and gunfire. 25 people were killed and 110 others injured.

[[Aden International Airport]]

CATEGORIES: Yemen, Airports in Asia

Aden International Airport is an international airport in Aden, Yemen.

It was a Soviet Air Force station during the 1970s and 1980s. The new terminal was built between 1983 and 1985.

During the Yemeni Civil War in the Aftermath of the Houthi takeover in Yemen, the city of Aden, including its airport, became a battleground. The Battle of Aden Airport took place on 19 March 2015.

On 22 July 2015, the airport was re-opened for civilian use. 

[[Dangerous Lies (2020 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 movies, 2020s thriller movies, Netflix movies, American thriller movies, Movies set in Chicago, Illinois

Dangerous Lies is a 2020 American thriller movie, directed by Michael Scott from a screenplay by David Golden. It stars Camila Mendes, Jessie T. Usher, Jamie Chung, Cam Gigandet, Sasha Alexander, Elliott Gould and Radhesh Aria. It was released on April 30, 2020, by Netflix. It had negative reviews. It is set in Chicago, Illinois however it was filmed in Vancouver, British Columbia.

[[Bryan Greenberg]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 births, Living people, Jewish American actors, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American stage actors, Actors from Omaha, Nebraska, Singers from Omaha, Nebraska, Actors from St. Louis, Missouri, Singers from St. Louis, Missouri

Bryan Greenberg (born May 24, 1978) is an American actor and singer. He played Ben Epstein in the HBO original series How to Make It in America, Jake Jagielski in the WB series One Tree Hill and as Nick Garrett on the short-lived ABC drama October Road.

[[34+35]]

CATEGORIES: Ariana Grande songs, 2020 songs, Songs about sexuality, 2021 songs

|producer=

"34+35" is a song recorded by American singer Ariana Grande, as the second track on her sixth studio album, Positions (2020). It was released as a single on October 30, 2020. The song was written by Grande, Albert Stanaj, Courageous Xavier Herrera, Scott Nicholson, Steven Franks, Tayla Parx, Victoria Monét, and its producers Peter Lee Johnson and Tommy Brown.  It runs for two minutes and 54 seconds. 

On October 30, 2020, the song was released by Republic Records as the second single from the album. The song's title and overall theme is about the 69 sex position with some sex jokes.

On January 15, 2021, a remix of the song featuring American rappers Doja Cat and Megan Thee Stallion was released with verses written by the artists. It is eight seconds longer than the original.

The song entered at number eight on the Billboard Hot 100 upon the album's release. Combined with sales of the remix, the song later peaked at number two in the US. 

[[Victoria Monét]]

CATEGORIES: 1993 births, Living people, American singer-songwriters, American pop singers, American R&B singers, Singers from Georgia (U.S. state), Writers from Georgia (U.S. state), Singers from Sacramento, California, Writers from Sacramento, California

Victoria Monét McCants (born May 1, 1993) is an American singer-songwriter. 

Monét has written songs for many singer such as Nas, Ariana Grande, Fifth Harmony, T.I., GOOD Music, Lupe Fiasco, Chrisette Michele, Coco Jones, Chris Brown, and Diddy Dirty Money. 

In 2019, Monét received two Grammy Award nominations for Album of the Year for her work on Grande's Thank U, Next and Record of the Year for "7 Rings".

[[Jabba the Hutt]]

CATEGORIES: Fictional characters introduced in 1977, Fictional characters introduced in 1983, Star Wars characters, Star Wars Skywalker Saga characters, Supervillains

Jabba the Hutt was a crime lord who operated from Tatooine. Jabba is a male who is part of the Hutt species. Jabba first appeared in Star Wars Episode VI: Return of the Jedi where he was killed by Princess Leia Organa during the rescue of Han Solo. Jabba had placed a bounty on Han Solo's head after Han failed to deliver a shipment. The bounty hunter, Boba Fett captured Han and brought him to Jabba. Jabba also appeared in Star Wars Episode I: The Phantom Menace where he was at the Boonta Eve podrace.

[[Regulations for the Order and Discipline of the Troops of the United States]]

CATEGORIES: American Revolutionary War, Books

The Regulations for the Order and Discipline of the Troops of the United States or Blue Book is an American army book from the Revolutionary War.  It is about how to teach soldiers to be good soldiers.  Friedrich Wilhelm von Steuben wrote the first version in 1777 and 1778 at Valley Forge. George Washington, Alexander Hamilton and other officers in the Continental Army helped.  Von Steuben rewrote the book a year later.

At Valley Forge in the winter of 1777-1778, Acting Inspector General von Steuben saw that many Continental officers gave their men different drills. Drills are practice exercises.  Using different drills meant the men might become confused in a real battle.  Von Steuben wrote new drills for the whole army.  He wrote them French.  His aide-de-camp, Pierre Ettienne Duponceau, and George Washington's aides-de-camp, Alexander Hamilton and John Laurens rewrote them in English.  General George Washington would read the drills and make changes. They gave each lesson to the officers one at a time.  Then the officers or their helpers made their own copies.  Then van Steuben and the officers would use the drills with the men.

The next year, in Philadelphia, von Steuben wrote down his Valley Forge drills in one book.  He wrote it in French.  Lieutenant Colonel Francois de Fleury helped.  Then Captain Benjamin Walker and Duponceu rewrote the book in English.  Captain Pierre Charles L'Enfant drew the pictures.

Congress decided to use the book starting in 1779.  The American military used the Blue Book until 1814.

[[Blue Book]]

CATEGORIES: Disambiguation pages

Blue Book may mean:

[[European Investment Bank]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 establishments in Europe, Companies of Europe, Banks, European Union

The European Investment Bank (EIB) is a publicly owned international financial institution whose shareholders are the EU member states. It was created in 1958 under the Treaty of Rome as a "policy-driven bank" using financing operations to further EU policy goals such as European integration and social cohesion. It should not be confused with the European Central Bank, which is based in Frankfurt (Germany) or with the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) which is based in London (United Kingdom).

The member states set the bank's broad policy goals and oversee the decision-making bodies of the bank: its board of governors and board of directors. It is the world's largest international public lending institution.

[[Kelli Berglund]]

CATEGORIES: 1996 births, American television actors, American movie actors, American child actors, Actors from California, Living people

Kelli Berglund (born February 9, 1996) is an American actress. She is known for playing Bree Davenport in the Disney XD series Lab Rats and its spin-off Lab Rats: Elite Force. In 2014, she played Mae Hartley in the Disney Channel Original Movie How to Build a Better Boy. She later played Carly Carson in the 2019 Starz television drama series Now Apocalypse. 

Berglund has been honored with many awards for her lyrical contemporary music and jazz.

Berglund was born in Moorpark, California.

[[Colour by Numbers]]

CATEGORIES: 1983 albums

Colour by Numbers is the second album by Culture Club. It was released on 10 October 1983. 

The songs on it are Karma Chameleon, It's a Miracle, Black Money, Changing Every Day, That's The Way (I'm Only Trying To Help You),  Church Of The Poison Mind, Miss Me Blind, Mister Man, Stormkeeper, and Victims.

In the UK it was the number one album for 5 weeks in 1983.

[[Dies irae]]

CATEGORIES: 13th century, Catholicism, Christian hymns, Poems, Latin language

"Dies irae" (ˈdi.es ˈi.re; "the Day of Wrath") is a Latin chant first written by either Thomas of Celano of the Franciscans (1200–c.1265) or Latino Malabranca Orsini (d. 1294), lector at the Dominican studium at Santa Sabina, in Rome. It comes from at least the 13th century, but it could be much older. Some have said it was written by St. Gregory the Great (died 604), Bernard of Clairvaux (1090–1153), or Bonaventure (1221–1274).

It is a poem in Medieval Latin with accentual stress and rhymed lines. The metre is trochaic. It is about the Last Judgment. It is known for being used at the Requiem (funeral mass).

The first melody to these words is used a lot in musical literature. Many recent movies like The Shining and The Lion King have used it.

[[Michael Nunn]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, Sportspeople from Iowa, People from Davenport, Iowa, African-American boxers, Living people

Michael Nunn (born April 14, 1963) is an American former professional boxer. He competed from 1984 to 2002. He is a two-weight world champion. Nunn held the International Boxing Federation (IBF) middleweight title, 1988 to 1991. He held the super middleweight title, 1992 to 1994. During these reigns, he held the lineal championship.

Nunn was born in Davenport, Iowa.

Louis Jean Joseph Charles Blanc (29 October 1811 – 6 December 1882) was a French politician and historian.

He is famous for helping the development of socialism in France.

[[Hutt]]

CATEGORIES: Star Wars species

Hutts are a slug-like species from Star Wars. Hutts are very large in size and are very heavy. They are most well known as crime lords and run the crime worlds of Star Wars. Hutts control their own area of the galaxy known as "Hutt Space" which the Hutts have controlled for thousands of years. Hutts come from the swampy crime world of Nal Hutta but are all over the galaxy. Jabba the Hutt is the most well known member of the species. The species first appeared in Star Wars Episode VI: Return of the Jedi and have also appeared in Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope (albeit through the special edition) and Star Wars Episode I: The Phantom Menace.
