Monster House is a 2006 computer-animated movie. It is directed by Gil Kenan, written by Dan Harmon, Rob Schrab and Pamela Pettler, It stars the voices of Mitchel Musso, Sam Lerner, Spencer Locke, Steve Buscemi, Maggie Gyllenhaal, Kevin James, Nick Cannon, Jason Lee, Fred Willard, Jon Heder, Catherine O'Hara and Kathleen Turner.

[[Dick Kulpa]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2021 deaths, American cartoonists, Artists from Illinois, Cancer deaths in Florida, Deputy mayors, Politicians from Illinois

Richard Allen Kulpa (January 12, 1953 – January 3, 2021) was an American cartoonist. His cartoons were in satire magazines such as Cracked and Weekly World News. He was born in Loves Park, Illinois, and also was an alderman for the city.

On January 3, 2021, Kulpa died of cancer in Boynton Beach, Florida. He was 67.

[[Eric Jerome Dickey]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, 2021 deaths, African American writers, American novelists, Cancer deaths in Los Angeles, Writers from Memphis, Tennessee

Eric Jerome Dickey (July 7, 1961 – January 3, 2021) was an American author. He wrote novels about contemporary African-American life. He also wrote crime novels about grifters, former convicts and assassins. He was a New York Times bestselling author. Dickey was born in Memphis, Tennessee. He went to the University of Memphis. 

Dickey died of cancer in Los Angeles, California, on January 3, 2021. He was 59.

[[Bronny James]]

CATEGORIES: 2004 births, Living people, African-American basketball players, American basketball players

LeBron "Bronny" Raymone James Jr. (l; born October 6, 2004) he is an American basketball player who attends Sierra Canyon School in Los Angeles. He is the elder son of professional basketball player LeBron James.

[[Bardufoss concentration camp]]

CATEGORIES: 20th century establishments in Norway, 1944 establishments in Europe, Nazi concentration camps in Norway

The Bardufoss concentration camp was in Northern Norway in the municipality of Målselv. During the occupation of Norway by Nazi Germany, the Nazi authorities made a "concentration camp in the town of Bardufoss," as an annex to the Grini concentration camp. It opened in March 1944 because other camps were too crowded, particularly Grini and the Falstad concentration camp. The area was cold. The camp had a very bad reputation for hard work, little food, and not enough shelter. It is estimated that 800 prisoners passed through the camp. About 550 were still there when the camp was liberated.

[[South Dakota Senate]]

CATEGORIES: South Dakota, State upper houses in the United States

The South Dakota Senate is the upper house of the U.S. state of the South Dakota state legislature.

[[Matt Servitto]]

CATEGORIES: 1965 births, Living people, Actors from New Jersey, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, People from Teaneck, New Jersey

Matthew Joseph Servitto (born April 7, 1965) is an American actor. He is best known for his role as FBI agent Dwight Harris in the HBO crime drama The Sopranos (1999–2007). His other television roles include Trask Bodine in All My Children (1989–1990), Donald Donatelle in Brotherhood (2006–2008) and Brock Lotus in Banshee (2013–2016). He has also appeared in movies such as Two Family House (2000) and Hitch (2005).

Servitto was born in Teaneck, New Jersey. He is a graduate of the Juilliard School in New York City.

[[Jack Thompson (actor)]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, Living people, Actors from Sydney, Australian movie actors, Australian television actors, Order of Australia

Jack Thompson AM (born John Hadley Payne; 31 August 1940) is an Australian actor. He is best known for his roles in Australian movies such as Sunday Too Far Away (1975), Breaker Morant (1980), The Club (1980) and The Man from Snowy River (1982). In 2002, he was made an honorary member of the Australian Cinematographers Society (ACS).

Thompson was born in Manly, a suburb of Sydney, New South Wales. He went to the University of Queensland in Brisbane. He has two children.

[[Martinus J. G. Veltman]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2021 deaths, Dutch academics, Dutch Nobel Prize winners, Dutch physicists, People from North Brabant, Theoretical physicists

Martinus Justinus Godefriedus Veltman (27 June 1931 – 4 January 2021) was a Dutch theoretical physicist. He shared the 1999 Nobel Prize in Physics with his Ph.D. student Gerard 't Hooft for their work on particle theory. He worked at Utrecht University, and later the University of Michigan in the United States. Veltman was born in Waalwijk, North Brabant. 

Veltman died on 4 January 2021 in Bilthoven, Utrecht. He was 89.

[[Brestskaya Gazeta]]

CATEGORIES: 2002 establishments in Europe, Newspapers in Belarus, Websites, Censorship in Belarus

Brestskaya Gazeta (Брестская газета) is a non-governmental newspaper from Brest, Belarus. Its first number came on November 18, 2002. The main language of the newspaper and its website is Russian, but some stories are written in Belarusian. Its latest number came on December 30, 2020.

It has been writing about the 2020 Belarusian protests and 2020 Belarusian presidential election, so several journalists of the Brest newspaper have been tried and arrested for that.

In October 2020, the newspaper joined a common statement by the Belarusian Association of Journalists and private media companies on the troubles of TUT.BY and limits on the use of private websites. The newspaper took a strong civil position against violence in writing about the Belarusian protests. The newspaper started buying and sending its copies to political prisoners. Brestskaya Gazeta printed their answers to its letters in prisons.

In late November, it became known that the Brest Regional Printing House, where the newspaper had been printed for 18 years, had said no to printing it starting 2021 for no reason; the fax was signed by Vyacheslav Shakhlevich, chief of the printing house.

The United Mass Media requested Shakhlevich, the Brest City and Regional Executive Committees, and the Ministry of Information to make possible to change the decision that created "troubles for the well liked private regional publication." Chief of the Belarusian Association of Journalists Andrei Bastunets said that the troubles made to Brestskaya Gazeta support the government' pressure on the regional news media, as "the fact that this is happening at the level of economic objects should make anyone foolish."

To stay away from punishment for not made transportation, it was chosen in time to give up on Belposhta's (Belpost (Белпошта), Belarusian postal service) subscription services for the first part of 2021. On January 19, 2021, it became known that Brestskaya Gazeta has stopped to be made for now. All printing houses in Belarus had made decisions not to print the newspaper.

On July 8, 2021, the office and the houses of its main people were looked for. Two days later Brestskaya Gazeta said that all the technical devices (computers. smartphones and tools like that) of its people were taken away.

[[Harald Maartmann]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2021 deaths, Sportspeople from Oslo, Norwegian Olympians, Skiers

Harald Rolf Maartmann (5 January 1926 – 1 January 2021) was a Norwegian cross-country skier. He competed in the 1950s. He won both the 17 km and the 50 km event in the Norwegian Championships in 1950. Maartmann also finished eighth in the 50 km event at the 1952 Winter Olympics in Oslo.

Maartmann died on 1 January 2021 in Oslo, aged 94.

[[Albert Roux]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2021 deaths, French chefs, French businesspeople

Albert Henri Roux GBR (8 October 1935 – 4 January 2021) was a French restaurateur and chef. 

He and his brother Michel ran Le Gavroche, the first restaurant in the UK to gain three Michelin stars. 

[[Joseph Zong Huaide (Shaanxi)]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, 2021 deaths, Centenarians, Roman Catholic bishops

Joseph Zong Huaide (宗怀德; 5 March 1920 – 5 January 2021) was a Chinese Roman Catholic prelate. He was the Roman Catholic Bishop of Roman Catholic Diocese of Shaanxi, China from 1987 to 2003. He was born in Sanyuan County, China. 

Zong died in Sanyuan in January 2021 at the age of 100.

[[Goldikova]]

CATEGORIES: 2005 births, 2021 deaths, Thoroughbred racehorses

Goldikova (foaled 15 March 2005 – 6 January 2021) was a champion Thoroughbred racemare. She has also raced in the United States and England. She has won 14 Group One races, with nine victories over colts and geldings. Goldikova was the only horse to win three (2008, 2009, 2010)  Breeders' Cup Mile races. She was ridden by Olivier Peslier. She retired in 2011. 

Goldikova died on 6 January 2021, aged 15.

[[Danilo Lim]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2021 deaths, Filipino military people, Generals, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the Philippines

Danilo Delapuz Lim (June 2, 1955 – January 6, 2021) was a Filipino brigadier general. He was Chairman of the Metropolitan Manila Development Authority from 2017 until his death in 2021. 

He was in jail at Camp Crame in Quezon City from 2006 to 2010 for rebellion charges and an attempted coup d'état. After more than 4 years in prison, Lim was granted temporary freedom by the Armed Forces of the Philippines on May 31, 2010.

Lim tested positive for COVID-19 on December 29, 2020. He died on January 6, 2021 from the infection at the age of 65.

[[Wendy Sherman]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, Living people, American academics, Politicians from Baltimore, Maryland, US Democratic Party politicians, United States Deputy Secretaries of State

Wendy Ruth Sherman (born June 7, 1949) is an American professor and diplomat. Sherman has been the United States Deputy Secretary of State since April 14, 2021. She is a professor of public leadership and director of the Center for Public Leadership at the Harvard Kennedy School. She was also the lead negotiator for the Iran nuclear deal.

On January 5, 2021 President-elect Joe Biden nominated Sherman to be United States Deputy Secretary of State under Antony Blinken. She was confirmed to the United States Senate on April 13, 2021.

[[International Society for Human Rights]]

CATEGORIES: International organizations, Human rights organizations in Europe, Frankfurt, 1972 establishments in Europe, 1970s establishments in Germany, Non-profit organizations of Europe

The International Society for Human Rights (ISHR) (Internationale Gesellschaft für Menschenrechte, IGFM) is an international non-governmental, non-profit human rights organization with Participative Status with the Council of Europe. It is a member of the Liaison Committee of the Non-Governmental Organizations at the Council of Europe. The ISHR has a right to watch for the African Commission of Human and Peoples' Rights. It is a friend of the Department of Public Information of the United Nations and can speak right to the United Nations Economic and Social Council.

The house of the ISHR is in Frankfurt am Main, Germany. The organization was made in West Germany in 1972. It was named the Society for Human Rights (die Gesellschaft für Menschenrechte). The organization became the International Society for Human Rights in 1982, when its branches in Austria, Switzerland, the UK, and France were made. Since then it has got bigger to be made up of 47 National Sections, National Groups, Regional Committees, and Affiliated Organisations worldwide. 

[[Mammal Species of the World]]

CATEGORIES: Biology books

Mammal Species of the World: A Taxonomic and Geographic Reference is a standard reference work in mammalogy giving descriptions and bibliographic data for the known species of mammals. It is now in its third edition, published in late 2005, which was edited by Don E. Wilson and DeeAnn M. Reeder.

[[Gigablaster]]

CATEGORIES: 2019 television series debuts, Brazilian television series, Animated television series

Gigablaster is a Brazilian Animated Series produced by TeamTO and Cake Entertainment in co-production with Gloob It is written by Eric Shaw.

The Gigablaster family of characters has a very playful blue rhinoceros, a shy DJ, an explosive guitarist, and an absent-minded, deaf zombie. They live in a karaoke in a large city. Together, Giga, Ziggy and Rubi are part of a band managed by Cool Daddy. They end up getting in trouble with villains ranging from Shimeji God to GossipCam Paparazzi.

[[Christine Leunens]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, Living people, Belgian novelists, New Zealand writers, Writers from Hartford, Connecticut

Christine Leunens (born 29 December 1964) is a New Zealand-Belgian author. She wrote the novels Primordial Soup (1999), Caging Skies (2008) and A Can of Sunshine (2013). The movie Jojo Rabbit (2019), directed by Taika Waititi, was based on Caging Skies. Waititi won an Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay for the movie.

Leunens was born in Hartford, Connecticut, United States. Her mother is Italian and her father is Belgian. She's lived mostly in Europe and New Zealand. She is a citizen of both New Zealand and Belgium. She is married and has three children.

[[Vakhtang Gomelauri]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 births, Politicians from Tbilisi, Living people

Vakhtang Gomelauri (ვახტანგ გომელაური, born 24 December 1974) is a Georgian politician, who is the current Minister of Internal Affairs of Georgia. He was head of the State Security Service of Georgia from 25 July 2015 to 9 September 2019.

[[Ekaterine Tikaradze]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, Government ministers of Georgia (country), Living people

Ekaterine (Eka) Tikaradze (ეკატერინე (ეკა) ტიკარაძე; b. 3 March 1976) is a Georgian politician who is Minister of Internally Displaced Persons from the Occupied Territories of Georgia, Labor, Health and Social Affairs of Georgia since 18 June 2019.

Qwant is a privacy-oriented search engine, originated and hosted in France, and is available in 13 languages. It has over  50 million total visits worldwide.

[[PATH Transit]]

CATEGORIES: Rapid transit systems in the United States

The PATH , known as Port Authority Transit  is a 13.8 mile 22.2 kilometers rapid transit system in the the northeastern New Jersey Cities of Newark , Harrison , Jersey City and Hoboken and Lower and Midtown Manhattan in New York City . It is operated as a wholly owned subsidiary of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. PATH trains run around the clock year around; four routes serving 13 stations operate during the daytime on weekends while two routes operate during weekends , late nights, and holidays. its tracks cross the Hudson River through century old cast  iron tubes that rests on the river bottom under a thin layer of silt it operates as a deep level subway in Manhattan and the Jersey City/Hoboken riverfront; from Grove Street in Jersey City to Newark , trains run in open cuts , at grade level, and on elevated track.

[[1918 Stanley Cup playoffs]]

CATEGORIES: 1910s in Canada, 1918 in ice hockey, Stanley Cup playoffs, March events

The 1918 Stanley Cup playoffs were played from March 11 until March 30, when the National Hockey League (NHL) champion Toronto Blue Shirts defeated the Pacific Coast Hockey Association (PCHA) champion Vancouver Millionaires for the Stanley Cup.

[[Acela Express]]

CATEGORIES: 2000 establishments in the United States, Amtrak, Rail transport in the United States, High-speed trains

Acela Express is Amtrak's flagship high-speed train service.  It runs along the Northeast Corridor, which is in the northeastern United States between Washington D.C. and Boston. It has 16 stops, including Providence, Rhode Island; Baltimore, Maryland; Philadelphia and New York City. The route has some places with high speed rail. Acela trains are the fastest trainsets in the Americas. They can move 150 mph (240 km/m) on 33.9 mi 54.6 on the route. Acela carried more than 3.4 million passengers in 2016.  Only Northeast Regional carried more people then, over 8 million. Its 2016 revenue was US$585 million, 25% of Amtrak's total.

[[2020–21 United States Senate special election in Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 elections, 2021 elections, Elections in the United States, Georgia (U.S. state), January 2021 events, November 2020 events

A special election was held to elect a Senator from the U.S. state of Georgia in two rounds on November 3, 2020; and January 5, 2021. It was held because  Republican Class III Senator Johnny Isakson resigned. Raphael Warnock got the most votes with 32.9%, and Kelly Loeffler came in second with 25.9% in the first round. Because no one got more than 50% of votes, a second round was held between the two highest. Warnock is projected to win the second round of the election.  The regular Class II election was also held on the same dates with two rounds.

[[Ras Murphy]]

CATEGORIES: 1886 births, 1975 deaths, Canadian ice hockey defencemen, Ice hockey people from Ontario, Montreal Wanderers (NHA) players, People from Ottawa

Erastus Booth Murphy (March 1, 1886 – March 10, 1975) was a Canadian professional ice hockey player. He played with the Montreal Wanderers of the National Hockey Association.

[[Pierre Vézina (ice hockey)]]

CATEGORIES: 1885 births, 1944 deaths, Canadian ice hockey defencemen, Ice hockey people from Quebec, Montreal Canadiens (NHA) players

Charles Pierre Vézina (b. June 29, 1885 – d. July 24, 1944) was a Canadian professional ice hockey player. He played with the Montreal Canadiens of the National Hockey Association in the 1911–12 season for one game and scored no goals. He was the brother of Georges Vézina.

CATEGORIES: 1885 births, 1955 deaths, Canadian ice hockey right wingers, Ice hockey people from Ontario, Montreal Wanderers (NHA) players

Edwin McGregor (February 9, 1885 – February 8, 1955) was a Canadian professional ice hockey player. He played with the Montreal Wanderers of the National Hockey Association.

[[George Warwick]]

CATEGORIES: 1890 births, 1964 deaths, Canadian ice hockey goaltenders, Montreal Wanderers (NHA) players, Ice hockey people from Ontario

George William Warwick (May 1, 1890 – September 28, 1964) was a Canadian professional ice hockey player. He played with the Montreal Wanderers of the National Hockey Association during the 1913–14 NHA season.

[[2021 United States Capitol attack]]

CATEGORIES: 2021 crimes in the United States, 2020 United States presidential election, 2020s riots, 21st century in Washington, D.C., Attacks on buildings and structures in 2021, Attacks on buildings and structures in the United States, Crime in Washington, D.C., Donald Trump, January 2021 events, Joe Biden, Riots in the United States, 2021 United States Capitol attack

On the afternoon of Wednesday, January 6, 2021, thousands of supporters of President Donald Trump were in Washington, D.C. to protest against the results of the 2020 presidential election. They went in to support Trump's demand for Vice President Mike Pence and Congress to reject President-elect Joe Biden's victory. The protests soon became riots as thousands of Trump supporters broke into the United States Capitol, damaging the building. The presidential historian Michael Beschloss called the attacks an attempted coup d'etat by the President. The attack of the United States Capitol building was the worst at that location since the War of 1812. 

[[Percentage point]]

CATEGORIES: Mathematics

A percentage point or percent point is the unit for the difference between two percentages. For example, an increase of 40% to 44% is a 4 percentage point increase, but a 10 percent increase in the total.

[[Frog Lady]]

CATEGORIES: Star Wars characters

Frog Lady is a character in Star Wars who asked for help from Din Djarin. Frog Lady told Din Djarin that she could help him learn information if he helped her keep her eggs safe and bring the eggs to her husband. Din agreed but the spaceship had crashed on a winter planet. But they managed to escape and get to the location. 

[[Carlos Aránguiz]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from pulmonary fibrosis, Chilean politicians, Chilean lawyers

Carlos Ramón Aranguiz Zúñiga (18 September 1953 – 3 January 2021) was a Chilean politician and lawyer. He was born in Antofagasta, Chile. He was a member of the Supreme Court of Chile from 2014 until his death.

Aránguiz died on 3 January 2021 in Antofagasta from pulmonary fibrosis, aged 67.

[[Renate Lasker-Harpprecht]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2021 deaths, Holocaust survivors, German writers, German journalists

Renate Lasker-Harpprecht (14 January 1924 – 3 January 2021) was a German author and journalist. She survived the Holocaust, while being held at Auschwitz and Bergen-Belsen.

She died in La Croix-Valmer on 3 January 2021 at the age of 96.

[[Lisa Monaco]]

CATEGORIES: 1968 births, Living people, CNN people, Politicians from Boston, Massachusetts, US Democratic Party politicians, United States Deputy Attorneys General

Lisa Oudens Monaco (born February 25, 1968) is an American attorney and politician. Monaco is the 39th and current United States Deputy Attorney General since April 2021 during the Joe Biden administration. She was the Homeland Security Adviser to President Barack Obama.

Bagdad is a 1949 American fantasy adventure movie directed by Charles Lamont and starring Maureen O'Hara, Paul Hubschmid, Vincent Price, Jeff Corey, John Sutton, Frank Puglia. It was distributed by Universal Pictures.

[[Andor]]

Andor is a future Disney+ show set in Star Wars. The show follows a young Cassian Andor when he helps start the Rebel Alliance. The show is set five years before Rogue One and will be released in 2022.

[[Josep Fornas]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2021 deaths, Spanish businesspeople, Editors, Politicians from Barcelona

Josep Fornas Martínez (19 October 1924 – 4 January 2021) was a Spanish politician, businessman and editor. He was born in Barcelona. Fornas was a member of the Democratic Union of Catalonia and Republican Left of Catalonia. He was a member of the Parliament of Catalonia from 1980 to 1984.

Fornas died on 4 January 2021 in Barcelona, aged 96.

Singh died on 5 January 2021, aged 72.

[[Mon Mothma]]

CATEGORIES: Star Wars characters, Fictional characters introduced in 1983

Mon Mothma is a character from Star Wars.  Mon Mothma is the leader of the Rebel Alliance.

She first appears in Star Wars Episode VI: Return of the Jedi in 1983.  Caroline Blakiston played Mothma. [[Bonifácio José Tamm de Andrada]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil, Brazilian politicians, Academics, Brazilian journalists

Bonifácio José Tamm de Andrada (14 May 1930 – 5 January 2021) was a Brazilian politician, law academic and journalist. He was born in Barbacena, Minas Gerais. He was a member of the Brazilian Social Democracy Party. From 1979 to 2019, he was a member of the Chamber of Deputies.

Andrada died on 5 January 2021 in Barbacena from problems caused by COVID-19, aged 90.

[[Alan Igbon]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, British movie actors, British television actors, British stage actors, Actors from Manchester

Alan Igbon (May 29, 1952 – early December 2020) was a British actor. He acted in television series such as The Professionals, Coronation Street and Boys from the Blackstuff. Igbon was born in Hulme, Manchester.

Igbon died in December 2020, aged 68. His death was announced a month later.

[[The Barretts of Wimpole Street (1934 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 movies, 1930s romance movies, 1930s drama movies, American romantic drama movies, MGM movies, Movies based on plays

The Barretts of Wimpole Street is a 1934 American romantic drama movie directed by Sidney Franklin and was based on the 1930 play of the same name by Rudolf Besier. It stars Norma Shearer, Fredric March, Charles Laughton, Maureen O'Sullivan, Katharine Alexander, Vernon Downing, Ralph Forbes and was distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. It was nominated for 2 Academy Awards in 1935 and was remade in 1957.

[[Cassian Andor]]

CATEGORIES: Star Wars characters, Fictional characters introduced in 2016

Captain Cassian Andor is a character from Star Wars who is in the movie Rogue One. He is played by actor Diego Luna. Cassian Andor was a soldier for the Rebel Alliance and helped the Rebel Alliance steal the plans to the Death Star. During the battle, Andor was killed with the rest of his team but the mission was a success. Cassian Andor will appear in his own show, Andor released in 2022.

[[Hugh Dillon]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, Living people, Actors from Ontario, Canadian movie actors, Canadian rock singers, Canadian television actors, Canadian voice actors, Singers from Ontario

Hugh Dillon (born May 31, 1963) is a Canadian musician and actor.  He is lead singer of the rock bands Headstones and the Hugh Dillon Redemption Choir. His television acting roles include as Mike Sweeney in Durham County and Ed Lane in Flashpoint. He also voiced Nick for the Valve video game Left 4 Dead 2 (2009). Dillon was born in Kingston, Ontario.

[[Ohio General Assembly]]

CATEGORIES: State legislatures of the United States, Government of Ohio

The Ohio General Assembly is the legislature of Ohio. It has two parts: the Ohio House of Representatives (lower house) and the Ohio Senate (upper house). They both meet at the Ohio Statehouse in Columbus, Ohio. Both houses are currently control by the Republican Party.

[[The Book of Boba Fett]]

CATEGORIES: Star Wars series, English-language television programs

The Book of Boba Fett is a future Disney+ show set in the Star Wars universe. The show will have Boba Fett and Fennec Shand after they take over Jabba the Hutt's criminal empire. The show will take place during the time of The Mandalorian and also with the future shows, Ahsoka and Rangers of the New Republic. It will air on Disney+ December 2021.

==Announcement== 

A post-credit scene at the end of the season finale for The Mandalorian season two showed Boba Fett and Fennec Shand arriving at Jabba's Palace where currently Bib Fortuna was leading. Fennec entered first, killed the guards and freed the slave. Boba Fett walked in next and Bib was very surprised to see him. Boba Fett quickly killed Bib Fortuna and walked up and sat on the throne with Fennec on his side.

[[Ohio House of Representatives]]

CATEGORIES: Government of Ohio, State lower houses in the United States

The Ohio House of Representatives is the lower house of the Ohio General Assembly. It meets at the Ohio Statehouse in Columbus, Ohio. It has 99 members that each represent one district. Members are elected to two-year terms. They can only serve up to four terms, as they are term limited. The house is currently controlled by the Republican Party.

[[Pacific Coast Ranges]]

CATEGORIES: Mountain ranges of the United States, Geography of Mexico, Mountains of Canada

The Pacific Coast Ranges are officially called the  Pacific Mountain System in the United States. However, our title is what people use most.

They are the mountain ranges which stretch along the West Coast of North America from Alaska south to Central Mexico. 

The Pacific Coast Ranges are part of the North American Cordillera. Broadly speaking, the coastal ranges include the mountains and basins down the Pacific coast from Canada to Mexico. That does not include the Rocky Mountains and their basins: they are included in the North American Cordillera.

[[Lesser Sundas frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

The lesser Sundas frog (Papurana elberti) is a frog from Indonesia and East Timor.

This frog is named after Johannes Eugen Wilhelm Elbert, a German scientist.

[[Leonid Bujor]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Moldova, Moldovan politicians

Leonid Bujor (27 November 1955 – 7 January 2021) was a Moldovan politician. He served as the nation's Minister of Education from 2009 to 2011. In December 2010, he was awarded with the Order of Honour by acting President Mihai Ghimpu. Bujor was born in Singureni, Rîșcani.

On 7 January 2021, during the COVID-19 pandemic in Moldova, Bujor died of COVID-19. He was 65.

[[Internet Adult Film Database]]

CATEGORIES: 1995 establishments in the United States, Pornography, Entertainment websites

The Internet Adult Film Database (IAFD) is an online database of information related to the pornography industry actors, actresses, directors, studios, distributors and pornographic movies in the United States.

[[Rodney Williams (governor-general)]]

CATEGORIES: Antigua and Barbuda people, Knights, 1947 births

Rodney Errey Lawrence Williams is Governor-General of Antigua and Barbuda.

[[American Delta Party]]

CATEGORIES: 2016 establishments in the United States, Political parties in the United States

American Delta Party is a political party founded by Rocky De La Fuente in 2016. American Delta Party held its national convention on September 1, 2016, in Chester Springs, Pennsylvania. De La Fuente was nominated as this party's presidential nominee on August 8, 2016.His running mate was Michael Steinberg of Florida.

[[Battle of the Oranges]]

CATEGORIES: Festivals in Europe

The Battle of the Oranges is a festival in Ivrea in northern Italy. The townspeople throw oranges at each other. The festival happens every year. It lasts three days.  It is right before Shrove Tuesday, which means it is right before the Catholic Lent season.

Legend says the festival started when the townspeople killed an evil duke.  The duke wanted to have sex with women on their wedding nights, so the people started fighting. A miller's daughter named Violetta cut off the duke's head.  The orange fights are between people pretending to be the duke's men and people pretending to be Violetta's helpers.

There was no festival in 1915-18, 1942-45 nor 2021.

[[Lady Mary Colman]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2021 deaths, English philanthropists, Socialites

Lady Mary Cecilia Colman (née Bowes-Lyon; 30 January 1932 – 2 January 2021) was an English socialite, philanthropist, and extra lady-in-waiting to Princess Alexandra, The Hon. Lady Ogilvy. 

The daughter of Michael Bowes-Lyon and Elizabeth Margaret Cator, her paternal aunt was Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother, and she was thus a first cousin of Queen Elizabeth II and Princess Margaret, Countess of Snowdon. 

Lady Mary died at her home in Bixley, Norfolk on 2 January 2021, aged 88.

[[Laurent Mailhot]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2021 deaths, Canadian historians, Writers from Quebec

Laurent Mailhot (22 September 1931 – 4 January 2021) was a Canadian historian, writer and professor.

[[K-2SO]]

CATEGORIES: Star Wars characters, Fictional robots, Fictional characters introduced in 2016

K-2SO is a droid character from Star Wars. He appears in the movie Rogue One. He works with Cassian Andor and they both fight for the Rebel Alliance. K2 went on many missions with Cassian including a mission with other rebel soldiers to steal the plans to a weapon known as the Death Star. K-2SO died protecting Cassian Andor as he and Jyn Erso got the plans. K-2SO is played by Alan Tudyk. Tudyk is scheduled to play him again in the upcoming show Andor in 2022.
